nytimes_articles.headline: Restaurants
nytimes_articles.abstract: The term California cuisine may be as outdated as leisure suits, but not because of intrinsic flaws in that cooking. On the contrary, the reason the phrase has faded is that so much of this style has been embraced by American cooks of all stripes. Wood grilling, minimal saucing, wholesome ingredients, a profusion of vegetables and greens: all of these are now found in American dining rooms from coast to coast.   Three years ago Michael McCarty, sort of a reverse Balboa, trekked East toting his flavored woods and baby lettuces and discovered an eager market for them. Mr. McCarty had earned a reputation in the nascent days of California cooking with his restaurant, Michael's, in Santa Monica. He still runs it today, splitting his time between New York and California.

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton Plans to Ask Congress to Approve Smaller, Cheaper Space Station
nytimes_articles.abstract: Saying that in even tight budgetary times the nation "cannot retreat from our obligations to invest in our future," President Clinton said today that he would ask Congress to support a smaller, less-expensive version of the space station.    Mr. Clinton said a space station was crucial to the country's long-term technical leadership and a focal point for international cooperation in the post-cold war era. "At a time when our long-term economic strength depends on our technological leadership and our ability to reduce the deficit, we must invest in technology but invest wisely, making the best possible use of every dollar," he said.   Mr. Clinton and Vice President Al Gore strongly supported the concept of a space station in last year's Presidential campaign. But that support was called into question last spring when the President, under pressure to reduce the Federal deficit and Government spending, ordered the space agency to redesign the orbiting laboratory to cut its costs significantly.    The Administration said it would propose spending $10.5 billion on the space station over the next five years, asking for $2.1 billion a year starting in the fiscal year 1994. In order to construct a permanently staffed orbital laboratory, spending could reach $16.5 billion by the year 2001, it said.   Compared with spending estimates for the original Space Station Freedom, which would have taken $14.4 billion in the next five years and $25.6 billion to complete, the new proposal could save up to $9 billion in construction costs and $18 billion in operating costs over the projected 10-year life of the station, the White House estimated.   Senior Administration officials said Mr. Clinton was pleased with the proposals for cutting costs, and would make the space station a "high priority" in future budgets. "You can and should assume that the President will support this, and that he will get involved personally," said a White House official who spoke on condition that he not be identified.   In addition to redesigning the station and streamlining the program's management, Mr. Clinton called for reducing bureaucracy and personnel at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to improve efficiency.    Noting that Mr. Gore's National Performance Review team would work with the agency on proposed management changes, Mr. Clinton said, "We are going to redesign NASA as we redesign the space station." Cutbacks in Personnel    NASA has spent almost $9 billion on the space station project over the last decade and continues to spend about $150 million a month on the program.  An independent panel that reviewed the latest NASA redesign effort said most of the savings of the new design would come from major changes in the management and organization of the project, including a 30 percent reduction in the 17,000 NASA and contractor personnel working on the program.   Mr. Clinton reviewed three options for a scaled-down station and chose a combination of the two that most resembled the existing design of the space station Freedom. That design calls for pressurized modules and solar power units attached to a girder-like truss or backbone. Mr. Clinton's plan incorporates most of the elements of what was called Option A, a simplified version of Freedom with scaled-down modules and less complex electrical and data systems, but includes elements of the more expensive Option B.   The President rejected the least expensive alternative, Option C, which called for orbiting the core of a station, a pressurized cylinder with solar panels attached, launched in a single space flight. Option C, criticized as less advanced technically than the other two, would not easily have accommodated modules being developed by international partners to the project.   The White House said the Administration would spend the next 90 days working with Congress, NASA and the project's international partners in Japan, Canada and Europe to work out the details of a new, simplified design of the station. A major goal of the effort, it said, would be to expand international participation in the project, which some observers took to mean a greater role for Russia.   "I will also seek to enhance and expand the opportunities for international participation in the space station project so that the space station can serve as a model of nations coming together in peaceful cooperation," Mr. Clinton said.   Dr. John M. Logsdon, director of the Space Policy Institute at George Washington University in Washington, said the President's action could make the station a truly international project. "I read the President's statement as leaving the door wide open for enhanced Russian participation," he said.   Major supporters in Congress said the President's decision to stay with many aspects of the design now in development would help the project retain political support, particularly among Congress members with space station work in their districts. Clinton Backs Supercollider    On another technological matter, Mr. Clinton today reaffirmed his support for the Energy Department's Superconducting Supercollider in a letter to Congress, a week before the House is to debate how it would finance the project.   "These are tough economic times, yet our Administration supports this project as part of its broad investment package in science and technology," he wrote in a letter to the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, William H. Natcher, Democrat of Kentucky.   Mr. Clinton sent the letter to Congress to counter speculation that the Administration planned to trim the $8.25 billion particle-accelerator project under construction in Texas, a White House official, speaking on condition of anonymity, told The Associated Press.

nytimes_articles.headline: CLINTON AND CONGRESS: Medicare; Cutting Health Dollars to Heal Deficit
nytimes_articles.abstract: The two houses of Congress are preparing for a fight over how deeply to cut the growth of Medicare, a fight that has major implications for the nation's elderly, for doctors and hospitals, and for the success of President Clinton's plan to overhaul the nation's health-care system.   Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee said today that they were seeking much deeper cuts in the growth of Medicare, the Federal health-insurance program for the elderly and disabled, than President Clinton proposed or the House of Representatives endorsed. The extra savings would reduce the need for the Senate to vote to raise taxes as much as the House did.

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: 'Alfonso Ossorio' 'Works From the 1960's'   Zabriskie Gallery  724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street  Through June 26    In all the media he explored -- and there were several -- Alfonso Ossorio (1916-1990) tended to the ornamental and excessive, and never more so than in the jam-packed sculptural assemblages he made in the 1960's and 70's. There is something almost appalling about these "conflations," as he called them, emerging aggressively from the wall, antlers and phallic forms protruding, seashells, glass eyes, metal tools, dice and bits of driftwood stewing together like flotsam washed in by a tide.

nytimes_articles.headline: CLINTON AND CONGRESS: The Budget; Democrats Pushing Plan Toward a Vote
nytimes_articles.abstract: Shrugging off Republican accusations that they were raising taxes and cutting services for millions of Americans, the 11 Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee today started muscling the first big chunk of President Clinton's budget toward a Senate vote and enactment into law.   Tonight, Mr. Clinton focused on shielding his budget from further attacks within his own party. At a televised news conference, he said he was "drawing the line" on more concessions to conservatives in Congress who, he said, would lower the deficit by cutting deeply into Federal benefit programs rather than taking the money from the well-off.

nytimes_articles.headline: For Children
nytimes_articles.abstract: 'Family Fun Run'   Central Park  97th Street and East Drive  (212) 860-4455  Recommended ages: 2 and up  Sunday    If you're a father who's always on the run, an organized race may be the chance to seize a fast-track moment with your family this weekend. At this family run, children as young as 2 can compete, starting in an energetic 50-yard dash.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: The listing of lottery results yesterday omitted a number in some copies for New York Pick 10. The complete Pick 10 numbers appear today, on page B2.

nytimes_articles.headline: On My Mind; Do Gods Get Angry?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Do you ever get angry at them?    I had wondered about that, before I had a chance to put the question -- whether the man whom millions love as a god allowed himself anger at those who slaughter his people and their nationhood.   He did, said the Dalai Lama, in his earlier years of exile. But he found that his anger weakened him, drained him, in his struggles against the Chinese Communists who had invaded, taken over and brutalized Tibet. So no, he did not get angry anymore.

nytimes_articles.headline: President, in Prime Time, Is Spurned by 2 Networks
nytimes_articles.abstract: After weeks of awkward stumbles and generally bad news, President Clinton hit a run of good luck this week that was timed so propitiously that his advisers decided that the President was ready for prime time.   But two of the three broadcast networks decided otherwise.

nytimes_articles.headline: CLINTON AND CONGRESS: Base Closings; Aspin Asks Base-Closing Panel Not to Add to List
nytimes_articles.abstract: Defense Secretary Les Aspin today told a Presidential commission studying base closings that shutting down more than he recommended could hurt military readiness and overwhelm Pentagon efforts to help communities find new uses for closed sites.    Mr. Aspin's cautionary tone was in striking contrast to his first appearance before the commission on March 15, when he acknowledged that his list was based on outdated assumptions of the military's future size, and all but invited the panel to close several more installations.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sweep Nets 2 Scofflaws At the Wheel
nytimes_articles.abstract: Two drivers whose licenses the police said had each been suspended more than 200 times were arrested this week, the latest of more than 1,500 motorists taken into custody under a two-month-old crackdown.   The two were stopped for minor traffic violations: one made a turn without signaling, the other took an illegal shortcut through a service station parking lot. But when the officers who pulled them over ran computer checks on their licenses, they discovered that the two had been stopped time and again but had never appeared in court.

nytimes_articles.headline: Governor Florio Prunes a Fig Leaf
nytimes_articles.abstract: Gov. Jim Florio's ban on blind trusts for New Jersey's public-office holders is undeniably political. It is nonetheless a useful acknowledgment that some blind trusts are not really blind. But the Governor went too far in throwing out all such trusts. Properly used, they can be valuable.   Mr. Florio's executive order followed the embarrassing disclosure that his chief of staff, Joseph Salema, owned 50 percent of a small securities firm that has built up a disproportionate share of New Jersey bond business. Federal investigators have yet to charge anyone with wrongdoing. But the governor is up for re-election, and hardly needs a scandal in his outer office. So his chief aide is gone, and Mr. Florio is hastily tightening ship.

nytimes_articles.headline: Helping Children Beat the Odds Against Them; Harriet Tubman School in Newark Thrives, but Only by Working Outside the System
nytimes_articles.abstract: When a panel of experts recently described the Harriet Tubman Elementary School as an "island of excellence," it was referring to education in a city where too many public schools get failing grades.   But the characterization was apt for another reason. Physically and socially, Tubman is as isolated as any island, a 19th-century pile of red brick on South 10th Street, just north of what remains of the Springfield Avenue shopping district. From any vantage point across weed-choked lots or from windows of the occasional row house, Tubman stands alone, a redoubt against a sea of urban problems -- and arguably one of the best-run elementary schools in the state.

nytimes_articles.headline:
Co-op Apartment Corporations;
I.R.S. Suspends Audits in a Tax Case
nytimes_articles.abstract:
In anticipation of possible changes by Congress in the way that cooperative apartment corporations are taxed, the Internal Revenue Service has instructed its field offices to suspend audits of cases related to Section 277 of the Internal Revenue Code.

Up to now, the I.R.S. has contended that residential co-op corporations are liable under Section 277 for additional taxes on income from such sources as laundry rooms and interest on reserve funds. If the I.R.S.'s contention is upheld, most co-ops around the country could wind up owing thousands of dollars or more in back taxes and penalties.

nytimes_articles.headline: Battle Over Japanese Politics May Force Election
nytimes_articles.abstract: The long-running fight over cleaning up Japan's scandal-plagued electoral system has broken out into open political warfare, increasing the likelihood that Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa will be forced to dissolve the Parliament and call an early election.   Some senior ruling party members said the outcome of this furious struggle was still in doubt, but today most Japanese news reports were predicting that an announcement from Mr. Miyazawa dissolving the Parliament would be made this afternoon.

nytimes_articles.headline: Impossible mission: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: In the event of U.S. military intervention, Bosnia will be much like Vietnam. The soldiers who are sent there will get themselves killed in record numbers. Those who don't die will receive the world's scorn when it turns out that they are unable to accom

nytimes_articles.headline: A Serious Fratello Takes Cavaliers Job
nytimes_articles.abstract: MIKE FRATELLO , the former Atlanta Hawks coach who became a TV analyst on National Basketball Association broadcasts, was hired yesterday as coach of the Cleveland Cavaliers. Fratello succeeds LENNY WILKENS , who resigned May 24 after the Chicago Bulls eliminated Cleveland from the N.B.A. playoffs in four games.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cruel to Substitutes
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Comparing President Clinton to a substitute teacher in "Settle Down -- and Toughen Up" (editorial, June 8) was brilliant. I vividly remember poor old Mrs. Bones trying to control my fourth-grade class. She looked about 90 years old and as if she weighed in at about 80 pounds. The class was totally in control the minute she walked in the door.

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: 'Howardena Pindell'  'Abstraction as Metaphor 1972-1992'   Kenkeleba House  214-216 East Second Street  Lower East Side  Through June 23  'Howardena Pindell' 'Social and Political Work 1980-1993'   Alternative Museum  594 Broadway, at Houston Street  SoHo  Through Wednesday    In her prolific career, Howardena Pindell has moved from work that relies on formal nuances to a passionate involvement with questions of identity and politics. These two shows trace the evolution of Ms. Pindell's art over the last 20 years, with Kenkeleba House offering a retrospective of her earlier paintings and collages, while the Alternative Museum features later works on political and social themes.

nytimes_articles.headline: 77-Trombone Requiem
nytimes_articles.abstract: In honor of Father's Day, Wendy Mae Chambers's "Mass for Mass Trombones: A Requiem for 77 Trombones" is to be performed tomorrow at 9 P. M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, Morningside Heights. The nine-movement work, dedicated to the composer's father, is constructed from the 13th-century Mass for the Dead. The audience will be surrounded by 11 choirs of seven trombones each, conducted by David Gilbert. Thomas Hutchinson is to perform a solo from the pulpit. Tickets are $10. Information: (212) 662-2133.

nytimes_articles.headline: TV Weekend; Dostoyevsky by Way of Jeremy Irons
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jeremy Irons was in town this week, being celebrated for his work not in film, as outstanding as it is, but in television. The Museum of Television and Radio decided, quite rightly, to focus on Mr. Irons's performances going back to the 1970's in "Love for Lydia" and continuing through, among other productions, "Brideshead Revisited" (1980-81) and "Tales From Hollywood" (1992). Not so coincidentally, Mr. Irons can be seen doing an especially intense turn on Bravo tomorrow night, at 7 and at 1:30 A.M., in the American premiere of the BBC production of "The Dream" (1990).    Adapted by Murray Watts from "The Dream of a Ridiculous Man," Dostoyevsky's last short story, "The Dream" is a monologue. The Man -- admittedly, I'm always suspicious of characters called the Anything, but here it works -- sits in a mansionlike setting that could be either a home or an insane asylum. And he talks, directly to the camera. Staying remarkably close to the story, the Irons character begins by admitting that "I am a ridiculous man," something he has known since the moment he was born. Then he tells us of the night, one November, when he decided to kill himself.

nytimes_articles.headline: Two Careers Close To Coming Full Circle
nytimes_articles.abstract: One has lasted 11 seasons; the other has toiled for 10. They were born role players, Trent Tucker the spot-up shooter, Darrell Walker the dogged defender. They came to the Knicks a year apart, first-round draft picks at the boot camp of a drill sergeant named Hubie Brown.   If they could have merged their skills somehow, become one player, the coach might have had something nice to say. Tucker was too passive to suit him. Walker was too wild. Sometimes it was as if their mere existence got under his skin.

nytimes_articles.headline: When Court Decisions Vanish From the Record
nytimes_articles.abstract: The lawsuit drags on for years. Finally, the court reaches a decision. Then suddenly, a few months later, the ruling all but vanishes, precluded from ever being used as a precedent in future cases. What happened?   Chances are, the losing party and the winner have struck a deal: in exchange for an extra sum or some other consideration, the winner agrees to ask the judge or an appeals court to issue an order "vacating" the decision, as if it had never existed.

nytimes_articles.headline: Yankees' Owner Revives Talk of Moving His Team
nytimes_articles.abstract: George Steinbrenner's on-again, off-again love affair with the Bronx may be off again, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday.   The owner of the New York Yankees, who has threatened several times over the last decade to abandon the team's home in the Bronx, is unhappy again and is talking about exploring other potential sites for his baseball team, the Governor and his top economic adviser said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Magic Suit Continues
nytimes_articles.abstract: The woman who says MAGIC JOHNSON gave her the virus that causes AIDS won't let public disclosure of her name force her to abandon her $2 million lawsuit against the former Los Angeles Lakers star, her spokesman said.   United States District Judge RICHARD A. ENSLEN in Kalamazoo, Mich., retitled the lawsuit yesterday to include WAYMER MOORE's name. The pseudonym Jane Doe had been used on court documents since the lawsuit was filed in October. Enslen initially had ordered the woman's identity be withheld to protect her 5-year-old daughter. But Enslen reversed his decision after Johnson's attorneys argued last month that keeping her name confidential was hindering their case as they tried to learn of her sexual history.

nytimes_articles.headline: Giuliani Backs Rights On Abortion
nytimes_articles.abstract: Rudolph W. Giuliani, whose 1989 campaign for mayor at times became bogged down in questions about his commitment to abortion rights, sought yesterday to remove the issue from his 1993 campaign by emphatically endorsing a woman's right to choose abortion without limitations.   Mr. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate, made his statement at a breakfast meeting organized by his wife, Donna Hanover Giuliani, who as a television news anchor was always Donna Hanover but like another political wife is now asking for an appellation evolution.

nytimes_articles.headline: Abroad at Home; Change Is Hard
nytimes_articles.abstract: Bill Clinton ran as the candidate of change. So, in his way, did Ross Perot. A large majority of Americans voted for them and for change. But since Jan. 20 we have been relearning -- we and President Clinton -- how hard change is in the American system.   In the campaign Mr. Clinton blamed "gridlock" in Washington, the tension between a Republican President and a Democratic Congress, for inaction on national problems. By now he knows that the difficulty is far more profound.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Officials Meet With FIFA
nytimes_articles.abstract: The formation of a professional soccer league in the United States and security measures for the 1994 World Cup were the main topics discussed today by officials from FIFA, the sport's world governing body, and the World Cup's American organizers.   The news conference was held a year to the day before the World Cup's opening ceremonies in Chicago. The officials said that all the sites, except for Stanford Stadium in Palo Alto, Calif., are on schedule to meet FIFA's standards for cup sites.

nytimes_articles.headline: Diner's Journal
nytimes_articles.abstract: Today's restaurant column is Bryan Miller's last for The New York Times. At his request, he is moving to a reporting assignment in the Style department. The first column by Ruth Reichl, who was named restaurant critic for The Times last week, will appear in Weekend on Sept. 3. In the interim, Weekend will publish reviews by other food writers on the staff.   Leaving a job like this after nine years and 3,700 meals reminds me, in a benign way, of those old movies where a long-stretch prison inmate is finally paroled. You see him gather his meager belongings, say goodbye to his buddies and shuffle into the harsh sunlight, carrying a paper bag and an expression of bewilderment. Like the ex-con, I am elated to have the chains of forced feeding removed, yet at the same time, I am apprehensive about leaving a familiar and reassuring environment for a new assignment.

nytimes_articles.headline: Five Hispanic Assemblymen Endorse Badillo
nytimes_articles.abstract: Five of the seven Hispanic Democrats in the State Assembly bucked their party today and endorsed Herman Badillo for New York City Comptroller.    Mr. Badillo is running on a fusion ticket with Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican-Liberal candidate who is challenging Mayor David N. Dinkins, the Democratic incumbent.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article yesterday about President Clinton's relations with the press referred incorrectly to the communications school at the University of Pennsylvania. It is the Annenberg School for Communication.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article on Wednesday about Congressional opposition to the Clinton Administration's plan to resume nuclear testing referred incorrectly to a deadline affecting the treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons. Its signers must decide in 1995 whether to renew the treaty indefinitely or for a fixed period, although technically it does not expire.

nytimes_articles.headline: Paris Service:1 Hit, 1 Miss
nytimes_articles.abstract: After centuries of haughtiness, imperiousness, and indifference, the French are beginning to wake up to their habits. They finally recognize that such behavior is neither socially appealing nor cost-effective in the modern, competitive world. Like the Re

nytimes_articles.headline: Untangling a Massacre in South Africa
nytimes_articles.abstract: At midday the accused men amble from the courtroom to the lawn, lift their faces to the sun, smoke their cigarettes, unwrap their lunches, exchange jokes in Zulu.   The picnic scene is so casual that it is hard to connect these 32 men with a slaughter that, just one year ago, halted South Africa's transition to democracy and tarnished President F. W. de Klerk's international image with allegations of state-abetted murder.

nytimes_articles.headline: The High Court's Low Profile
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Supreme Court Justices may be feeling lonely, because they are becoming increasingly irrelevant to the nation's central political debates. They will have to get used to their lower political profile.    A glance at the docket shows that the Court is not likely to issue any blockbuster decisions before the term ends later this month. The nomination of Ruth Bader Ginsburg has provoked controversy only over the selection process. Her confirmation hearing will not -- and should not -- be an inquisition.

nytimes_articles.headline: INSIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Democrats Begin Pushing Budget Toward Full Senate   Ignoring Republican attacks about raising taxes, the 11 Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee began muscling the first big chunk of President Clinton's budget package toward a vote by the full Senate. Page A20. Surge in the Trade Deficit    The trade deficit widened again in April, to $10.49 billion, as the imbalance with Japan hit its highest level in five and a half years. Page D1. Political Struggle in Japan    Japan's Prime Minister faces pressure to call an election because of political warfare over cleaning up the nation's electoral system. Page A11. Vanishing Court Records    The Supreme Court will hear a case testing the right of litgants to agree that all records of a lawsuit should be permanently erased. Law, page D17.

nytimes_articles.headline: Daylight for Dark Angel
nytimes_articles.abstract: Arthur Ashe's dark angel stepped into the light yesterday. JOHN McENROE, whose trademark on-court outbursts had provided Ashe a vicarious outlet for his own repressed feelings, announced that he had taken his friend's place as chairman and chief angel of Ashe's favorite children's charity.    "Arthur and I had a closer relationship than people realized," McEnroe said as he accepted responsibility for the Safe Passage Foundation, the Newark-based project Ashe had established in 1990 to use tennis instruction and personal counseling to keep inner-city children in school.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Jordanian aid to Iraq in the Persian Gulf war referred incompletely to the aid the United States has withheld from Jordan. Because of Jordan's support for Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait, the United States is withholding $50 million in economic and military aid from fiscal 1992 and $26 million from fiscal 1993. Also because of an editing error, the article misstated the year of the Persian Gulf war in some editions. It was 1991, not 1992.

nytimes_articles.headline: THE ASPIRATION FOR CONSTITUTIONAL GOVERNMENT IN INDONESIA
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE ASPIRATION FOR CONSTITUTIONAL GOVERNMENT IN INDONESIA. : A Socio-legal Study of the Indonesian Konstituante 1956-1959 By Adnan Buyung Nasution. 552 pages. 45,000 rupiahs (about $22). Pustaka Sinar Harapan. .Reviewed by Adam Schwarz . IT may be true

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: In France, the paparazzi are wending their way to St.-Paul-de-Vence in Provence, where BERNARD-HENRI LEVY, the philosopher with a movie-star following, and ARIELLE DOMBASLE, an actress, are to be married tomorrow. The ceremony will be conducted in the town hall and will be followed by a dinner in La Colombe d'Or, a hotel.   Interest is building to a peak: yesterday's issue of Le Figaro contained a drawing by Karl Lagerfeld of the couple waltzing. In it, Miss Dombasle, in her Chanel wedding dress, points to Mr. Levy, who is wearing his usual white shirt worn open, and says, "Your decolletage is deeper than mine."

nytimes_articles.headline: 1918: View of Suffragists : IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: PARIS - Among the changes which this war has brought about none is more striking than the change of attitude toward women's suffrage. Before the war a "suffragist" was regarded as an anarchist in petticoats, to be pitied as a lunatic or put unde

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Art; Paul Klee as a Master Of Line Over Color
nytimes_articles.abstract: The exhibition of 77 paintings, drawings and prints by Paul Klee at the Guggenheim Museum SoHo has a magical presence. Though minute in relation to Klee's complete output of more than 9,000 works, it has a particular point of view and a specific provenance. For this and other reasons, it is irresistible but slanted (or the other way around).   The same could, of course, be said of every other Klee exhibition. His work speaks to us on a one-to-one, confidential basis. This is heightened by the fact that very often his pictures are so small that only one person at a time can stand in front of them. Our Klee is the only Klee, we think, and we don't like to have anyone else mess with him.

nytimes_articles.headline: At Long Last, Mattingly and Boggs Deliver
nytimes_articles.abstract: When the Yankees linked Wade Boggs and Don Mattingly in the batting order this season, they were ordered to attack pitchers every game, make the opposing manager cringe, make George Steinbrenner smile and keep the Yankees humming toward important baseball games in September.   It seemed appetizing. Boggs and then Mattingly. Six batting titles between them. Enough hitting knowledge to fill a textbook. Enough pivotal hits to produce a documentary. The Yankees waited for them to click as a duo. And waited and waited.

nytimes_articles.headline: Article 449393 -- No Title
nytimes_articles.abstract: For people who do not live in the vicinity of World Wide Plaza, the residential and commercial development that looks as if it has been plucked from Wall Street and dropped into Clinton, the first reaction is often disbelief. In the complex, which has houses offices, apartments, stores and a movie theater, is a miragelike brick-and-stone plaza that is as cheery as it is unknown.   You'd think that the sight of office workers sunning around the gently gushing fountain on a pretty spring day, seemingly far from the harsh asphalt and clang of Eighth Avenue, would inspire some bold entrepreneur to serve food. Well, it took two years, but Richard Barber and Katy Keck, who also own Paradice, the Bohemian food shop in the Manhattan Plaza complex, have opened New World Grill, offering simple, superbly prepared dishes with Asian and Southwestern touches.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A chart yesterday showing the distribution of ethnic groups in Nigeria misstated the percentage for those who are members of other than the Hausa, Yoruba, Ibo or Fulani. They are 33 percent of the population.

nytimes_articles.headline: Newcomers Find Success Despite the Barriers
nytimes_articles.abstract: After following their dreams to the United States, Yolanda Vasquez and her husband found themselves in a dark, three-room tenement in North Bergen with a mattress on the floor, wondering what had possessed them to leave Panama.   They had no working papers, no job connections and few prospects -- at a time when immigration laws were about to become stricter and halfway decent jobs hard to come by, even for Americans.

nytimes_articles.headline: Coleman Aids Charity
nytimes_articles.abstract: New Jersey Nets forward DERRICK COLEMAN told about 100 people at the GQ/Starlight Foundation Annual Sports Celebrity auction at the Paramount last night that in remembering the late Drazen Petrovic he has learned to live life one day at a time. That's one of the reasons he's helping the charity this year.   Coleman was one of several sports celebrities at the auction. A jersey and football autographed by Giants quarterback PHIL SIMMS sold for $1,200.

nytimes_articles.headline: President Approves Space Station Plan
nytimes_articles.abstract: Citing the role of a space station in the nation's long-term technological leadership, President Clinton gave his support to the project but called for a smaller, cheaper version of the design currently in development.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mozart in New Jersey
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Opera Festival of New Jersey is to open its 10th season tomorrow at 8 P.M. with Mozart's "Magic Flute," in English, at the Allan P. Kirby Arts Center of the Lawrenceville School, Route 206 (Main Street) in Lawrenceville. Jayne West, Richard Clement and Lawrence Craig head the cast in a production staged by Francis J. Culliman; Michael Pratt conducts. The Opera Festival will present Bizet's "Carmen" later this month, and Peter Maxwell Davies's "Lighthouse" next month. Tickets are $28 and $44. Information: (609) 936-1500.

nytimes_articles.headline: Owen, in Shift, Backs New Bosnia Plan
nytimes_articles.abstract: In an abrupt reversal, the chief European negotiator in the Bosnian war advised the besieged Muslim-dominated Government in Sarajevo today to recognize that it could not win back much of the land lost to Serbs and Croats and to "look very seriously" at a plan to carve up the country into three distinct enclaves.   Appearing unusually tired at a news conference after another series of talks, Lord Owen, the European negotiator, acknowledged that the long effort to settle the war had failed "in the sense of keeping Bosnia and Herzegovina together in the way I think would have been the fairest and the best."

nytimes_articles.headline: Simple Categories Just Don't Explain the World; Attached to Big Guns
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Samuel Huntington's June 6 Op-Ed article seems to me fictional and xenophobic. He uses religious labels to separate "civilizations," which are in a great state of flux and increasingly interdependent. Having just returned from nine months as a visiting scholar at the Central Institute of Fine Arts in Beijing, I question what he means by "Confucian civilization." Is he referring to China and Korea?   Having visited an entirely deserted Confucian temple in Suzhou (all the Government money flows to tourist sites like the gardens), I can hardly be convinced that Confucianism in its institutional, religious sense is predominant in China; making money in Western capitalist fashion is more of a current value. If any religion is making headway in China, it is Christianity, again contradicting Mr. Huntington's thesis of separately evolving religious "civilizations," sealed off and pitted against each other.

nytimes_articles.headline: Politics Spells an End to a Tribute to Boren
nytimes_articles.abstract: A $150 million Central Intelligence Agency scholarship named after Senator David L. Boren of Oklahoma was created as a tribute to his service as chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee.    But today it became a casualty of bitterness directed at its founder, a Democrat making his name with blunt criticism of President Clinton. Operating behind closed doors, the House Intelligence Committee voted unanimously to scrap the program, which had been approved in secret two years ago during Senator Boren's tenure, which ended in January.

nytimes_articles.headline: Budget Bill: Make It Better
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton's budget plan got roughed up by Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee. But the bill that is emerging would still cut the deficit by about $500 billion over five years, primarily with lower defense spending and higher taxes on families with taxable income over $100,000. The committee bill, like the President's plan, would be a step toward fiscal prudence.   Nevertheless, the bill would come at a steep price to poor workers and makes health-care reform needlessly more difficult. Senate Democrats cut $45 billion from the energy tax passed by the House. More than $35 billion of the gaping hole was filled by whacking Medicare, food stamps and tax credits for low-paid workers -- cuts that House-Senate conferees should fully restore.

nytimes_articles.headline: Woman Is Accused of Pushing Daughter Into Bronx Traffic
nytimes_articles.abstract: A Bronx woman twice pushed her 6-year-old daughter into traffic on the Grand Concourse on Wednesday evening, forcing drivers to slam on their brakes to avoid hitting the child, the police said yesterday, announcing her arrest.   Witnesses said that the daughter, Margaret Neiss, clung to her mother's leg but was pushed into traffic as they crossed the busy four-lane highway.

nytimes_articles.headline: CLINTON AND CONGRESS: Intelligence; BUDGET CUT LIKELY FOR INTELLIGENCE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Defying stern warnings from the Clinton Administration, Democrats in Congress are preparing to cut more than $1 billion from a White House intelligence budget request.   The cuts would leave the nation's intelligence agencies with only about as much money for next year as they were given by Congress this year. President Clinton had asked for an increase that would have outpaced inflation, contending that the national security requirements in the post-cold war era justified the steeper rise.

nytimes_articles.headline: F.B.I. Backs Plan to Remove Connally Bullet Fragments
nytimes_articles.abstract: The F.B.I. today endorsed the idea of removing bullet fragments from John B. Connally, the former Texas Governor who died Tuesday, in the hope of laying to rest the controversy over the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.   Mr. Connally, who was buried today at a state cemetery near Austin, Tex., was wounded in the back, wrist and thigh while riding with Kennedy in a Dallas motorcade when the President was killed on Nov. 22, 1963.

nytimes_articles.headline: Go Back to Peacekeeping In the Somali Quagmire: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: In only five days, Operation "Inflict Punishment" has wasted much of the political capital that Operation Restore Hope won for the United States during five difficult months in Somalia. By blindly supporting the United Nations attempt to impose

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; At 630 Yards, 17th Remains Unreachable
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT'S not only the longest hole in United States Open history; it's also uphill. Here in the meadows below Watchung Mountain, about 20 miles west of the World Trade Center, the 630-yard 17th hole at Baltusrol is shaped like the map of New Jersey.   It's as if the tee were down at the bottom of the Garden State Parkway near the Cape May beaches. As if those six cross bunkers out there about 400 yards were the Raritan toll booths. As if the green were up in Mahwah near the New York border.

nytimes_articles.headline: Talking Headache: Barkley Is Tired of Magic's Spiel
nytimes_articles.abstract: Charles Barkley says he isn't interested in what Magic Johnson has to say.    "Sometimes," Barkley said, "Magic talks just to hear himself talk."   One of the things Johnson said Wednesday night as analyst on NBC's telecast of Game 4 of the National Basketball Association finals was that Barkley can't be friends with Michael Jordan and play hard against him.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corruption in Government-Bought Science Needed Exposure; Not Whistle-Blowers
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   As chairman of the history department at the University of Massachusetts that employs Prof. Stephen Oates, the target of accusations of plagiarism by Walter Stewart and Ned Feder, I object to the headline and tone of "Revenge on Two Whistle-Blowers" (editorial June 4). You attribute the reassignment of Mr. Stewart and Mr. Feder more to revenge by those they have angered and embarrassed than to their own misconduct as Federal employees.

nytimes_articles.headline: Simple Categories Just Don't Explain the World
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "The Coming Clash of Civilizations or, The West Against the Rest" (Op-Ed, June 6) by Samuel P. Huntington, director of Harvard's Olin Institute for Strategic Studies, is fraught with dangerous assertions. While the article illustrates the declining importance of the nation-state, it offers a hollow paradigm of a new world order rife with competing civilizations.    To categorize the world into Western, Confucian, Japanese, Islamic, Hindu, Slavic-Orthodox, Latin American and "possibly African" civilizations is arbitrary and ahistorical at best, racist at worst. Mr. Huntington's depiction of civilizations as "the highest cultural grouping of people and the broadest level of cultural identity" follows the logic that leads to the justification of "ethnic cleansing," for he implicitly asserts that authentic, pure civilizations exist.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hear This
nytimes_articles.abstract: Michael Crichton has just signed a $2.5 million movie contract with Warner Brothers for a book he hasn't finished. Since he wrote "Jurassic Park," Warners must figure he's a good risk. The subject of the book, which doesn't have a title yet, is

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: "I want to make sure that all of us bishops understand the depth and seriousness, the pain and the agony of this problem, and why it strikes at the very heart of the church's trust level and credibility." -- BISHOP JOHN F. KINNEY, the head of a new committee of Roman Catholic bishops considering the sexual abuse of minors by priests.  [ A1:1. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: U.N. TEAM ENTERS A MUSLIM ENCLAVE
nytimes_articles.abstract: United Nations military monitors in Gorazde, in eastern Bosnia, reported tonight that the Muslim city has been heavily damaged in a three-week Serbian offensive.   After waiting three weeks for permission from commanders of the Serbian nationalist forces to enter the Gorazde enclave, which the United Nations has declared a "safe area," eight military observers finally arrived late Wednesday.

nytimes_articles.headline: Keep on the Grass, Furiously
nytimes_articles.abstract: Furiously, the speed horse who's been in a slump, may have put his career on new footing yesterday when he raced on grass for the first time and won by seven lengths at Belmont Park.   The 4-year-old son of Danzig followed in the path of his stablemate Lure, who energized his career last summer when he switched from dirt to turf and won five of his next six races. Their trainer, Shug McGaughey, tried the same switch for Furiously, who responded by streaking past five rivals in the homestretch to win a $46,000 handicap. At the wire, he had seven lengths on Say Dance, who in turn had two lengths on Permit.

nytimes_articles.headline: Public School Reading Scores Show Modest Rise
nytimes_articles.abstract: New York City's public school students showed a modest improvement this year on the annual reading test, but some of the poorest and lowest performing districts in the Bronx and Brooklyn suffered considerable declines, the Chancellor's office reported yesterday.   And though the scores were up slightly from 1992, they lagged below the record reading levels of the year before that, both for the city as a whole, and in each individual community school district.

nytimes_articles.headline: Off-Duty Corrections Officer Slain in Brooklyn
nytimes_articles.abstract: An off-duty corrections officer was shot and fatally wounded last night in East New York, Brooklyn, after he became involved in an argument between a male friend and a woman, the police said.   The shooting occurred amid a confused scene of fighting and yelling outside the Jowel Food Center on Sutter Avenue, and the precise sequence of events was not immediately clear.

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton, Praising 'Success,' Says Goal Was Not to Capture Aidid
nytimes_articles.abstract: One day after United Nations forces attacked the headquarters of a Somali clan leader, President Clinton said tonight that the military action was over and declared it a success.   "The United Nations, acting with the United States and other nations, crippled the forces in Mogadishu" of the faction leader, Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, Mr. Clinton said. "His forces were responsible for the worst attack on United Nations peacekeepers in three decades. We could not let it go unpunished."

nytimes_articles.headline: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: I see why the Americans don't intervene in the former Yugoslavia. Didn't they do the same ethnic cleansing with the Indians, the original inhabitants of North America?

nytimes_articles.headline: Welcome Jordan's King as a Friend
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United States and its allies have only a handful of truly loyal and disinterested friends at the top levels of the Arab and Muslim worlds. Among these, King Hussein of Jordan is in a class by himself. By inviting the king to a White House meeting thi

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/City Ballet; Balanchine's 'Union Jack' Revisited
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Union Jack" is not a perfect ballet but it is a perfectly ingenious one.   Unlike everyone else, George Balanchine chose to celebrate the 1976 Bicentennial of American independence from Britain by celebrating British tradition. "Union Jack," a ballet unlike any other, was the joyful if provocative result. It returned, in its multi-hued tartan glory, to the New York City Ballet on Wednesday night for the first time since 1987.    With seven kilted regiments marching through Balanchine's stylized military tattoo, an affectionate music-hall duet and the revue-style hilarity of its final navy dances, the entire spectacle ended with the expected sensational bang. The recorded cannon shots boomed through the strains of "Rule Britannia" and the dancers onstage, dressed as tars, presumably spelled out "God Save the Queen" with their semaphore flags.

nytimes_articles.headline: For Best Revenue, Tax Cigarettes $1.26
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   According to Jeffrey E. Harris, a $2 increase in the Federal excise tax on cigarettes from 24 cents a pack to $2.24 a pack would increase tax revenue from $5 billion to $33 billion (Op-Ed, June 4). Professor Harris underestimates the reduction in smoking rates that would accompany the excise tax hike and thus substantially overestimates the additional tax revenue that would be generated.

nytimes_articles.headline: Wisconsin School Wins Case On Random Locker Searches
nytimes_articles.abstract: Going significantly beyond the 1985 Supreme Court ruling on search and seizure in public school buildings, Wisconsin's highest court has ruled that school officials can search student lockers even if they have no reason to believe that any particular locker holds evidence of a crime.   Lawyers on both sides say the ruling will give the United States Supreme Court an opportunity to address a Fourth Amendment issue it left open eight years ago. In that case, New Jersey v. T.L.O. (the student in the case was identified by those initials), the Justices said students were protected by the Fourth Amendment's ban on unreasonable search and seizure, but to a lesser degree because of the need for discipline.

nytimes_articles.headline: Epitaph for a Living Quayle: Hometown Museum's 'Stuff'
nytimes_articles.abstract: Clarisa, an artist with a mass of raven black hair and only one name -- "just like Cher" -- drove all the way from Milwaukee with her 3-D laminated brass portrait of Dan Quayle.   She hoped to contribute the work, which depicts Mr. Quayle climbing the stairway of politics, with a cross in the background, to The Dan Quayle Center and Museum, which opened in the former Vice President's hometown today. She had, after all, sent one of her brassy portraits, with "Liz" emblazoned on it, to Elizabeth Taylor for the star's 60th birthday and received a thank-you note in return. 'Cream of the Cream'    But Thomas Mehl, the curator of the first Vice Presidential museum to honor a living person, refused to help Clarisa carry it inside, apparently not considering it quite right for his exhibit, "Huntington to Washington -- the Dan Quayle Trail."

nytimes_articles.headline: Singapore:Signs of Intelligent Nightlife
nytimes_articles.abstract: In yet another incarnation of the bar in Venice that Hemingway made famous, a saloon cum nightclub called Harry's has opened in Singapore. This means Singapore joins an international rostrum of cities, all proud possessor's of a "Harry's" which

nytimes_articles.headline: Brazil Prolongs Haiti's Agony
nytimes_articles.abstract: U.S. Navy and Coast Guard vessels ring its coasts. It has barely six weeks' oil supply on hand. The worldwide oil embargo voted by the U.N. Security Council on Wednesday should have marked the beginning of the end for Haiti's military regime.    But at the last minute Brazil got squeamish. The Council flinched from authorizing those vessels to enforce the embargo. The likely results: more unnecessary weeks of suffering for the Haitian people, and a weakening of Brazil's own claim to a permanent Security Council seat.

nytimes_articles.headline: Surgery for Medalist
nytimes_articles.abstract: KEVIN MAHANEY, the 1992 Olympic silver medalist in sailing who is organizing an America's Cup defense team for 1995, underwent surgery for cancer yesterday at the Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Hanover, N.H.

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Altoon Sultan   Marlborough Gallery  40 West 57th Street  Manhattan  Through July 9    The highly finished gouaches in this small exhibition of drawings and prints show Altoon Sultan's realist art at its best. Ms. Sultan's abiding interest is domestic architecture set in landscape, and since she divides her time between Southern California and rural Vermont, with a few more exotic stops along the way, the terrain she paints has considerable variety.

nytimes_articles.headline: Art in Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: Teun Hocks   P.P.O.W. Gallery  532 Broadway (near Spring Street)  SoHo  Through July 2    Like an existential nebbish, Teun Hocks, in his hilarious photographic tableaux, battles a world that corresponds too closely to both his sweetest dreams and his nightmares. Four photographs here present Mr. Hocks as a bare-chested sailor, complete with captain's hat and corncob pipe; in each, a different tattoo festoons his chest, offering updated and unmacho versions of a sailor's fantasies: a campfire, a pair of slippers, a Mercedes-Benz and a cozy cottage.

nytimes_articles.headline: Research Group's Tie to Drugmaker Is Questioned
nytimes_articles.abstract: The director of the National Institutes of Health said today that the agency would issue guidelines to help prevent future agreements like the one in which The Scripps Research Institute agreed to give a Swiss drug company all its discoveries for up to 20 years.   In her last appearance before Congress as director of the institutes, Dr. Bernadine P. Healy told the House small-business subcommittee on regulation the results of her agency's survey of 380 agreements between universities and companies.

nytimes_articles.headline: 1943:Japanese Attack : IN OUR PAGES: 100, 75 AND 50 YEARS AGO
nytimes_articles.abstract: AN ADVANCED SOUTH PACIFIC BASE - [From our New York edition:] A force of about 120 Japanese bombers and fighter planes attempted to attack Guadalcanal on June 16 but American fighters shot down 77 planes in a major air victory. Only six American fighters

nytimes_articles.headline: Oh Is the Teen Spirit at the Open
nytimes_articles.abstract: His shirt was two sizes too big, flopping over the top of his pants, which were a few inches too long. And his slender club bag was definitely not the big, bulky leather job the touring pros' caddies usually strain under.   But Ted Oh, a 16-year-old Californian whom few people had heard of until this week, even in California, became the instant darling of the 93d United States Open with his first tee shot today at the Baltusrol Golf Club.

nytimes_articles.headline: Turgeon Is a Gentleman and a Scorer
nytimes_articles.abstract: Pierre Turgeon of the Islanders, married earlier this month, now has another lady in his life.   She is Lady Byng, the trophy given each year by the National Hockey League to "the player adjudged to have exhibited the best type of sportsmanship and gentlemanly conduct combined with a high standard of playing ability."

nytimes_articles.headline: Sihanouk Is Reunited With Son, Who Vows Secession Bid Is Over
nytimes_articles.abstract: Only days after he announced a secessionist movement in Cambodia's eastern provinces, the wayward son of Prince Norodom Sihanouk was reunited today with his father and promised that his secessionist campaign was over.   "This audience marks the official end of the 'secessionist' movement in certain provinces of Cambodia," the royal palace said in a statement after the meeting between Prince Sihanouk, Cambodia's head of state, and the son, Prince Norodom Chakrapong.

nytimes_articles.headline: U.S. Team Quits Tour de France Over Shared Slot
nytimes_articles.abstract: Angered by being told it would have to share a slot in the Tour de France, the Subaru-Montgomery team based in the United States decided late Wednesday to withdraw from the bicycle race. ."The team feels it deserves a full squad in the race, not a

nytimes_articles.headline: Assembly Tax-Cut Plan Fans Political Flames in Trenton
nytimes_articles.abstract: It will be at least weeks before the tax-cut proposal that the Assembly Speaker introduced today comes to a vote, but the political impact of his move was immediate.   It set off a heated exchange between Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian and Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco, while sending both Gov. Jim Florio and his Republican rival, Christine Todd Whitman, scrambling for safe political ground.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Stronger Voice of America
nytimes_articles.abstract: It may be a shotgun marriage, but the fusion of America's two international broadcasting services seems a good outcome. President Clinton has endorsed a proposal that would consolidate the Voice of America with its independently operated rivals in Munich, Radio Free Europe and Radio Liberty. The merger would eliminate overlap, save money and strengthen the Voice.    Most important, the Voice of America would gain greater independence from political meddling. The Voice has never had the independence of the Munich stations. But now it would be protected by a new heat shield: a seven-member, bipartisan Board of Governors for Broadcasting that would be named by the President and confirmed by the Senate.

nytimes_articles.headline: 25 Players Conspire To Remain 24 1/2 Back
nytimes_articles.abstract: The vision of a viable future for the Mets arrived in the fifth inning here at Three Rivers Stadium tonight. The crowd that had come together at the mound dispersed, the latest pitcher headed for the showers, the infielders to their positions. There, alone with the baseball, stood Dallas Green. The Mets' manager bent, picked up the resin bag and climbed the hill again.   Was the manager going to pitch? Could it hurt? A search of the record books was undertaken. Green, a pitcher in parts of seven seasons in the majors, last worked on the mound in 1967. He was undefeated that season. Hey, so what that he was also without a victory and had an earned run average of 9.00. The Mets aren't looking for triumphs anymore. To be merely entertaining would be enough.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Art Market
nytimes_articles.abstract: Grosvenor House Fair   London is buzzing this week with antiques dealers, museum curators, collectors and socialites from every major art capital in the world. The Grosvenor House Antiques Fair is the main attraction. For the social set, the 59-year-old show, which opened on June 9, falls neatly between the Derby and Ascot, and lovers of art and antiques flew in from all over the world for the gala on June 10. It is sandwiched between two new shows: the British Antique Dealers Association's fair, which took place in London just six weeks ago, and what dealers refer to as the "Harrods Fair," the International Art and Antique Show, which opens on Nov. 11 on the department store's third floor.   Competition is always daunting, even for so well-established a show as Grosvenor House. So was the prospect of another bleak season, but the mood among dealers has been surprisingly upbeat. Quite a change from the close of last year's fair, when 18 dealers (nearly 20 percent of those participating) dropped out, saying they just hadn't made enough money. Major names like Didier Aaron, Colnaghi, Carlton Hobbs and Richard Feigen were missing from this year's roster.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Film: Last Action Hero; A Hero Within and Without
nytimes_articles.abstract: Young boy links up with film detective, on and off screen. Like a long ``Saturday Night Live'' sketch with great special effects.

nytimes_articles.headline: Norris Loses His Cool
nytimes_articles.abstract: Super welterweight champion TERRY NORRIS , usually calm amid the bravado of boxing news conferences, lost his cool yesterday in San Diego while responding to comments about the Saturday fight card he heads.

nytimes_articles.headline: You Can't Cut Costs With Living Wills
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   In "Good Ethics, Good Health Economics" (Op-Ed, June 8), Joseph C. d'Oronzio assumes living wills would always be operative when patients are dying, stopping unnecessary medical care and thus controlling health care costs. But living wills were developed so that patients' decisions about medical treatment would remain in effect even if they became incompetent and terminally ill.

nytimes_articles.headline: Reviews/Film; Nature: Good! Toxins: Bad! Very Bad!
nytimes_articles.abstract: Appealing, pensive animation.

nytimes_articles.headline: GE Took No Shortcuts: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR
nytimes_articles.abstract: Regarding "GE Lights a Painful Path to Prosperity" (Business/Finance, June 8): .The implication that General Electric's revitalization in the 1980s involved a large increase in debt and a decline in research and development is incorrect. GE t

nytimes_articles.headline: For Father's Day, Jim Pierce Is Given a Ban
nytimes_articles.abstract: Citing conduct unbecoming by a parent of one of its players, the Women's Tennis Council today banned Jim Pierce, father of 14th-ranked Mary Pierce, from Wimbledon and all remaining events on the 1993 Kraft Tour.   The decision, which Pierce is expected to appeal, is unprecedented in the sport but was not unexpected. Pierce's continual verbal interference during his daughter's matches, along with his highly publicized fistfight with two Dutch spectators at the French Open last year, had eventually led to his being placed on probation in January. And it had left him subject to a new W.T.C. rule that punishes such conduct with a suspension, a fine, or both.

nytimes_articles.abstract: EMPIRE ADMITS MISLEADING LEGISLATURE   Officials of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, who acknowledged on Wednesday that they had provided state regulators with false financial data, say that they also misled state legislators last year by using the data to secure a major rescue plan for the company. IMMIGRANTS' SUCCESS STORY   After following their dreams to the United States, Yolanda Vasquez and her husband are finally, like many thousands of other immigrants who make their way against great odds, on the verge of success. A1. NEW YORK CITY

nytimes_articles.headline: Yeltsin Promises Ukraine Security Guarantees
nytimes_articles.abstract: Meeting with President Leonid M. Kravchuk of Ukraine at a country house outside Moscow, President Boris N. Yeltsin today confirmed Russia's willingness to give Ukraine security guarantees.   The guarantees would come as the Ukrainian Parliament considers ratification of the first strategic arms treaty, known as Start I, and a related vote on the country's non-nuclear status.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Art; Glass Sculptors Whose Work Transcends Craft
nytimes_articles.abstract: The cold war between contemporary art and crafts is still on. The Pattern and Decorative movement of the 1970's tried to effect a truce, but negotiations faltered in the 80's. A furniture-as-art vogue came and went overnight, and craft objects showed up in the work of consumerist artists like Jeff Koons and Haim Steinbach chiefly for their irony value. The present trend toward multiculturalism might reconcile the two categories, and exhibitions like "Africa Explores" at the Center (now Museum) for African Art a few years ago demonstrated how it could be done. But crossover figures in New York City galleries are still rare.   All of which gives "Glass Installations," at the American Craft Museum, more than usual interest. The six participating artists have created large-scale, site-specific installations from glass, a medium long identified with discrete functional forms and highly specialized techniques. In doing so, they obscure -- with varying degrees of success -- the line between traditional craft and the kind of politically and psychologically motivated installation art popular today. While none of the work in the show is earthshakingly radical -- in fact, some of it feels vaguely familiar and expressively tepid -- it represents a step in an interesting direction, and a good one for the American Craft Museum to be taking at this time.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rhode Island Governor Settles Paternity Suit
nytimes_articles.abstract: Gov. Bruce Sundlun of Rhode Island and a 17-year-old Michigan girl announced yesterday that they had agreed to a settlement of a paternity suit that she had filed against him.   Smiling broadly and holding hands at a Statehouse news conference, Mr. Sundlun and the girl, Kara Kathleen Hewes, said the Governor had agreed to treat her as his daughter and pay her tuition to the University of Michigan beginning this fall.

nytimes_articles.headline: THE MOVIE GUIDE : L'Odeur de la Papaye Verte
nytimes_articles.abstract: Directed by Tran Anh Hung. France. . Saigon in the 1950s: Mui, a 10-year-old peasant girl, has come to serve a rich family. A discreet, almost invisible spy, she learns their secrets - the husband runs the household to ruin. Ten years later, she moves on

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Film; Blood, Fire And Death, Slow-w-wly
nytimes_articles.abstract: Smugglers vs. police. Mandarin melodrama via Hong Kong, crammed with violence and corpses. Standard bulger.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cason Outraces Stars and Doctors
nytimes_articles.abstract: Andre Cason received a diagnosis of a ruptured Achilles' tendon, a career-ending injury, less than a year ago. His trusted coach, Loren Seagrave, was suspended indefinitely by USA Track & Field in January.   But in the mercurial sport of track and field, nothing is forever. The diagnosis was incorrect. Seagrave was still allowed to be a consultant. And tonight, the diminutive Cason defeated a star-studded field to capture the men's 100-meter dash in the USA/ Mobil championships here at Hayward Field.

nytimes_articles.headline: Fore! The Mother of All Traffic Jams
nytimes_articles.abstract: After all the years of planning to stage the United States Open at the Baltusrol Golf Club here this year, 30,000 parking passes were issued for 15,000 parking spots. Today's chaos resulted.   It was worse than imagined, or even imaginable, beginning at the one-lane exit of Route 24 West, where four lanes of cars, buses, limos and taxis had to head for one narrow off ramp. Then came an even more tortuous trek down not-quite-Broad Street to Overlook, and left to reach Baltusrol three miles away.

nytimes_articles.headline: EMPIRE BLUE CROSS GAVE FALSE REPORT TO '92 LEGISLATURE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Officials of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield, who acknowledged on Wednesday that they had provided state regulators with false financial data, said yesterday that they also misled state legislators last year by using the data to help secure a major rescue plan for the company.   The figures exaggerated Empire's financial losses on its policies with high-risk customers, generally its oldest and sickest, a group the insurer had argued posed a special burden. Those figures were used in legislative testimony, and reinforced in a major lobbying campaign, to help persuade lawmakers to enact a series of changes in insurance laws sought by Empire, said the officials, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'A Rosenberg Cantata'
nytimes_articles.abstract: Leonard Lehrman is to conduct the Metropolitan Philharmonic Chorus tomorrow in a revised version of his work "We Are Innocent: A Rosenberg Cantata," in commemoration of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg on the 40th anniversary of their execution.  The performance, with the soloists Helene Williams, soprano, and Ronald Edwards, tenor, starts at 8 P.M. at the Unitarian Church on Plandome Road in Plandome, L.I. The concert is being presented by the Prof. Edgar H. Lehrman Memorial Foundation and the National Committee to Reopen the Rosenberg Case. Admission is by donation. Information: (516) 626-0238.

nytimes_articles.headline: On Stage, and Off
nytimes_articles.abstract: ALBERT HIRSCHFELD knows just how he'll celebrate his 90th birthday on Monday. After a long day at the drawing board (he works seven days a week), he and his wife, Dolly, will be first-nighters, as is their custom. That evening just happens to be the opening of the revival of "Camelot" on Broadway, "and I'm going to pretend that the cast party is for me," he says.    In a way, each first night is a party for this man, who has attended virtually every Broadway opening since the late 1920's. There will, of course, be formal nonagenarian observances for this conjuror of line and perspective whose caricatures have been appearing in the drama pages of The New York Times for 66 years. Today, tomorrow and Sunday, Mr. Hirschfeld will be dropping in at a three-day birthday celebration in his honor, an open-house retrospective of his work at the Margo Feiden Galleries (699 Madison Avenue, at 62d Street, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.).

nytimes_articles.headline: Bishops Struggle Over Sex Abuse By Parish Priests
nytimes_articles.abstract: Confronting a problem that has increasingly undermined confidence in their leadership, the nation's Roman Catholic bishops today took their first steps toward creating a nationwide policy for investigating and preventing the sexual abuse of minors by priests.    At a semiannual meeting, the National Conference of Catholic Bishops announced the creation of a special committee of seven bishops to draw up a plan for rooting out past and potential offenders, for providing care to victims and for preventing further misconduct.

nytimes_articles.headline: Woodbury Journal; Q. What's Grist for the Gardener? A. BBC Show
nytimes_articles.abstract: The first question came from Sheila Spencer, a local woman: Could the panel suggest something besides a small shrub she might try growing over an old cesspit on her lawn? It had just swallowed her viburnum tinus.   On the stage of the Woodbury village hall, hunched behind a long table covered in green baize and draped in thick cables, the four touring panelists from the British Broadcasting Corporation's "Gardeners' Question Time," one of Britain's longest running radio programs, leaned into their microphones and mulled the alternatives.

nytimes_articles.headline: Girl Scout Cookie Monsters
nytimes_articles.abstract:
The Girl Scouts' national organization reaps more than $400 million a year from what it calls "girl generated income" -- cookie sales. But, The Wall Street Journal reported last month, "People buy the cookies thinking they are helping the Girl Scouts, not knowing that the Girl Scouts themselves only get 40 cents a box." The rest goes to financing the organization's bureaucracy. 

This spurred me to drag out my fifth grade diary. A sample reading leaves me mystified as to what the troop leaders even had to show for our 40 cents.

nytimes_articles.headline: What They're Reading
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sir Leon Brittan, EC trade commissioner, has just finished reading Joseph Conrad's volume of short stories "Typhoon," and is now reading David McCullough's "Truman." ."I have just started it. He is just doing a series of menia

nytimes_articles.headline: CHRONICLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Love blooms in Washington: TONY RODHAM, 38, the younger of Hillary Rodham Clinton's two brothers, and NICOLE BOXER, 25, the daughter of Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, have become engaged and will be married next spring.   The engagement was announced yesterday by the Boxer family in Marin County, Calif., and by Dorothy Rodham, Mr. Rodham's mother, in Little Rock, Ark. Mr. Rodham's father, Hugh Rodham, died in April.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gotti Lawyer Argues To Overturn Verdict
nytimes_articles.abstract: Listening to legal arguments on whether John Gotti's murder-racketeering conviction should be overturned, a panel of judges yesterday peppered a prosecutor with questions about why Bruce Cutler had been barred from acting as a defense lawyer in the Gotti trial.   The three-judge panel, which seemed more troubled by the disqualification of Mr. Cutler, Mr. Gotti's longtime lawyer, than by any other issue in Mr. Gotti's appeal, reserved its decision after hearing the arguments. Judge Amalya L. Kearse presided over the panel in a packed Manhattan courtroom of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

nytimes_articles.headline: Excerpts From Clinton's News Conference at the White House
nytimes_articles.abstract: Following are excerpts from President Clinton's news conference tonight at the White House, as recorded by The New York Times: OPENING STATEMENT    Ladies and gentlemen, first I want to speak with you about a situation that all of us have followed very closely in the last week. And that is the United Nations action in Somalia. General Powell reported to me this afternoon that this operation is over and that it was a success. The United Nations, acting with the United States and other nations, has crippled the forces in Mogadishu of warlord Aidid and remains on guard against further provocation. Aidid's forces were responsible for the worst attack on U.N. peacekeepers in three decades. We could not let it go unpunished. Our objectives were clear. The U.N. sought to preserve the credibility of peacekeeping in Somalia and around the world to get the food moving again and to restore security.

nytimes_articles.headline: On the Western Door It Says 'Please Don't Disturb'
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Balkan war has deeply shaken opinion throughout Europe, but with this revealing difference: While the West is agonizing over the moral implications, people in the East worry about their own security. .From where I am writing, next door to the vast

nytimes_articles.headline: 2 Are Arrested In the Theft Of Tax Checks
nytimes_articles.abstract: An employee of the New York City Finance Department was arrested on charges of stealing checks worth $698,000, investigators said yesterday.   The employee, Damon Sidberry, 25, stole 77 checks, officials at the city's Department of Investigation and the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

nytimes_articles.headline: Review/Theater; Episodes From Life In a Modern Matriarchy
nytimes_articles.abstract: "So much of life depends on when you stop the story," a young woman says in "The Brooklyn Trojan Women," by Carole Braverman. If the playwright shared that conviction, her play would surely be a different affair.   This partly autobiographical piece about the family of an 80-year-old former actress presents several stories: the old woman's memories of love and tragedy in a Jewish village in Poland, the idealistic pursuit of justice in Nicaragua by one of her granddaughters, and the competition between two other granddaughters for a married man one of them has picked up on the Belt Parkway in Brooklyn. These stories do not really mesh, emotionally or conceptually. They simply occur in a series of episodes that inevitably remind one of the plotting of daytime soap operas.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corruption in Government-Bought Science Needed Exposure
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   "Revenge on Two Whistle-Blowers" (editorial, June 4) objects to the use by Walter Stewart, my fraud-busting colleague, of a hunger strike to protest muzzling by our employer, the National Institutes of Health. Without the hunger strike, would you have written an editorial?   Scientific fraud wastes money and leads to the punishing of whistle-blowers. More important, fraud and the way it is covered up are signs of bad ethics, which cost more in other ways. The problem is dirty politics, incubating in American science since World War II, when the Government started paying for most research.

nytimes_articles.headline: Owners Approve Playoff Format
nytimes_articles.abstract: Major league club owners yesterday endorsed an expanded playoff format for 1994, but in a rare development for them, they listened to the players union and omitted the details for the plan that doubles participation in post-season play.    In another development related to the union and coming negotiations for a new collective bargaining agreement, the owners moved toward resolving the issue of enhanced revenue sharing, a proposal that their chief labor executive, Richard Ravitch, has been aggressively urging them to accept.

nytimes_articles.headline: CLINTON AND CONGRESS: Campaign Finance; Senate Passes Measure to Curb Aid From PAC's
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Senate today passed campaign finance legislation that would create voluntary spending limits and reduce the amounts that political action committees can give candidates.   The Senate bill actually proposes to ban PAC contributions absolutely, but it adds that if that is found to be unconstitutional, as many senators believe, the contributions must be reduced to $1,000.

nytimes_articles.headline: Search for a Chancellor Focuses on 10 Prospects
nytimes_articles.abstract: With less than two weeks remaining in Joseph A. Fernandez's tenure as New York City's Schools Chancellor, the committee named to find his replacement has focused its scrutiny on 10 candidates, school officials said yesterday.   As the search moves into its final stages -- with Board of Education members saying they hope to name the new Chancellor by June 30 -- the racial politics of the unfolding mayoral race are expected to play an increasingly prominent role.

nytimes_articles.headline: COURTS IN NIGERIA DIFFER ON ELECTION
nytimes_articles.abstract: The outcome of Nigeria's presidential elections was thrown into further confusion today when two separate federal courts -- in conflict with a third -- ordered the military Government to release the results of voting on Saturday.   On Wednesday, the National Electoral Commission suspended the publication of final election results after the federal High Court of Abuja ruled that they should not be made public until allegations of corruption and vote-tampering were heard. The Abuja court's decision came in response to a lawsuit by the Association for a Better Nigeria, a private lobbying group that wants the Government of Gen. Ibrahim Babangida to stay on for at least four more years.

nytimes_articles.headline: Troops Storm Somali Chief's House but He's Gone; U.N. Attack in Mogadishu Follows Hours of Bombing by U.S.
nytimes_articles.abstract: After hours of American bombardment that shook the city, United Nations troops stormed the headquarters of Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid early this morning, but the Somali clan leader and his top aides were not there.    The center of Mogadishu was transformed into a battlefield as aircraft led the assault and peacekeepers swept through the city. United Nations troops cordoned off General Aidid's compound, but then became caught up in firefights with Somali gunmen.

nytimes_articles.headline: Racing Report Is In, And Jockeying Begins
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sweeping changes in operating, taxing and betting on horse racing in New York State were proposed to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday when his special commission released its report on how to revive an industry that it said was "in decline in New York State and throughout the nation."   The report sprang no surprises after nine months of hearings and two months of briefings. But it did concede that "the reform process will be long, difficult and at times frustrating," especially since its main provisions would have to be approved by the Legislature. And the Governor took the occasion to renew his attack on the New York Racing Association for "having blown the whole racing industry."

nytimes_articles.headline: Serial Killer Is Stalking London Homosexuals
nytimes_articles.abstract: A serial killer here is stalking homosexuals, and the police appealed to him today to give himself up.   Since March 8 the killer is believed to have killed five men after picking them up in bars and nightclubs. All of the victims were found in their homes, naked and strangled or asphyxiated.
