Pete Hamm caught two touchdown passes for Sacramento -- an 11-yarder from David Archer in the second quarter and a 13-yarder from Kerwin Bell in the third. Winnipeg quarterback Matt Dunigan and Sacramento defensive end Randy Thorton were ejected 2 minutes 11 seconds into the game. Dunigan lost his cool after a late hit, ripped the helmet off a Gold Miners' player and threw the headgear 50 yards down the field. Another proposed United States expansion team -- the San Antonio Texans -- folded because of financial trouble. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Investing Without the Frills
nytimes_articles.abstract: DO you have a talent for spotting a good stock, but feel you lack the necessary funds to realize your ambitions? Or are you simply looking for a cost-effective means of buying and selling international equities? Rather than plump for a mutual fund - an un

nytimes_articles.headline: Theme Schools Face Hurdles In Opening
nytimes_articles.abstract: As they race to open more than 30 small experimental public schools in the fall, New York City educators say they are grappling with an array of difficulties -- from hiring directors to finding buildings to signing up students.   Four of the 37 small new schools will not open in September as originally planned, school officials said yesterday. All four will instead open in the fall of 1994.

nytimes_articles.headline: Survival of Symphonies: Radical Changes Urged
nytimes_articles.abstract: One year ago, the American Symphony Orchestra League took its own pulse and did not like what it found. Bad news about American orchestras, their finances, their audiences and their musical operations had been trickling in piecemeal for years. The so-called Wolf report, a study commissioned by the league, documented what most had long suspected.   The Wolf report also inspired a task force of 150 people within and outside the music world. They have been meeting over the last year, addressing issues like repertory, labor relations, community life, cultural diversity, education, volunteerism, fund raising and management.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tolbert's Victory Prevents a Devers Sweep
nytimes_articles.abstract: Hurdles, real and conceptual, were in the way. All were cleared tonight, by national champions Lynda Tolbert and Jack Pierce at the USA/Mobil championships.   At a hot and humid Hayward Field, Tolbert overcame favorite Gail Devers, plus medical problems that included a torn hamstring, stress fractures in both her feet and chronic anemia. She edged Devers in a photo finish, winning the women's 100-meter hurdles in 12.72 seconds to foil a historic attempt at a double by her more famous rival.

nytimes_articles.headline: Catherine Harris, Michael Shraga
nytimes_articles.abstract: Catherine Lawrence Harris, the managing editor of equity research at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., was married yesterday to Michael Robert Shraga, a managing director at the Bankers Trust Company, both in New York. The Rev. James B. Jeffrey performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, L.I.   Mrs. Shraga, 41, graduated from Trinity College in Hartford. She is the daughter of Mrs. Eckley B. Coxe of East Hampton, and the late David T. Harris. Her father was a senior executive vice president with the United States Trust Company in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Headline
nytimes_articles.abstract: As a nation, we have pretty much developed our notion of minority policy based on the black population, and just stuck Latinos and Asians into that profile. The problem is that the profile doesn't fit.  DAVID HAYES-BAUTISTA, a sociologist at U.C.L.A. [ 27:4. ]

nytimes_articles.headline: Nita Lelyveld, Benjamin Powers
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nita Lelyveld, a daughter of Carolyn and Joseph Lelyveld of New York, and Benjamin Erling Powers, a son of Sally and William Powers of Needham, Mass., were married yesterday in a civil ceremony at the country home of the bride's parents in Gardiner, N.Y.    The bride, 28, is a writer for The Associated Press in Washington. She is a magna cum laude graduate of Harvard University. Her mother is the director of the Bronx Municipal Hospital Day-Care Center, which serves children with AIDS. The bride's father is the managing editor of The New York Times.

nytimes_articles.headline:
The View From: Chappaqua;
Raising Orchids Presents an Exotic Challenge
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WHEN Bill Smiles talks about orchids, his voice is tinged with what may be best described as awe. "Stop to think about the plant I'm holding in my hand," he said recently. "It was plucked from a forest in Thailand, shipped to my home in Chappaqua; then I put it in my greenhouse here, and I am trying to make it grow. What a challenge!

"No, not just a challenge -- an addiction. You get 1 orchid, then you get 2, then 4, then 8, 16, 32 and onward. If you get 1 and you're successful with it, I guarantee you will wind up with 1,000."

nytimes_articles.headline:
THING;
At Last, A Thang
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WHAT: It has one neck, one head, shoulders and a waist. No arms, no legs, but it does get around. It has accompanied everyone from yodeling cowpokes to Tommy Smothers. Woody Guthrie contended that his could kill a Fascist. Bluesmen like Robert Johnson swore their licks came straight from the Devil, by all accounts one mean axman. Even Elvis, the King himself, wiggled and warbled with a leather-encased Martin dreadnought slung at his side. The pearl-inlaid Martin, in fact, vintage or new, is the ne plus ultra of acoustic guitardom -- vintage models can set you back almost six figures.
THIS IS NEW? What's new is that last year, the acoustic guitar actually outsold its aggressive electric offspring by $16 million, after the electric, and the 80's synthesizer explosion, had virtually placed it on the endangered species list. And Eric Clapton's penchant for self-effacement finally panned out on his "Unplugged" album, which snagged him the Grammys that had eluded him through nearly three decades of megawatt rock stardom.

nytimes_articles.headline: Elise B. Packard, Bryan D. Jones
nytimes_articles.abstract: Elise Barry Packard, a daughter of Sandra G. Packard and Thomas W. Packard, both of New York, was married yesterday to Bryan David Jones, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Larry Jones of Knoxville, Tenn. The Rev. William Bergen, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. Robert Graham, an Episcopal minister, took part in the ceremony.   Ms. Packard, 26, is keeping her name. She is a clerk for Chief Judge Judith W. Rogers of the District of Columbia Court of Appeals. She and her husband graduated magna cum laude from Brown University. The bride received a law degree from Georgetown University.

nytimes_articles.headline: RESULTS PLUS
nytimes_articles.abstract: TENNIS Navratilova Wins For Martina Navratilova, it was a familiar first step. First Eastbourne, then Wimbledon. Seven of Navratilova's nine Wimbledon crowns have followed triumphs on the grass courts at Eastbourne, England. Yesterday, the top-seeded Navratilova captured a record 11th singles title in this warm-up tournament, defeating Miriam Oremans of the Netherlands, 2-6, 6-2, 6-3. Oremans, ranked 42d in the world, stunned the American in the first set with a biting serve and competent net play. The 20-year-old Dutch player, playing in her first final on the women's tour, became rattled in the third set and received a warning for racket abuse after several unforced errors. (AP) Leconte Takes German Title: Henri Leconte won his ninth career tournament yesterday and taught Andrei Medvedev a lesson on grass by routing the young Russian, 6-2, 6-3 in the final of the Halle Open in Germany. Leconte, a few weeks shy of his 30th birthday, dominated the match against the 18-year-old Ukranian, who was playing only his second tournament on grass. Medvedev has climbed to No. 9 in the world after winning two tournaments and reaching the French Open semifinals last month. (AP)   Quick Work by Stoltenberg: Unseeded Jason Stoltenberg defeated fellow Australian Wally Masur, 6-1, 6-3 yesterday to win the Direct Line Insurance Manchester Open in England for his first tour title.(AP) AUTO RACING Toyota Leads Le Mans Eddie Irvine drove Toyota into a tenuous lead over the defending champion Peugeot of Philippe Alliot and 45 other drivers in the Le Mans 24-hours yesterday, with both carmakers trading the lead and suffering serious setbacks with some of their racers.   Five hours into the race, the Toyota TS-010 driven by Irvine and Japan's Masanori Sekiya and Toshio Suzuki held about a one-minute lead over the pole-sitting Peugeot 905 of Alliot, fellow Frenchman Jean-Pierre Jabouille and Italian Mauro Baldi. Another Peugeot 905 was in third.   A Toyota RY-2 from the turbo-charged Category II was a surprising fourth place, followed by another Toyota TS-010. (AP) BOWLING Williams Wins 3d Title Walter Ray Williams Jr. became the first three-time winner this year on the Professional Bowlers Association tour when he beat Bryan Goebel, 258-254, in the championship match of the $125,000 Northwest Classic in Kennewick, Wash., yesterday. (AP) SOCCER Ecuador Tops U.S. Ecuador, getting goals from Raul Aviles and Eduardo Hurtado, beat the United States, 2-0, yesterday in Quito, Ecuador, and became the first team to qualify for the America Soccer Cup quarterfinals. Aviles scored in the 10th minute and Hurtado in the 35th for Ecuador. Angel Fernandez assisted on both goals.   Ecuador leads Group A with 4 points, followed by Uruguay with 3 and Venezuela with 1. The United States has no points. The United States is on the brink of elimination, although it could still qualify by beating Venezuela on Tuesday. The two best third-place teams also will remain in the competition. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: American Indian Artists Deserved Better Review
nytimes_articles.abstract: I was dismayed at Vivien Raynor's inappropriately brief review of "Bridging Two Worlds: Contemporary Native American Art," the exhibition that I co-curated at the Pelham Art Center. The review  [ "Finding One's Way in Contemporary and Native America" ]  appeared on May 16.   The "Bridging Two Worlds" exhibition includes works by seven Native American artists from all over the country and the accompanying catalogue essay, based on interviews with them, is 12 pages. Moreover, this is the most thorough exhibition of its kind ever presented in Westchester, and given multicultural concerns, it is unfortunate that Ms. Raynor found little to say.

nytimes_articles.headline: Miss Kyropoulos, Mr. McIntyre
nytimes_articles.abstract: Adriane Kyropoulos, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Kyropoulos of Hartsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Fred Headen McIntyre 3d, a son of Mr. McIntyre Jr. of Lexington, N.C., and the late Ann M. McIntyre. The Rev. Peter N. Kyriakos performed the ceremony at Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Church in New Rochelle, N.Y.   Mrs. McIntyre, 25, is a database administrator in the New York law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton. She and her husband graduated from Duke University.

nytimes_articles.headline: O'Rourke at Work: A Look At How Things Are Done
nytimes_articles.abstract: ANDREW P. O'ROURKE gathered his cabinet in the conference room next to his office one day recently to discuss Peekskill and the surrounding area. Arriving a half-hour late from a call-in show at radio station WVOX in New Rochelle, Mr. O'Rourke began questioning the commissioners, essentially asking each one, "What's new?"   The aim was not to establish policy or even review it; the County Executive holds weekly so-called issues meetings with eight close aides for that. No, the commissioners were there to prepare the County Executive for a Town Hall meeting he had scheduled for the following evening.

nytimes_articles.headline: Just Sit Down Anywhere and Tell Us What's New
nytimes_articles.abstract: It's time to get to the bottom of one of the major mysteries of television in the 90's: Why is Dan Rather on the left and Connie Chung on the right?   Surprisingly, considering how many male-and-female local anchor teams are on the air and how many network programming decisions are based on extensive audience research, Mr. Rather and Ms. Chung seem to have sailed into uncharted territory. "There's no evidence I can find that the placement of the anchors makes a difference," said Frank N. Magid, a consultant who is widely credited with developing the bantering-anchor local news format known as "happy talk."

nytimes_articles.headline: Happy Days?
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE FIFTIES By David Halberstam. Illustrated. 800 pp. New York: Villard Books. $27.50.

nytimes_articles.headline:
On the Job With Jack Provenzano;
Plying the Road to Rescue All Those Who Are Stuck
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IT was 9:35 on a gray Thursday morning when Jack Provenzano hopped into his tow truck for his first call of the day. He drove only a few minutes, just around the corner from his office, to pick up a 1987 Chevy Monte Carlo that refused to start. 

Mr. Provenzano lowered the wheel lift to meet the rear tires and hooked the wheels to the truck. With a few pushes of a few buttons he hydraulically lifted the car up a foot or so.

nytimes_articles.headline: Robyn M. Berry, Keith V. Bradsher
nytimes_articles.abstract: Robyn Meredith Berry and Keith Vinson Bradsher, reporters in Washington, were married yesterday in Eden, Wyo. The Rev. Gary Turner performed the ceremony at the Oregon Trail Episcopal Church.   Ms. Meredith, 25, is adopting the last name of her maternal grandfather, the late Robert Meredith. She works for The American Banker, a newspaper in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: New & Noteworthy
nytimes_articles.abstract: BECOMING A MAN: Half a Life Story By Paul Monette. HarperSanFrancisco, $12. Winner of the 1992 National Book Award for nonfiction, this autobiography chronicles Paul Monette's struggle to accept his homosexuality after years spent hiding it. "His fine memoir is affirmative and ultimately celebratory," Wendy Martin said here last year.  A GOOD SCENT FROM A STRANGE MOUNTAIN By Robert Olen Butler. Penguin, $10. Robert Olen Butler was an Army linguist in Vietnam and his experience infuses his first collection of short fiction, which won the 1993 Pulitzer Prize. All 15 stories are told from the point of view of a Vietnamese emigrant to the American Gulf Coast, where his or her sense of loss is less a result of the war than of cultural displacement. Last year our reviewer, George Packer, praised the stories' originality, calling them "the work of a writer who is intoxicated by Vietnam and the Vietnamese, who loves what has alienated so many other Americans."

nytimes_articles.headline: Bumped Traveler May Sue
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, ruled earlier this month that airline passengers can sue for compensatory, but not punitive, damages if they are bumped from flights for which they have a confirmed reservation. In doing so, it rejected arguments that the Airline Deregulation Act of 1978 barred any claim against carriers under state law.   The decision is applicable in California, Idaho, Montana, Oregon and Washington. But because the court disallowed the claim for punitive damages, airline officials and consumer advocates do not expect any change in advance booking procedures, nor do they expect a rash of lawsuits.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Cotton Brief
nytimes_articles.abstract: YOU like to think of yourself as a member in good standing of the biosphere. You recycle, now that it's the law. You try to buy organic grapes and try not to buy plastic bags. You even give money to the National Resources Defense Council, though you're a little behind on your Amicus Journals. But you and Sting see eye to eye on the rain forest, and that's important. You believe in compost as a concept, and even though you voted for Al Gore, you nodded when former Environmental President George Bush said in 1992 that buying cotton instead of synthetics would "restore America's moral fiber."    No, you're not the arch-druid, but between your naked self and the world it's strictly natural fibers, right down to your briefs. You're green.

nytimes_articles.headline: Oblique Angles Deserve Applause
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   No doubt sexiness, along with realism, went out of Hollywood movies in 1934 when the Production Code came in, as Caryn James points out in "Movies Used to Be Really Good by Being Bad"  [ May 30 ] . But sexiness wasn't always replaced by "coyness and romantic haze," as she seems to think. The popular arts are often at their most inventive and entertaining when they come up against the stops of the form and the culture and they have to deal obliquely with what can't be shown explicitly.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ailing Giants Slow Economy
nytimes_articles.abstract: AT the idyllic 120-acre head quarters of Reader's Digest here where employees grow vegetables and flowers in little plots during lunch hour and exercise on running trails that crisscross the estate-like grounds -- news of layoffs early this month shattered an image that this large corporation had of remaining untouched by the economic hard times.   But to regional economists, the announcement that the global publisher of magazines, books and home entertainment products was laying off 250 workers here -- about 10 percent of its work force in the United States -- came as just one more piece of hard evidence that the county continues to be bogged down by economic difficulties, even though other parts of the state and the nation are beginning to show signs of life.

nytimes_articles.headline: Empire Audits Show $51 Million Inflated In '89-90 Loss Data
nytimes_articles.abstract: Internal auditors examining two sets of books kept by Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield have found new discrepancies showing that losses on the company's "high-risk" accounts were exaggerated by $51 million in reports filed with New York State regulators in 1989 and 1990. Last week, the company acknowledged exaggerating its losses by at least $28 million in 1991.   The false reports to the state apparently started about the time Empire, the nation's largest nonprofit health insurer, began an intense lobbying campaign for sweeping changes in state insurance law. The campaign was based on the premise that Empire was unfairly burdened with high-risk customers. These were generally the oldest and sickest New Yorkers, whom the for-profit insurers were not required to take, but they also included self-employed people and others who could not get insurance elsewhere.

nytimes_articles.headline: Farm-Market Plan Meets Opposition
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IT seemed like a good idea at the time. The owners of Sapore di Mare, one of the trendiest restaurants on the South Fork, offered its parking lot as a site for a farmers' market that would sell local produce.

Using the lot during the day from Friday through Sunday would not interfere with the Wainscott restaurant's usual brisk nighttime trade, and the local agricultural economy would receive a boost.

nytimes_articles.headline: Megan P. Shea And Cyrus Cook
nytimes_articles.abstract: Megan Patricia Shea and Gavin Cyrus Cook, both English teachers at the Choate Rosemary Hall school in Wallingford, Conn., were married yesterday. Two Roman Catholic priests, the Rev. Joseph Devlin, the chaplain of Choate, and the Rev. Joseph O'Keefe, performed the ceremony in the Chapel of Our Lady at Canterbury School in New Milford, Conn.   Ms. Shea is keeping her name. She graduated from Bates College and received a master's degree in English from Middlebury College. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James P. Shea of New Milford. Her father is the chairman of the history department at Canterbury. Her mother, Patricia T. Shea, is a saleswoman at Devoe Realty, a real estate brokerage in New Milford.

nytimes_articles.headline: Who Knows Best?
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   I agree with Lawrence O'Toole that putting valuable musical properties to "good, tasteful and interesting" use is a highly subjective task. But I ask him who is best to make that determination: the director who put Nellie Forbush in a straitjacket, as Mr. O'Toole reports, or William and James Hammerstein, who observed their father as he created the shows, heard his reactions to numerous performances good and bad, and in the 33 years since his death staged and supervised dozens of productions of these shows?  STEVEN SUSKIN New York The writer is the author of "Show Tunes, 1905-1991: The Songs, Shows and Careers of Broadway's Major Composers."

nytimes_articles.headline:
The Deadly Sins/Lust;
Even the Bible Is Soft on Sex
nytimes_articles.abstract:
ORIGINALLY the word simply meant pleasure and then was modulated to signify desire and, specifically, sexual desire. How can sexual desire be a sin? Did not God instruct Adam and Eve to be fruitful and to multiply? Did He not say, having created woman from Adam's rib, that "therefore shall a man leave his father and his mother, and shall cleave unto his wife: and they shall be one flesh"? The singleness of flesh is itself a vivid metaphor for copulation. The organic world is soaked in sex; Lucretius, in his epic "On the Nature of Things," begins by saluting Venus: "Yea, through seas and mountains and tearing rivers and the leafy haunts of birds and verdant plains thou dost strike fond love into the hearts of all, and makest them in hot desire to renew the stock of their races, each after his own kind."

Venus alone, in the rousing translation by Cyril Bailey, is "pilot to the nature of things" -- without her aid nothing "comes forth into the bright coasts of light, nor waxes glad nor lovely." Two millenniums after Lucretius and his fellow Latin celebrants of all-powerful love, Freud and his followers have reconfirmed the helplessly sexual nature of humankind and have announced the harmfulness, not to say the futility, of sexual repression. How strangely on modern ears falls the notion that lust -- sexual desire that wells up in us as involuntarily as saliva -- in itself is wicked! With what nervous hilarity did we greet Jimmy Carter's famous confession: "I've looked on a lot of women with lust. I've committed adultery in my heart many times." Mr. Carter was running for President at the time; his opponent, the incumbent Gerald Ford, was a more typical post-Freudian man. Asked how often he made love, he healthily responded, "Every chance I get." Impotence, frigidity, unattractiveness -- these are the sins of which we are truly ashamed.

nytimes_articles.headline: IN THE NATURAL STATE
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE bird opened her eyes at the first touch of morning sun. Head raised, she assessed the state of her world. It seemed, to the best of her ability to discern, fine. Without more preliminaries, she waded into the adjacent pool and started to feed. 

Even in the half light of dawn, an observer could pin a name to this medium-sized shorebird without hesitation or thought. The bird's most obvious trait, its long yellow legs, is also the source of its name -- yellowlegs, or, more specifically, lesser yellowlegs, a species of sandpiper.

nytimes_articles.headline: POSTINGS: Delmonico's Hotel; Coming Full Circle
nytimes_articles.abstract: At a time when low occupancy and low room rates have made many New York hotel owners wish they could leave the business, Delmonico's Hotel, on Park Avenue and 59th Street, is getting back in. Delmonico's, built as a 550-room hotel in 1929 and converted to a 170-unit apartment building in 1972, has spent $5 million to reinvent itself again, this time as a 130-suite hotel.   "You can still earn more on a hotel than on an apartment building," said Joseph Kaminski, the 28-year-old general manager of Delmonico's, which is owned by Elizabeth Kleinhans.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Poet in the Heart of Noise
nytimes_articles.abstract: CITY POET The Life and Times of Frank O'Hara. By Brad Gooch. Illustrated. 532 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

nytimes_articles.headline: For Car Renters, The News Is Bad
nytimes_articles.abstract: AUTO renters who have been saving the cost of a collision damage waiver because a credit card or charge card provided this protection will need to take a close look at any new rules coming from their credit card company or bank. The protection may be disappearing.   American Express and the Visa card and Mastercard issued by Chase Manhattan Bank are cutting back. American Express is limiting the number of companies in the United States where its card will provide a C.D.W. alternative, and has eliminated coverage in Italy and New Zealand. The Chase Bank's standard Visa and Mastercards will no longer provide a C.D.W. alternative at all.

nytimes_articles.headline: Drawing the Line in Somalia
nytimes_articles.abstract: Americans stare with understandable confusion at the jarring images from Somalia. What began last year as a humanitarian mission is now a bloody urban brawl in Mogadishu. Provoked by the slaughter of 24 Pakistani peacekeepers on June 5, United Nations forces struck back with daily assaults by U.S. warplanes against a local warlord. And although this is a U.N. operation under a Turkish commander, the cry in the street is "Down with America!"    Although the punitive actions seem justifiable, the operation now stands at a dangerous point. The U.S. and U.N. could slide unthinkingly into deep involvement in Somalia's internal chaos.

nytimes_articles.headline: Wickman: Lucky? Good? Maybe Both?
nytimes_articles.abstract: So which is it? Is he just lucky? Or is he a talented survivor?   Bob Wickman weighed the questions. He sat, bent over in front of his locker, while relief pitcher Neal Heaton told him to put this game behind him. He couldn't.

nytimes_articles.headline: Would-Be Auto Thief Is Slain at a Brooklyn Service Station
nytimes_articles.abstract: A 30-year-old would-be car thief died on the pavement of a Brooklyn gasoline station yesterday after picking the wrong target, the police said.    The man, Steve Ellis, 31, of 140 Barbey Street in Brooklyn, was pronounced dead shortly after his intended victim, Jerome Mance, thwarted the attempt to steal the car, which was occupied by Mr. Mance's wife and three children, said a police spokesman, Officer Scott Bloch.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lisa Laplace, Matthew Smith
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lisa Jill Laplace, a lawyer, was married last evening to Matthew Adam Smith, a corporate finance associate, both in New York. Rabbi Robert Rabb officiated at the Plaza.   The bride, 28, is an associate with the law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell. She graduated from Duke University and received a law degree from Brooklyn Law School. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Laplace of Tenafly, N.J. Her father is a partner of L. J. & M. Laplace, a chemicals distributor in Elmwood Park, N.J.,

nytimes_articles.headline: Elana Seaman, Timothy Walsh
nytimes_articles.abstract: Elana Felicia Sophia Seaman, a social worker in New York, was married on Friday to Timothy Charles Walsh, an associate at Epstein & Cresci, a law firm in New York. Associate Justice Kristin Booth Glenn of the New York State Supreme Court officiated in her chambers in Manhattan.   Ms. Seaman, 32, is keeping her name. She is a social worker in private practice and a therapist at the Hudson Guild, a settlement house in New York. She graduated from Bard College and received a master's degree in social work from Hunter College. She is completing training in early childhood group therapy at the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services, a social services agency in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Susan Panno, David Shepard
nytimes_articles.abstract: Susan Ann Elizabeth Panno, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Francis V. Panno of Waccabuc, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Jeb Shepard, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Shepard of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. John R. Gilchrist performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Ridgefield, Conn.   Mrs. Shepard is a special-events coordinator in the corporate external affairs department of the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York. She graduated from Mount Holyoke College.

nytimes_articles.headline: He's Lost in Yonkers, But Not in Plainview
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHEN Brad Stoll of Plainview was 14 he told his parents that he did not want to go to sleep-away camp again. They agreed that he could stay home for the summer, but only if he found a job.    That week Brad rode his bicycle to the nearby Plaza Playhouse in Old Bethpage, auditioned for a part in "Treasure Island" and won the leading role of Jim Hawkins.

nytimes_articles.headline: Setting the Pace in the Cafe Competition
nytimes_articles.abstract: CASUAL Italian cafes are more numerous on Long Island than sun-bathers at the beach on a glorious summer day. Yet, just as every June day is not picture perfect, all pasta-pizza cafes are not alike.   Blue skies are more likely when a cafe is in the hands of experienced restaurateurs. That is the case at the new Caffe Milano in Woodmere. It has the same owners as three of the Island's top-rated Italian restaurants, Navona in Great Neck, Stresa in Manhasset and Trattoria Tulipano in Huntington.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article on May 23 about the Eastern Shore of Maryland misstated the locations of Oxford and Vienna. The towns are south of St. Michaels.

nytimes_articles.headline: 3 State Lobbyists and How They Work
nytimes_articles.abstract:
FOR the legions of young Congressional aides known as Hill Rats, making the rounds of receptions and fund-raisers is a chance at free shrimp and Swedish meatballs. For Richard J. Kinney, the attraction is more complicated.

Mr. Kinney is a lobbyist, a vice president of legislative affairs for Schering-Plough, the Madison pharmaceutical company. His mission at these events, he said, is "to make sure that the person in whose honor the event is being held knows that you were there." That person is most likely to be a member of Congress. Given the two-year term of office, he adds, "by the time they're elected they're running again."

nytimes_articles.headline: Relaxing the Guard at Buckingham Palace
nytimes_articles.abstract: London this Summer has not been short of hot tickets. But the real sizzler is a ticket for any one of the days in August and September on which part of the interior of Buckingham Palace will for the first time be open to a paying public.   This event, which begins on Aug. 7 and runs for eight weeks, has already taken rank in the history of tourism as a major first. Within hours of the announcement, Buckingham Palace became the No. 1 attraction in Britain for visitors from abroad. Tickets have the magical properties of fairy gold. To have a pair in one's pocket this summer will turn frog into prince and frump into Circe. Not to get to go will be a catastrophe best hidden from the folks back at home.

nytimes_articles.headline: Call for Moscow Aid Office Splits Wealthy Nations
nytimes_articles.abstract: The United States is pressing the Group of Seven leading industrialized nations to set up an office in Moscow to coordinate Western aid, but Britain and France oppose the idea, Western officials said this week.   The goal of the plan is to give the seven nations a more effective and aggressive role in distributing aid to Russia, said the officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bill Clinton's Brightening Sky
nytimes_articles.abstract: What a difference a week makes. Here was an Administration bloodied by self-inflicted wounds and reduced to arguing that it was not incompetent. And then, surprisingly, came three real achievements on a single day: committee approval in both the Senate and House of President Clinton's national service program, serious progress on campaign finance reform and a big victory in the Senate Finance Committee for the deficit-reduction plan that lies at the heart of Mr. Clinton's strategy for economic renewal.   The optical lesson is that a modest amount of substantive achievement can overcome a whole lot of stylistic failure. Only the most churlish opponent could fail to smile upon Mr. Clinton's overdue good fortune; indeed, one could almost hear a collective sigh of relief not only among the President's friends but also among puzzled citizens who had begun to wonder whether Mr. Clinton would ever locate the leadership capacities he left lying around the White House a few months ago.

nytimes_articles.headline: Perspectives: 40 Wall Street; Asian Buyer Accepts a Leasing Challenge
nytimes_articles.abstract: "THEY wanted a signature building, but anything over $100 million they wouldn't touch," said Edmund Yu, who acted as consultant last year to Hong Kong businessmen seeking a major real-estate investment in New York City.   The search led downtown. And last month Kinson Properties closed on the purchase of the long-term leasehold to the distinguished if tattered 1.1-million-square-foot skyscraper at 40 Wall Street. Within weeks, after major new capital investment, the 66-story building is expected to be back on the leasing market. It is 80 percent vacant.

nytimes_articles.headline: Badillo Campaigns For Remembrance
nytimes_articles.abstract: Herman Badillo was mingling with potential voters at a neighborhood fair in Co-op City in the Bronx when he came upon a woman who met his hand with both of hers.   "Long time no see," she said in Spanish. "What are you running for now?"

nytimes_articles.headline: Jennifer Embree, Michael Lannan
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jennifer Campbell Embree, a daughter of Mrs. Thomas Wade 3d of Seacliff, L.I., and Jeb N. Embree of New York, was married yesterday to Michael Thomas Lannan, the son of Mrs. Richard Burse of Newton, Mass., and Thomas Lannan of Boston. The Rev. Linda Quinlan performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of Bridgehampton, L.I.   Mrs. Lannan teaches prekindergarten classes at the Belmont Day School in Belmont, Mass. She graduated from Wittenberg University and received a master's degree in education from Lesley College. Her father is a vice president of Kidder, Peabody & Company, the securities brokerage, in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Forgotten History: Furgol Won Here
nytimes_articles.abstract: He is Baltusrol's forgotten man.   While the last two Opens here have been celebrated as the site of victories by Jack Nicklaus, unsung Ed Furgol's victory in the Baltusrol Open before those is lost in golf's foggy mid-1950's. It came after Ben Hogan's epic victory in 1953 at Oakmont outside Pittsburgh, and before Jack Fleck's Cinderella story at Olympic in San Francisco in 1955.

nytimes_articles.headline: Another Perspective On Bob Jones University
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:    As one who had the misfortune of attending Bob Jones University for three semesters in the late-1970's, I read Lynda Edwards's article ("Worldly Lessons," May 30) with both interest and horror. Though some teachers there may stress the importance of caring about workers with H.I.V., feelings of hatred and intolerance of gays are widespread at the school. They can speak of living in the 90's, yet the institution lost its tax-exempt status in the 80's for its racial policies.

nytimes_articles.headline: No Arnold. No T. Rex. Just Art.
nytimes_articles.abstract: This time of year, you might feel as if you need a private detective to track down a serious movie -- one without superstars, life-threatening stunts or fast-food tie-ins. In fact, the situation isn't nearly so desperate. There are plenty of new films aimed at viewers who don't care to see Arnold climb a mountain carrying a dinosaur under his arm. Though "Much Ado About Nothing" and "Orlando" are the most visible signs of counterprogramming, they are just the beginning.    Here is a critical guide to this summer's art films. (Most have opened in New York and Los Angeles and will gradually make their way across the country during the next two months.) Some are better than others at avoiding dopey situations, but all are guaranteed dinosaur-free.

nytimes_articles.headline: Athens
nytimes_articles.abstract: Even Athenians have a love-hate relationship with their city. The same taxi driver who insists en route from the airport that there's no better place in the world is the first to curse the sprawling, smog-smothered city. While Athens can be a disappointment, a tangle of cement and wires, congested streets with few reminders of its illustrious past, the patient, open-minded traveler can discover its charms.   The secret is to search for the city's pockets of beauty, its moments of greatness and its idiosyncrasies. One way to do this is to stroll the neighborhoods, from the elegant suburb of Kifissia to working-class Piraeus. Athens is still the megalo horio, the big village. Sit at a ritzy cafe in the Kolonaki quarter: on your left is the hurdy-gurdy player who talks about the civil war as though it were yesterday; on your right, a patrician mother enjoying a frappe with her transvestite son in full gear. Pass a designer boutique in the suburb of Maroussi; a rooster crows from the whitewashed house next door. The nightclubs may resemble those in any other European capital, but after midnight, rock and roll, rap and hip hop give way to the wails of Greek love songs. The young abandon their studied cool to dance the flirtatious tsifteteli -- the girls on tabletops, the boys on bended knee, clapping to the beat.

nytimes_articles.headline: Miss Montgomery And Mr. Moore
nytimes_articles.abstract: Allison Montgomery, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clark T. Montgomery of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., was married yesterday to Nicholas Connell Moore, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George C. Moore of New York. The Rev. Richard McKeon Jr. performed the ceremony at Zion Episcopal Church in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.   Mrs. Moore and her husband are both 27 and graduates of Kenyon College. She is an account coordinator in Philadelphia for the advertising firm of Foote Cone Belding. Her father is an executive vice president and group director at Gray Advertising in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: LAWN MUSIC   Westport has a long history of providing cultural perquisites, from the Westport Country Playhouse founded in the 30's by the prestigious New York Theater Guild, to the Famous Artists School begun in the 40's, to the Levitt Pavilion, celebrating its 20th anniversary this year.

nytimes_articles.headline: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: 1893 FAIR RECALLED   The Columbian Exposition of 1893 in Chicago celebrated the 400th anniversary of Columbus's discovery of America in 1492. The fair was dedicated in 1892, but the 633 acres of buildings, gardens, exhibits and amusements were not completed in time, so the opening actually took place in 1893.

nytimes_articles.headline:
MUSIC;
At Waterloo, Rarely Performed Works
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE Waterloo Music Festival is one place where the major American symphonic repertory gets a fair shake. The festival's directors -- Samuel Lipman, artistic director, and Gerard Schwarz, principal conductor -- took up the cause of American music long ago and remain committed to regularly exploring works that other orchestras rarely perform.

The Waterloo Foundation for the Arts in Stanhope, the parent organization for both the Waterloo Festival Orchestra and the Waterloo School of Music, will begin the 18th summer season for both the orchestra and school on Friday and Saturday. The orchestra, which is made up of the school's faculty members and the advanced college and conservatory students who attend the summer program, will perform six Saturday night concerts under a tent at the historic Village of Waterloo.

nytimes_articles.headline: Miranda Cowley And Bruno Heller
nytimes_articles.abstract: Miranda Phillips Cowley, a daughter of Blair Resika and Robert Cowley, both of New York, was married yesterday to Bruno Heller, the son of the late Caroline Carter and the late Lukas Heller. The Rev. John H. Smith, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony on the banks of Horseleech Pond in Wellfleet, Mass.   Mrs. Heller, 31, is a freelance book editor in New York. She graduated magna cum laude from Harvard University. Her father is the editor in chief of Military History Quarterly, a magazine in New York. Her mother is a mezzo-soprano in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Belgrade, Young Try To Dance the War Away
nytimes_articles.abstract: Glowing in shiny new suits and dresses, the class of 1993 from Belgrade High School No. 11 swirled through the polished lobby of the Hyatt Hotel here last Saturday night, laughing and mugging for one another's cameras.    It was the graduation ball, an annual ritual that had set back many of their families a half-month's salary, but outside the hall, where a band pounded out a loud rock-and-roll beat, not everyone felt like dancing.

nytimes_articles.headline: Martha C. Clarke, James F. Kiley 3d
nytimes_articles.abstract: Martha Campbell Clarke, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard W. Clarke Jr. of Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday to James Francis Kiley 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kiley of Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. The Rev. Ronald Gliatta performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Weekapaug (R.I.) Chapel.   Mrs. Kiley is a freelance public-relations specialist in East Hampton, L.I. She graduated from Denison University. Her father is a money manager at Ingalls & Snyder Inc., an investment bank in New York. Her mother, Lua Clarke, retired as a librarian for the Bedford (N.Y.) Free Library.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mountain, Sea and Story At Clew Bay
nytimes_articles.abstract: "THE most beautiful view I ever saw in the world," wrote William Makepeace Thackeray in 1842 of Clew Bay. It was his first visit to this beguiling sweep of water speckled with 365 oddly shaped islands amid the bleak mountains and boglands of County Mayo. The sun was just setting as the carriage bearing the author-to-be of "Barry Lyndon" and "Vanity Fair" rounded Croagh Patrick and rumbled along the coast road on into Westport: "The mountains were tumbled about in a thousand fantastic ways and . . . the bay . . . which sweeps down to the sea, and a hundred islands in it, were dressed up in gold, and purple, and crimson, with the whole cloudy west in a flame. Wonderful, wonderful!"   In the 150 years since Thackeray -- who was usually more prone to satire than hyperbole -- published his sharply observant travel narrative "The Irish Sketchbook," little has changed along the shores of Clew Bay. A paved road now winds among the villages and resorts along the north-facing coast, spilling out onto the pier at Roonagh Quay, meandering inland through the pub-lined main street of Louisburgh, and skirting the swatch of brilliant white sand against the bay's dark aqua at Old Head Beach. Just to the east, the mottled green and black slopes of Croagh Patrick loom above the ancient path that in pre-Christian times brought crowds of pilgrims to the mountain's base for a festival honoring the Celtic god Lug, long before St. Patrick and his followers spread the new faith to the West of Ireland.

nytimes_articles.headline: Getting Parents More Involved In Educating Their Children
nytimes_articles.abstract:
AS the classroom day drew to a close recently at the Morris Street Elementary School in Danbury, Karen Miller's kindergarten was the scene of controlled chaos. Twenty children scrambled for their backpacks, grabbed a last-minute snack of green grapes and lined up at the door. But Ms. Miller's duties did not end when she walked her boisterous charges to the lobby. Fifteen minutes later, she had an appointment across the street for a parent-teacher conference at Ashley Harvey's house.

The girl's parents, Robert and Jo Harvey, ushered Ms. Miller into their living room, where Ashley settled into her mother's lap on the sofa. The adults discussed Ashley's anxiety about leaving her mother in the morning, her growing interest in spelling and her readiness for first grade. Before leaving, Ms. Miller read Ashley the story "City Mouse, Country Mouse." Such visits are not unusual for Ms. Miller and two other kindergarten teachers at Morris Street. They are participating in an innovative program in the Danbury schools that aims to increase parental involvement, as well as providing more full-day kindergartens and preventing older students from dropping out. Over the last nine months, Ms. Miller has visited all her students' homes at least once. Sometimes she brings an interpreter; many parents are immigrants from the Dominican Republic, South America and Asia. Although most students walk to the neighborhood school, parents seem happier to meet the teacher on their own turf. "School doesn't seem to have happy memories for them," Ms. Miller said.

 Last year, after being designated by the General Assembly as one of 12 urban priority districts, Danbury received $1 million from the state for the current school year, to try to reduce the number of students who drop out. The other priority districts are Bridgeport, Hartford, Meriden, New Britain, New Haven, New London, Norwalk, Norwich, Stamford, Waterbury and Windham. The state program manager, Carol Chapin, said that the districts were given a total of $10 million for 1992-93, and that legislators budgeted $11 million for 1993-94. District officials were required to develop three-year programs, with grants to be determined annually. 

Previously, the choice of priority districts was based on test scores and the number of children from families on welfare. In Danbury, only one child in nine comes from a welfare home. But the new rules automatically included the state's eight largest cities, based on the 1990 census. Smaller districts are eligible for aid if they have large numbers of children from families on welfare.

nytimes_articles.headline: Human Greed Holds the Reins
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Sports Editor:   It took me years to recover from the tragedy of the Ruffian-Foolish Pleasure race, but with the Belmont, I have watched my last race. It is purely for man's profit that these magnificent, fragile creatures are pushed beyond their limit. George Vecsey ("Racing Can't Afford More Tragedies," The Times, June 6) asks when animal rights' groups are going to speak out against this human (not humane) narcissism. I echo the question and mourn Prairie Bayou. PATRICIA B. COHEN New York

nytimes_articles.headline: Treat Judge Ginsburg Like a Man
nytimes_articles.abstract: I accept that Senate confirmation of Judge Ruth Bader Ginsburg is a foregone conclusion. And of course I'm glad a second woman will soon grace the Supreme Court. But let's face it: Were Judge Ginsburg a man who voiced similar criticisms of Roe v. Wade, he'd be "Borked."    Judge Ginsburg's views, as expressed in public statements, on the constitutional right to an abortion are alarming. To spare her a rigorous examination of those views in a general celebration of her womanhood would promote the condescending sexism and stereotyping that Judge Ginsburg herself has fought all her life.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Voice of Barkley Rises Above Others
nytimes_articles.abstract: The unveil ing of a new basketball monument call it Beyond Magic -- was sabotaged Friday night in Chicago. When the curtain was raised, there stood the intruder, with the maniacally comic veneer of Jack Nicholson and an eerily familiar message.   "Heeeere's Chuckie," roared Charles Barkley.

nytimes_articles.headline: INSIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract: De Klerk Seeks Black Vote    President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa began a campaign for votes from blacks, saying it symbolized his party's rebirth as a rainbow coalition of peaceful moderates. Page 10. U.S. Captured Soviet A-Arms

nytimes_articles.headline: Europeans Try to Revive a Faded Dream of Unity
nytimes_articles.abstract: After a year in which little has gone right for them, European Community leaders will gather Monday for a summit meeting intended to convince skeptical Europeans that plans for greater regional unity have not been buried by a severe economic recession and the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina.   It will be no easy task. The community's biggest governments have all been forced to look inward as a result of rapidly climbing unemployment, new intolerance of third-world immigrants, demands for greater trade protectionism and polls showing that their own popularity is tumbling.

nytimes_articles.headline: Racing Report Ignoring The Key Question: How
nytimes_articles.abstract: Many racing people reacted with skepticism yesterday to the report by the Governor's special commission on horse racing, and suggested that the commission had tried to be all things to all people in a business surrounded by red ink, an unknown future and politics.   Nobody disagreed with the warning issued by the chairman of the commission, Vincent Tese, who also serves as Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's director of economic development: "Unless there is change in the way this industry does business, I can guarantee you that in three years the purses will be down. Unless there is change, this industry is in for a long, deep slide."

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A review on May 23 about "For God, Country and Coca-Cola," a history of the soft drink and its maker by Mark Pendergrast, misstated the location of a 1960 sit-in at a Woolworth's lunch counter. It was in Greensboro, N.C.

nytimes_articles.headline: On Psychiatry And Sexuality In America
nytimes_articles.abstract: NAME: A. M. Homes IDENTITY: 31-year-old novelist. Lecturer at Columbia University. NEW BOOK: "In a Country of Mothers" (Knopf, $22), the story of a psychiatrist who convinces herself that one of her patients is the daughter she gave up for adoption years before.

nytimes_articles.headline: Melinda Duryea, Alexander Draper
nytimes_articles.abstract: Melinda Farnsworth Duryea, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Duryea of Lattingtown, L.I., was married yesterday to Alexander Yearley Draper, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank W. Draper of Atlanta. Msgr. Charles A. Ribaudo performed the ceremony at St. Dominic's Chapel in Oyster Bay, L.I.   The bride and the bridegroom both graduated from the University of Virginia.

nytimes_articles.headline: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
nytimes_articles.abstract: 700 Guests for Style Setter   WHEN giving a party for 700 people, a delicate question arises. What to do about bathrooms? When the party is at Martha Stewart's house in East Hampton, the question becomes even more delicate.   Portable toilets simply will not do. Ms. Stewart is known for her mastery of home decor and proper living. "Can you imagine Porta Potties in her rose garden?" a guest asked.

nytimes_articles.headline: In the Region: New Jersey; Recent Sales
nytimes_articles.abstract: Edison  $114,000   65 Ovington Avenue  3-bedroom, 1-bath, 36-year-old Cape Cod; brick front, fenced lot, new roof, full basement; taxes $2,105. Madison  $253,000   16 Shadylawn Drive  4-bedroom, 2-bath, 41-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, fireplace; taxes $3,593.
