nytimes_articles.headline:
Bedminster Township Journal;
A Dissenting Voice Is Heard in Horse Country
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THIS is the heart of horse country, where it sometime seems that all of the 7,000 residents ride, and Jacqueline Onassis and Malcolm Forbes Jr. maintain estates. It is also the site of Hamilton Farms, the home of the United States Equestrian Team. Since 1961 the team has won 26 Olympic medals and 44 Pan-American medals. 

When the residents learned that Bedminster had been chosen for the first time to be host to the World Pairs Driving Competition in October, there were expressions of pride and pleasure. In fact, this week Hamilton Farms will be the scene of the final selection trials for the competition at the United States Equestrian Team Festival of Champions.

nytimes_articles.headline: Schools Seek to Foster Positive Values
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE cement walk around the Ridgeway Elementary School here was splashed with chalk spectrums -- vivid clues to an attitude inside the building.

Across town, at George Washington Elementary School, a first grader, Angel Buitron, was "star of the week." His classmates -- and his teacher, Randi Sacks -- were taking turns as "stars." Angel's classmates learned a lot about him: his favorite things to do, his favorite foods, why his parents think he's special.

nytimes_articles.headline: BOMB KILLS SEVEN IN A CAIRO STREET
nytimes_articles.abstract: A nail-packed bomb exploded late Friday in a crowded Cairo street, killing 7 people and wounding 15, in the latest incident in what appears to be a new and deadlier round of urban warfare in Egypt's capital.   The explosion killed and wounded vendors and men sipping tea in a small cafe. It was the fifth bombing in a public place in the last four months.

nytimes_articles.headline: Fresh Air Hosts Nurtured A Lasting Relationship
nytimes_articles.abstract: Diana C. Vila's childhood was full of adult responsibilities. As far back as she can remember, she cooked her own food, washed her own clothes and baby-sat for her two brothers and various cousins while her mother was scraping out a living.   But Ms. Vila could escape. She could close her eyes and dream about "a pretty white home with the big green lawn where there weren't any problems." It was the home in Pennsylvania Dutch country that she visited every summer through the Fresh Air Fund.

nytimes_articles.headline: Beasts With Friendly Offerings
nytimes_articles.abstract: Squatting clay figures with bowls on their heads were found in the Mediterranean region thousands of years ago. Julie Dermansky has revived the form, in collaboration with Sue Jensen, a potter.   Each ceramic beast is one of a kind, with charming pop eyes and an irresistibly demented smile.

nytimes_articles.headline: Editors' Notes
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article on page 25 of The Times Magazine today assesses the relative influence of members of the Clinton Administration and others in the President's inner circle. In discussing Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, it says Mr. Babbitt is a leading contender for the Supreme Court. On Monday, after the magazine had gone to press, President Clinton nominated Ruth Bader Ginsburg for the opening on the Court.

nytimes_articles.headline: Uproar Over Bikini-Clad Carwashers in Metuchen
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IN January Todd Solley opened a carwash on Prospect Street. In May, to increase business, he hired 15 young, bikini-clad women to wash and dry the cars by hand. The resultant publicity lured customers, but it also gained the attention of the Borough Council, which now says Solley's Carwash is violating zoning rules and has threatened to close it effective tomorrow. 

Mr. Solley is accusing the town of hypocrisy and wants it to admit its true motives for trying to close down his business. And Mayor Susan Marshall does acknowledge that the bikini-clad women were what prompted the threat to close the shop, but she says bikinis are not the issue. "We are not legislating morality," she said. "If he is not in compliance with our zoning laws then he should be shut down."

nytimes_articles.headline: Town-House Sales Pick Up as Their Prices Fall Off
nytimes_articles.abstract: LIKE those of much of the New York residential real estate market, the sale prices of one-family town houses in Greenwich Village, the Upper East Side and other prime Manhattan neighborhoods have been, for the most part, falling for the last five years.   The decline, however, has now left prices at what some real estate brokers believe are bargain levels and, according to several recently released reports, has prompted a small resurgence in sales in some parts of the city, particularly on the Upper East Side.

nytimes_articles.headline: Old and New Faces at Caramoor
nytimes_articles.abstract: GARRICK OHLSSON, Richard Stoltzman, the Tokyo, Emerson and Cassatt String Quartets and the Orchestra and Chamber Ensemble of St. Luke's are returning to the Caramoor Festival this summer along with a good many old friends. In fact, says the executive director, Howard Herring, "Many of the great international artists appearing this season were nurtured here; this adds another dimension to their performance."   Certainly this is true for conductor and soloist at the opening concert, Saturday evening at 8:30: Julius Rudel made his Caramoor conducting debut (and began a 15-year tenure as music director of the festival) in 1964, while Misha Dichter first played at the Festival in Katonah more than 20 years ago. The all-Beethoven program lists the "Creatures of Prometheus" Overture, the Third Piano Concerto and the "Eroica" Symphony.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cupless Season Yields Odd Pairs
nytimes_articles.abstract: The summer of 1993, an off year in sailing as far as the America's Cup, has created the unlikeliest of bedfellows for two coming regattas.   The pairing of Wall Street executives and high-profile America's Cup yachtsmen, including Bill Koch and Kevin Mahaney, is expected to add a new dimension to yacht racing next weekend off Newport, R.I.

nytimes_articles.headline: Killing What Slavery Could Not
nytimes_articles.abstract: CLIMBING JACOB'S LADDER The Enduring Legacy of African-American Families. By Andrew Billingsley. 446 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster.

nytimes_articles.headline: FIGHTING IN BOSNIA EASES UNDER TRUCE
nytimes_articles.abstract: On the second day of a countrywide cease-fire, fighting reportedly waned today, although Bosnian, nationalist Serbian and Croatian news reports traded accusations of violations, especially around the United Nations "safe area" of Gorazde.   Unconfirmed reports on the Sarajevo this morning said Bosnian Serbs had stopped shelling Gorazde but continued attacking Muslim positions on the edge of the eastern Bosnian enclave.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lesbian Wins Appeal on Vermont Adoption
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Vermont Supreme Court said Friday that a woman involved in a long-term lesbian relationship could adopt her partner's two children.   In the nation's first appellate-level ruling in such a case, the court said that "to deny the children of same-sex partners, as a class, the security of a legally recognized relationship with their second parent serves no legitimate state interest."

nytimes_articles.headline: NO QUICK SOLUTION IN HAITI FORESEEN
nytimes_articles.abstract: Diplomats involved in efforts to resolve Haiti's nearly 21-month political crisis say they consider it unlikely that Haitian military leaders will respond positively to a United Nations oil embargo imposed on their country until the reality of functioning without fuel sinks in.   Haiti's oil supplies, needed for transportation, power generation and industry, are thought to guarantee four to six weeks of normal consumption.

nytimes_articles.headline: Idea From Long Beach Turns Into Spectacle
nytimes_articles.abstract:
AS "Jurassic Park" opens in movie theaters, Long Islanders may be happy to know that the idea behind the film was formulated in their backyard. Although paleontologists have not been roaming Plainview nor have there been dinosaur discoveries in Deer Park, the idea was evolved near the Boardwalk in Long Beach, where Dr. Charles R. Pellegrino lives. 

In 1985, Dr. Pellegrino published an article in Omni magazine discussing the idea that bacteria in the stomachs of prehistoric blood-sucking insects preserved in amber could have come from dinosaurs. If scientists could read the DNA in the bacteria and clone it, the theory continued, they could recreate dinosaurs.

nytimes_articles.headline: BOXING: Fear Suffers a Technical Knockout; Holyfield Bulks Up and Returns to Ring for Pride and Against Prejudice
nytimes_articles.abstract: Evander Holyfield has had to overcome his fear of the ring each time he has stepped between the ropes. Now, after an eight-month absence from boxing, he will have to do it again.   Holyfield, who has not fought since losing the heavyweight championship to Riddick Bowe last November, will take on Alex Stewart on Saturday night in Atlantic City in what marks the beginning of an effort to regain the title.

nytimes_articles.headline: Please Don't Shoot This Player Piano
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Perfection without practice," boasted an advertisement early in the century. "All the joy without hard work!" said another. "You need no musical training to play it," proclaimed a third. So appealing were player pianos that by the 1920's they accounted for more than half the keyboards sold annually in the United States. Pianists like George Gershwin and Sergei Rachmaninoff recorded piano rolls, paper scrolls intricately perforated so that sensors in the player mechanism could more or less recreate their playing.   Much has changed since then. Recordings have obviated the need for elaborate pieces of self-playing furniture. The piano itself has suffered, having lost its prominent place in middle-class domestic life. It has even acquired an adjective -- acoustic -- to distinguish it from electronic keyboards with no connection to the home and no specified character.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Views on Contemporary Civilization and Its Discontents
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT is a yearly event: the Bronx Museum of the Arts selects 35 new artists to participate in a career-development seminar focusing on the realities of the art world, then exhibits works by them. Though mainly produced, as usual, before the seminar, this year's crop of art looks more like its aftermath.    To put it another way, the 13th yearly "Artist in the Marketplace," seems restrained to the point of glumness. It could be the tenor of the times, as reflected by Marysol Nieves and Lydia Yee, who, as curator of Latin American art and associate curator of contemporary art, respectively, did the choosing. More likely, it is another manifestation of the mania for topicality, which is sweeping the scene.

nytimes_articles.headline: Amanda Kuklin, John Derderian
nytimes_articles.abstract: Amanda B. Kuklin, a daughter of Anthony and Vivienne Kuklin of Larchmont, N.Y., was married there yesterday to John B. Derderian, a son of Robert and F. Gail Derderian of Wellesley, Mass. Msgr. Walter F. Kenny performed the ceremony at St. Augustine's Church.   Mrs. Derderian is an assistant vice president at Shawmut Bank in Boston. She and her husband graduated from Connecticut College, she cum laude. She was elected to Phi Beta Kappa there. Her father is a partner in the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article yesterday about management changes at Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield misstated the background of Harold E. Vogt, Empire's chairman, in some copies. He has been a board member for a decade but has not worked within the company.

nytimes_articles.headline: What's Pilobolus Doing With 'Finnegans Wake'?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Year after year, "Finnegans Wake," its spine uncracked, sat on their bookshelves like a dare.   "There was always this nagging sense that you somehow weren't man enough to have tackled it," Robby Barnett said.

nytimes_articles.headline: America Out of Reach
nytimes_articles.abstract: DECLINING FORTUNES The Withering of the American Dream. By Katherine S. Newman. 257 pp. New York: Basic Books. $23.

nytimes_articles.headline: Lauren Hackworth, Stephen Petersen
nytimes_articles.abstract: Lauren Christine Hackworth, a daughter of Barbara Hackworth of San Jose, Calif., and Michael Hackworth of Saratoga, Calif., was married yesterday to Stephen Bruce Petersen, the son of Betsy Petersen of Darien, Conn., and Bruce Petersen of Savannah, Ga. The Rev. Theodore Iverson, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at Villa Puerta Dorada, a private residence in Rutherford, Calif.   Mrs. Petersen, 28, graduated cum laude from Santa Clara University and received a master's degree in art history from Florida State University earlier this month. Her father is the president and chief executive of Cirrus Logic Inc., a maker of semiconductors in Fremont, Calif.

nytimes_articles.headline: Get a Life, Valentina
nytimes_articles.abstract: PERSONAL EFFECTS By Francesca Duranti. Translated by Stephen Sartarelli. 152 pp. New York: Random House. $19.  AFTER 10 years of marriage, Valentina Barbieri has been jilted by her husband, a monster of appetite. Riccardo "wants everything": fame, designer clothes, an expensive car, a fancy address, a summer retreat, swanky friends, experimental sex and, above all, money. And he gets it -- gets a radio talk show and a showpiece girlfriend too, an economist, appropriately enough. He does all this by writing smart-alecky and irreverent biographies of the church fathers. These biographies succeed, however, because of Valentina's research and editing, for which she has received no recompense, material or emotional. One day she hears furtive scratchings on the door of her apartment, formerly theirs, and through the peephole discovers her ex-husband removing the brass plaque on which is engraved his name, formerly theirs. "As of that moment," Valentina says, "I ceased to exist."

nytimes_articles.headline: Commercial Property: Looking for the Right Space; Why Mastercard Stayed in Manhattan
nytimes_articles.abstract: AS it turns out, Mastercard International isn't leaving Manhattan after all. Instead, the fast-growing interbank organization, which has been bursting out of its headquarters space at 888 Seventh Avenue, at 53d Street, will spread out across some 350,000 square feet at 1345 Avenue of the Americas, the old Burlington House at 55th Street.   New York City gets to keep 450 jobs now and a promise of more than double that number before the decade is out. Mastercard gets as much space as it needs at an excellent price, gets its name on the door of a Class A building in central Manhattan and doesn't have to put any employees through the enervating process of relocating.

nytimes_articles.headline: Seen the One Where Arnold Sells Noodles?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Americans abroad will not have to wait for the foreign release of "Last Action Hero" or "Sliver" to see Arnold Schwarzenegger and Sharon Stone this summer. All they'll have to do is turn on the television and wait for an ad.   Along with earning millions from summer blockbusters, stars reap additional benefits from commercials shown in foreign countries. Not surprisingly, American celebrities who reluctantly endorse products at home are only too happy to appear in ads abroad.

nytimes_articles.headline: Playoffs to Decide Who Represents U.S.
nytimes_articles.abstract: SIX days of play beginning on Wednesday in Memphis will determine four teams to represent the United States in the 1993 World Team Championships at Santiago, Chile, in September. When they get there, all four teams will be among favorites to win world titles.   In the open series, one team may be slightly weaker than it had hoped to be. Cliff Russell, Sam Lev, Larry Cohen, David Berkowitz, Marty Bergen and Bjorn Fallenius qualified for these playoffs by winning the 1991 Reisinger Teams. Fallenius had to withdraw because he represents Sweden internationally, and his partner, Bergen, wished to withdraw also. The team would have added Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell, one of the world's best pairs, but the American Contract Bridge League did not allow Bergen to withdraw and he will play an improvised partnership with Rodwell.

nytimes_articles.headline: American Jets Fly Over Somali Capital, Provoking Jeers and Insults
nytimes_articles.abstract: United States jets screamed over Mogadishu today, the first sign that a Marine amphibious force is approaching as part of a continuing show of force in support of United Nations operations against a Somali clan leader.    The jets were greeted by jeers and insults from about 2,000 Somalis who had gathered in a raucous but peaceful demonstration in support of the clan leader, Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid.

nytimes_articles.headline: Britta A. K. Herlitz, Daniel H. Lerner
nytimes_articles.abstract: Britta Ann Katherine Herlitz, the assistant publisher for the J. B. Lippincott Company in New York, was married last evening to Daniel Hamilton Lerner, an independent options trader on the American Stock Exchange. The Rev. James Gardiner, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated at the Larchmont (N.Y.) Yacht Club.   Mrs. Lerner, 28, graduated cum laude from Middlebury College. She is the daughter of Bruce and Geraldine Herlitz of Larchmont. Her father is the president of the Herlitz Company, a medical convention-management and publishing company in New York. Her mother is a public elementary-school teacher in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Elizabeth A. Joffe, George J. Nolan
nytimes_articles.abstract: Elizabeth A. Joffe, a vice president at Marine Midland Bank in New York, was married yesterday to George J. Nolan, a vice president with Merrill Lynch & Company in New York. The Rev. William Benwell performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Our Lady of the Mount Church in Warren, N.J.

nytimes_articles.headline: Woodcuts in the Japanese Style; Photos of Japan
nytimes_articles.abstract: OF the two current exhibitions bearing witness to the opening up of Japan in the 19th century, one is at the MacCulloch Hall Historical Museum in Morristown, the other at Rutgers Zimmerli Museum in New Brunswick. The main gallery at MacCulloch Hall has been born again -- with walls painted a color that lies somewhere between lime and apple green. Even so, the display of woodcuts by Arthur Wesley Dow (1857-1922) more than holds its own -- as well it might, for Dow was a man intoxicated by color and well before the advent of Orphism and its American counterpart, Synchromism.   One reason the artist's work has not attracted comparable attention from historians may be that, drawing inspiration from Japanese prints, he expressed his chromatic ideas in landscape, rather than in abstractions. And though he took a "holistic" view that encompassed the decorative arts, he was primarily a printmaker. Yet as a teacher and writer he exerted considerable influence -- Georgia O'Keeffe, Max Weber and Alvin Langdon Coburn were among his students -- and did much to further the American branch of the Arts and Crafts Movement.

nytimes_articles.headline: Woman in the News; Immigration Expert Who Takes Broad Approach -- Doris Marie Meissner
nytimes_articles.abstract: WASHINGTON, June 19 A child of immigrants, Doris M. Meissner grew up in a German-speaking household in Milwaukee during World War II and suffered the anguish of ethnic discrimination early.    "I can clearly recall sitting on buses and streetcars and hearing my mother tell me not to talk, because it wasn't good to be heard speaking German," she said in a telephone interview from Milwaukee. - Ms. Meissner, 51, is now expected to become the custodian of the hopes of today's immigrants and those trying to gain entry. President Clinton nominated her on Friday to be Commissioner of Immigration, which requires Senate confirmation.   Ms. Meissner (pronounced MICE-ner) has specialized in immigration issues for nearly two decades, serving at the Justice Department in Democratic and Republican administrations. She served briefly as acting Commissioner in 1981.   Her family nurtured her longstanding interest in government and public issues, she said. "I think it probably came from my home and from my parents' strong feeling that you give back," she said. "They were always very grateful to have been here and to have built a life here." Paying a Debt

nytimes_articles.headline: Your Home: The Walk-Through; Inspections That Can Pay Off
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT is customary on the day before a closing for buyers to visit homes they are purchasing one last time to make sure everything is working and it is being left in exactly the condition outlined in the sales contract -- ceiling fixtures, washing machine, dog house, azaleas and all.   Though this particular inspection frequently takes a back seat to other 11th-hour dramas -- documents that must be picked up or final arrangements with the movers -- it should not be lightly dismissed, even if the broker takes it all very casually.

nytimes_articles.headline: Robin Gethers, LeVerne Summers
nytimes_articles.abstract: Robin Denise Gethers, a news assistant at The New York Times and a textile artist, was married yesterday to LeVerne Summers, an actor in New York. The Rev. John O. Fowler, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Ramada Plaza Hotel in New Rochelle, N.Y.   Mrs. Summers, 38, graduated cum laude from Wells College. She is the daughter of Dorothy Tilghman of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and Alfred Gethers of the Bronx. Her father is a foreman at the General Rags Textile Corporation, a maker of industrial clothing and rags in Brooklyn. Her mother, now retired, was an administrative assistant with the Bankers Trust Company in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Backlash' Pops Up As Prop du Jour
nytimes_articles.abstract: Once there was a serious book of feminist reportage. "Hey, honey," some slick director told the book, "I can make you a star." Something like that must have happened, because suddenly Susan Faludi's best-selling "Backlash: The Undeclared War Against American Women" has become a movie icon. The 1991 book appears on screen as a conspicuous and jokey prop in two current films and is the subject of a catty reference in a third. When "Backlash" turns up in the movies, you can hear the Zeitgeist calling.   In "Indecent Proposal," Demi Moore walks into the office of the billionaire businessman played by Robert Redford. His receptionist shows every sign of being a bimbette -- bleached-blond hair, heavy makeup, lethal fingernails -- except she is reading "Backlash."

nytimes_articles.headline: Shalini Stevens and Robert Schetty 3d
nytimes_articles.abstract: Shalini Maria Stevens, a daughter of Yvor and Gwen Stevens of Bombay, India, was married yesterday to Robert Austin Schetty 3d, the son of Gloria Schetty-Plante of Miller Place, L.I., and the late Mr. Schetty. The Rev. Claude J. D'Souza performed the ceremony at St. Louis de Montfort Roman Catholic Church in Sound Beach, L.I.

nytimes_articles.headline: Randy Karafin, Steven Hubert
nytimes_articles.abstract: Randy Hope Karafin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Karafin of Villanova, Pa., was married last evening to Dr. Steven Lee Hubert, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Selmar Hubert of Rye Brook, N.Y. Rabbi Max Hausen performed the ceremony at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia.   Mrs. Hubert and her husband, both 26, graduated from the University of Pennsylvania, she summa cum laude and he magna cum laude. He was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. The bride received a law degree from Harvard University. Her father is a partner in Karafin & Gruenstein, a Philadelphia law firm. Her mother, Barbara Karafin, is a freelance photographer in Villanova.

nytimes_articles.headline: Stone Age Settlement in an Irish Bog
nytimes_articles.abstract:
SEVERAL centuries before it occurred to the Egyptians to build pyramids, Dr. Seamus Caulfield says, his ancestors were busy erecting stone walls to fence in their cattle and tombs for their dead atop the grassy cliffs in the northwest corner of Ireland, now known as County Mayo.

But the traces of this prehistoric settlement became buried over the millennia under 10 to 12 feet of bog (the word means soft in Gaelic), the mudpack of decayed vegetation called peat or turf that is mostly good for burning in the hearth on bone-chilling nights.  Until 1934, the ancient walls and tombs beneath this 2,500-acre bog called Ceide Fields -- five miles west of the small town of Ballycastle -- were largely unnoticed. Then Dr. Caulfield's schoolmaster father noticed that farmers digging peat were lugging and cutting rocks from the brown fields that looked different, huge, whitish-gray, and he noticed that they lay in patterns.

nytimes_articles.headline: Elisa Sickmen, Brian L. Zied
nytimes_articles.abstract: Elisa Bonnie Sickmen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Sickmen of Stony Brook, L.I., was married last evening to Brian Lee Zied, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Zied of Alpharetta, Ga. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey officiated at the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel.

nytimes_articles.headline: POSTINGS: Hetrick-Martin; Fewer Sites, More Space
nytimes_articles.abstract: By reducing its quarters from three buildings to one, the Hetrick-Martin Institute in Manhattan is going to be doubling its space.   The 14-year-old institute, which offers education, counseling and support services to lesbian and gay teen-agers, plans to move this fall into 17,000 square feet on the third floor of 10 Astor Place, at Lafayette Street. As part of the institute, the Harvey Milk School will move to Astor Place from its current home at 401 West Street. The institute's other programs and offices are operated at 24 Horatio Street and 80 Eighth Avenue.

nytimes_articles.headline: Julia Wallace, Robert Bennett
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. Julia Wallace, a veterinary surgeon in South Weymouth, Mass., was married yesterday to Robert Egan Bennett, a real estate consultant in Hingham, Mass. The Rev. John J. Bishop performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Dedham, Mass.    Dr. Bennett, 31, is with South Shore Veterinary Associates. She and her husband graduated from Princeton University. She received her veterinary degree from Tufts University. Dr. Bennett is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Neil W. Wallace of Sherborn, Mass. Her father is the chairman of the General Investment and Development Company, a real estate concern in Boston.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'She Loves Me' Is a Confection That Won't Cloy
nytimes_articles.abstract: Technically, the original Broadway production of "She Loves Me" was a flop. Although it collected a sheaf of admiring notices in the spring of 1963 -- "a bonbon of a musical," cooed The Times -- and ran for more than 300 performances, it never recouped its investment. By Broadway's unforgiving yardstick, that makes you a failure in the record books.   I don't know anybody who thinks of the show that way. It's my experience that anybody who thinks at all fondly about past musicals feels passionately about "She Loves Me" and yearns for a revival. Some hit musicals -- those that did turn a penny or two -- have far less devoted followings.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article on April 11 about Skye, Scotland, incorrectly identified the part of the island from which Charles Edward Stuart, known as Bonnie Prince Charlie, was taken to the mainland in 1746. A reader's letter dated April 17 pointed out that the prince left Skye from the town of Elgol, not the Sleat peninsula. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

nytimes_articles.headline: Giving Voice to the Renaissance in Siena. Siena?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sculptor, painter, architect, engineer, theorist and, in general, "homme extraordinaire," Francesco di Giorgio can lay claim to the dubious honor of being the most undervalued artist of the 15th century. Sit through a course on the Renaissance and chances are his name will not be mentioned: he was a nova in that constellation of Italian artists that held all Europe in thrall. The problem is that he was born a Sienese, and as all visitors to that Tuscan city know, Siena and its artists are synonymous with the Middle Ages. Writing on the occasion of a visit in 1873, Henry James remarked that "other places perhaps may treat you to as drowsy an odor of antiquity, but few exhale it from so large an area."   The means of rectifying this neglect has been provided in the form of a lucidly conceived exhibition, "Francesco di Giorgio and the Sienese Renaissance: 1450-1500," on view here through July 31 in the church of Sant' Agostino. The exhibition, which includes 120 paintings, sculpture, drawings and manuscript illuminations, is as rich and multifaceted as the personalities it features. Foremost among these is the great Florentine sculptor Donatello, who spent the years 1457 to '59 in Siena; Francesco's mentor, the sculptor-painter Vecchietta; his associate Nerroccio de' Landi; and the North Italian miniaturists Girolamo da Cremona and Liberale da Verona, who were called upon to illuminate the choirbooks of the cathedral.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Perps Are Almost Always Male
nytimes_articles.abstract:

nytimes_articles.headline: Murder Trial in Beating by Detroit Officers Begins
nytimes_articles.abstract: A jury that took two painstaking weeks to assemble will have to decide whether the fatal beating of a black motorist was a wild exercise of raw power by the police or the action of committed officers confronted by a struggling man in a high-crime area.   As opening arguments began Friday in the trial of three white former officers, many people here wonder whether what happens inside the courtroom will ignite an explosion in the streets. The trial is expected to last six to eight weeks.

nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   On May 2 you carried an author's query by Carole Klein indicating that she was engaged on a biography of Doris Lessing and asking if any of your readers had relevant correspondence, memorabilia or personal recollections.

nytimes_articles.headline: Airborne Spirits Lose Altitude
nytimes_articles.abstract: WAVE farewell to the three-martini flight. The days of the airplane as a flying cocktail lounge are pretty much over, as health-conscious passengers and business travelers on tight schedules forgo cocktails and cognacs in favor of a little wine or water.    Overall consumption of alcohol on planes is down, with a decline of about 10 to 15 percent a year for the last several years at most airlines, according to food and beverage managers at major domestic and foreign carriers. Passengers who do drink spirits tend to drink vodka, but most others are ordering beer or wine or water.

nytimes_articles.headline: A 'Taming of the Shrew' That Trusts in Love
nytimes_articles.abstract: IF only as a truce in the ceaseless battle of the sensibilities over what "The Taming of the Shrew" means -- is it a feminist parable? a sexist put-down? -- the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival staging of Shakespeare's provoking comedy is to be embraced with a relieved sigh.   Make love, not war, Dylan Baker's saucy staging seems to be saying, and with that, the weight of decoding Shakespeare with cryptic and coy interpretations is lifted. Here is a successful production that takes the side of benevolent reconciliation.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hope for Overhaul Dims on a Crumbling Subway Line
nytimes_articles.abstract: At the Park Place subway station on the Franklin Avenue shuttle, the outdoor platform is covered with plywood boards because the concrete underneath is so badly eroded. A collapsed fence invites children to play on the tracks and, one recent afternoon, 8-year-olds jumped on and off the wooden covering of the electrified third rail.   Long considered one of the most run-down and neglected parts of New York City's sprawling transportation network, the tiny, five-station Franklin Avenue shuttle, which cuts 1.7 miles across central Brooklyn to connect the A train with the D, needs an overhaul as badly as any subway line in the system. Not since 1957, the last year the Dodgers played nearby in Ebbets Field, has the shuttle seen a healthy ridership, and it almost looks as if that was the last time any repairs were made.

nytimes_articles.headline: 7 Years Later, N.F.L. Players Sign Pact
nytimes_articles.abstract: It's official. Seven years after professional football's last collective bargaining agreement expired, it's court-aided replacement took official effect yesterday as GENE UPSHAW, the executive director of the National Football League Players Association, announced that the sweeping new seven-year agreement had been ratified by a majority of the union's members. It had been approved by the National Football League owners on May 6. Among other things, the agreement provides for more than $1 billion in player benefits over the seven years. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: Anne V. Zaldastani, John W. Griffen
nytimes_articles.abstract: Anne V. Zaldastani, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Othar Zaldastani of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married yesterday to John Winslow Griffen, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Clyde Griffen of Poughkeepsie, N.Y. The Rev. Mark J. Baker performed the ceremony at St. David's Episcopal Church in South Yarmouth, Mass.   Ms. Zaldastani, 27, is keeping her name. She graduated from Duke University. Until recently, she was a legislative assistant in Washington to Representative Richard J. Durbin, Democrat of Illinois. Her father is the chairman of Zaldastani Associates Inc., an engineering-consulting concern in Boston.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of the Times; Looking at New Jersey, But Thinking of Queens
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT happens every spring, or so it seems, the rumble emanating from the Bronx concerning a potential move by the Yankees.   This time, though, the rumbles may be for real. George Steinbrenner, baseball's version of the boy who cried wolf, may be about to unleash a bite of his own.

nytimes_articles.headline: Avoiding Traffic Jams in the Computer Age
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT is 11 o'clock in the morning and an executive in White Plains is flying to Los Angeles at 2 P.M. Pressing a button on a computer in his office, the screen displays traffic information along the route to the airport and he sees a trouble spot on the far side of the Triborough Bridge and plans to leave the office early.    Such customized traffic-information programs are being marketed to companies by Westchester Commuter Central, a traffic-communications center in Elmsford and a joint venture between Westchester County and Metro Traffic Control, a Houston-based traffic reporting service, which operates traffic information centers in every state. Since November, the center has been supplying traffic and commuter information free of charge to county agencies, said Clifford Cole, the manager of the center.  5-Year Agreement With the County    "Our traffic-information clearinghouse is the first public-private project of its kind in the country," Mr. Cole said. "It is also a showcase for our system."

nytimes_articles.headline: Pennsylvania's South Beach?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Night and day, an army of fashion models descends on the town. Calvin Klein, Randolph Duke, Michael Kors, Bill Blass, Isaac Mizrahi and other designers have visited recently, and so have celebrities like Joan Rivers, C. Z. Guest and Paul Prudhomme.   Could this be South Beach? Oh, please. The hot destination is West Chester, Pa., the home of the QVC Network. Since Barry Diller became chairman of the home-shopping network in January, the trip to rural West Chester, about 24 miles west of Philadelphia, has become a sort of pilgrimage for retailers and publishers. Executives from Saks, Bloomingdale's, the Gap, Random House and Simon & Schuster have made the trek. Herewith, a quick guide to what's what in town:

nytimes_articles.headline: Sports of The Times; The 'We' In Watson's Open Bid
nytimes_articles.abstract: AFTER seven holes in Thursday's first round of the United States Open at Baltusrol, Tom Watson was already four over par. But walking to the eighth tee, a voice said reassuringly, "We were four over in the first round at Pebble Beach, too."   We.

nytimes_articles.headline: Wimbledon '93 Favors Only the Brave and Lucky
nytimes_articles.abstract: Everyone knows about the treachery of Wimbledon's lawns, a damp expanse described as "slimy" by players for whom familiarity has not bred the sort of fondness nine-time champion Martina Navratilova harbors for the most difficult surface in the sport. But this year, even before the grass can turn traitor or the moody weather can wreak havoc , several Wimbledon contestants have already been set dangerously adrift by a particularly unforgiving draw.   The trouble starts right with the defending men's champion, Andre Agassi, whose No. 8 seeding not only happens to be the lowest ever awarded a holder of the title, but is also something of a gift considering his actual computer ranking of, ominously enough, 13th in the world.

nytimes_articles.headline: Shuttle Is Readied to Retrieve European Satellite
nytimes_articles.abstract: The space shuttle Endeavour and its crew of six were completing preparations today for a mission to track, catch and retrieve a European research satellite.   National Aeronautics and Space Administration officials said today that no major problems, including weather, appeared to stand in the way of liftoff on Sunday of the nation's newest shuttle on its fourth flight. The launching is planned for 9:38 A.M.

nytimes_articles.abstract: Natasha Justina Pray, a daughter of Mrs. F. Richards Ford 3d and Malcolm S. Pray Jr., both of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Eric Grayson, a son of Lieut. Col. Cyrus Grayson, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Grayson of New York. The Rev. Terence Elsberry, an Episcopal minister, and the Rev. Richard Stearns, a Presbyterian minister, jointly officiated at Christ Episcopal Church.    Mrs. Grayson, known as Tina, is the vice president and the director of sales and member services for the American Fitness Institute in Greenwich. She graduated from Hartwick College. The bride is a stepdaughter of Mr. Ford.

nytimes_articles.headline: Don't Let the Pesticide Polluters Fool You
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   As an environmentalist and a chemist, I applaud Michael Fumento's effort in "Mother Nature's Pesticide Factories" (Op-Ed, June 9) to defuse the public's exaggerated fear of chemicals. However, his basic argument, that pesticides made by humans pose a lesser risk than those produced by nature is disingenuous.   "Nature's pesticide factories" -- the fruits and vegetables consumed by humans and other animals -- do not discharge thousands of tons of hazardous chemical waste annually. According to the Environmental Protection Agency, the United States chemical industry released 1.55 billion pounds of toxic chemicals into the environment in 1991, a figure that almost certainly is an underestimate, but still far exceeds those reported for other industrial categories.

nytimes_articles.headline: Suzanne Topalian and Drew Pardoll
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. Suzanne Louise Topalian, a senior investigator at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Dr. Drew Mark Pardoll, an associate professor at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore. Walter Duke, the Mayor of Alpine, N.J., officiated at the Hackensack Country Club in Oradell, N.J.   Dr. Topalian, who is keeping her name, is with the surgery branch of the National Cancer Institute. She graduated from Wellesley College and received a medical degree from Tufts University. She is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm F. Topalian of Alpine. Her father is the president of the Topalian Trading Company, an Oriental rug concern in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline:
DINING OUT;
A Sea Breeze From Portugal and Brazil
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IF the Portuguese and Brazilian cuisine of this new restaurant reminds diners of Caravela in Tarrytown, they are on the right track. Manuel Cabral, partner in the Tarrytown spot, has opened Aquario and brought his warmth and charm, and a cuisine that clearly appeals, to the White Plains-Silver Lake district. 

Not much has changed in the decor of this place last occupied by Edmondo's Too, making Aquario one of the more elegant establishments to serve this increasingly sought-after cuisine. But to this congenial dining room appointed a la Roman luxe, Aquario has added its own mark: lovely Portuguese tiles at the entry, a lobster tank, a niche of attractive desserts and, on weekends, a gorgeous display of fresh fish, vegetables and fruit -- assuring those who enter here that they do so at no risk (to their health).

nytimes_articles.headline: Regulating Travel Insurers
nytimes_articles.abstract: New York State will regulate travel insurance more strictly starting July 1. After a review starting in 1991 and a public hearing in January on its handling of insurance against 300 types of "special risks," the state Insurance Department concluded that trip cancellation, accidental death on a trip, lost luggage and similar problems did not constitute a "special risk," as insuring a skydiver did. So all underwriters of travel insurance packages delivered in New York State must get approval for their rates and forms before selling the policies. Formerly, most policies were sold under the looser "special risk" provisions without prior approval.    So far, seven companies have submitted policies to the Insurance Department for approval: BCS Insurance Company of Chicago; National Union Fire of the American International Group in New York; TransAmerica of Los Angeles; Mutual of Omaha; Federal Insurance of Chubb of New Jersey; Travelers Insurance in Hartford, and Twin Cities Fire of the Hartford Company.

nytimes_articles.headline: INDIA LEADER FACES POLITICAL BATTLE
nytimes_articles.abstract: Three days after a Bombay stockbroker stunned many Indians by saying he had paid a $300,000 bribe to Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao, the governing Congress Party rallied today around Mr. Rao.   Members of Parliament from the Congress Party said they had "full faith" in Mr. Rao, but his main political opposition, the Bharatiya Janata Party, stepped up its demands for his resignation, comparing the allegations to the Watergate scandal.

nytimes_articles.headline: Translating 'The Inferno'
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Because there can never be too many translations of "The Divine Comedy," I read with interest the article on the latest incarnation of "The Inferno" and the marathon reading that launched it ("Hell Night at the 92d Street Y," May 9). I wish I'd been there.

nytimes_articles.headline: Everybody's Getting Into the Dinosaur Act
nytimes_articles.abstract:
AT the Biotechnology Center at the University of Connecticut, a scientist like Linda Strausbaugh usually just goes about her business, quietly working on the international human genome project -- trying to understand the DNA sequence, the blueprint of a human being.

But with "Jurassic Park," now on movie screens across the country, it is anything but quiet at UConn in Storrs. The film depicts dinosaurs brought to life from ancient bits of DNA, and television news crews and other reporters have been trekking about the campus to see real people working in the field of genetic engineering.

nytimes_articles.headline: Nicklaus Is Still Golden, Even in the Twilight of His Career
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jack Nicklaus's third United States Open here at the Baltusrol Golf Club is turning out to be a grim encore. The Nicklaus numbers today were 39-37-76, and his three-round total of 218 is eight above par.   But Nicklaus, who won the Open championship here in 1967 and 1980, remains grand with his considerable gallery. His presence on the 13th was typical, a smart smattering of applause as the Bear approached the green, having hit from the rough into a bunker.

nytimes_articles.headline: As Hispanic Presence Grows, So Does Black Anger
nytimes_articles.abstract: When Cuban refugees began arriving here 30 years ago, Ruth Page was working as a seamstress in a tailoring and cleaning shop, and she says she had no strong feelings one way or another about the Spanish-speaking people. But when she lost her job to a Cuban, her attitude changed.   Now Mrs. Page remains resentful,and worried about the still-growing Hispanic presence in Miami. So when the Dade County Commission met last month to consider abandoning a requirement that all county business be conducted in English, she was one of several black Miami residents who attended the meeting to speak out.

nytimes_articles.headline: Sleeping With the Ghosts of Silver City
nytimes_articles.abstract: ON most evenings the desolate Owyhee mountains in the high sagebrush desert of southwestern Idaho take on a bluish hue as you reach them from the dusty and barren foothills beneath. I had returned deliberately late in the day to this lonely spot to see the inky blue sky crep over the granite peaks. And a friend and I planned to spend the night in Silver City, a ghost town over 6,000 feet above sea level that lay 23 miles along a dirt road in the interior of these mountains.   Formerly the jewel of Idaho's mining camps during the gold rush days of the late 1800's, Silver City is a rare example of one that is still intact -- neither gussied up like a theme park after the manner of Deadwood, S.D., or Virginia City, Nev., nor obliterated by modernization.

nytimes_articles.headline: Apprehension on 2 Sides: AIDS Cases and Members of Clergy
nytimes_articles.abstract: "I WAS the type of Catholic that only went to church on holidays," Louis Wiese, 27, of Centerport, said. "But when I found out I was H.I.V. positive, I felt dirty and humiliated, like I had done something wrong and got caught.    "I was intimidated by the diagnosis and wanted to find my inner strength to help me deal with what would come. I wanted to reach back to the Catholic Church, but it was so difficult."

nytimes_articles.headline: Kamieniecki's Wish Is Nokes's Command
nytimes_articles.abstract: Scott Kamieniecki wanted the ball back for the top of the ninth inning. He was only a substitute, a call-up starter asked to do the job while Jim Abbott is on the disabled list. He had never pitched a complete-game victory in the major leagues. He had not won two games in a row for almost a year. He wanted the chance.   Yankees Manager Buck Showalter set this as his rule: If the Yankees could get one more run in the bottom of the eighth inning yesterday, if they could increase their lead over the Minnesota Twins to four runs, he would let Kamieniecki go back out for the ninth.

nytimes_articles.abstract: Philipsburg Manor, North Tarrytown, N.Y, June 12.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mayors, Meeting in New York, Have Eyes Set on Washington
nytimes_articles.abstract: Five months after a new President took office with a pledge to tackle the problems of the nation's cities, more than 200 mayors gathered in Manhattan yesterday for a meeting dominated by the question: what happened to the early promise of the Clinton Administration?   Many at the 61st convention of the United States Conference of Mayors said that despite Mr. Clinton's stumbles, they were still optimistic that he would succeed in helping their cities. But they also said they were disappointed that some of his legislation had foundered -- although they went out of their away to avoid criticizing the President personally.

nytimes_articles.headline: Imprisoned 'Nice Girl' Puts It All On Tape
nytimes_articles.abstract: HERB MEADOW is best known for screenplays like "The Robe" and "Redhead From Wyoming" and for his television series "Have Gun, Will Travel." Along with his television and film credits, he is also known for his children's stories.    On top of that Mr. Meadow is a playwright. His new drama, "What's a Nice Girl Like You Doing in a Place Like This?" is having its premiere at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, where it will continue on the Second Stage through July 11.

nytimes_articles.headline: Russia Says U.S. Got Sub's Atom Arms
nytimes_articles.abstract: After years of silence, Russia has acknowledged that one of the boldest American spy missions of the cold war succeeded in recovering two nuclear warheads from a Soviet submarine that had exploded and sunk in Pacific waters more than three miles deep.   It is the first time Russia has said that the West captured any of its nuclear arms.   The warheads were recovered in 1974 by an American vessel, the Glomar Explorer, a panel of Russian scientists said in a report to President Boris N. Yeltsin.

nytimes_articles.headline: In the Cause of New War Memorials
nytimes_articles.abstract: THREE new commemorative coins honoring Americans who served in World War II will be issued by the United States Mint beginning July 9. The coins come in denominations of $5, $1 and a half-dollar. The profits will be used to create a memorial in Washington to all those who served in the war and to help pay for a United States D-Day and Battle of Normandy Memorial in Normandy, France.   The Mint is authorized to issue 300,000 $5 coins, a million $1 coins and two million half-dollar coins.

nytimes_articles.headline: Two Colorado Dance Festivals
nytimes_articles.abstract: Western Colorado will be the site of an avalanche of dance programs this summer. In Aspen, the 24th season of DanceAspen Festival opens on July 1, featuring Martine Van Hamel's New Amsterdam Ballet with Marianna Tcherkassky, Amanda McKerrow and Gary Chryst. Other companies scheduled to appear during the eight weeks of performances are: Lines Contemporary Ballet (July 8 to 10), Mark Morris Dance Group (July 15 to 17), Pilobolus (July 22 to 24), Ballet West from Salt Lake City (Aug. 5 to 7) and Hubbard Street Dance Chicago (Aug. 11 to 14 and 18 to 21). From July 19 to 31, a minifestival of experimental work includes performances by the San Francisco-based dance theater company Contraband; a collaborative project between performance artists Eiko and Koma accompanied by Native American musicians Robert Mirabal and Reynaldo Lujan of Taos, N.M.; and Rachel Rosenthal. All performances will be staged at the  DanceAspen Festival Theater, on Maroon Creek Road. Tickets range from $5 to $30. For ticket information call (800) 933-3820.   An hour away, people can improve their dance skills as well as watch the pros at work at the Glenwood Springs Dance Festival, June 28 to July 18. Dendy Dance, Contraband and Denver Contemporary Dance companies will perform, and dancers from these companies, as well as other guest artists including Milton Myers, will teach courses geared to intermediate and advanced dancers. There are also classes for children and young dancers. Tickets for performances, which will be held at the Glenwood Springs High School, 1340 Pitkin Avenue, range from $5 to $9. The cost of a full week of classes, which will be taught at Colorado Mountain College, 1402 Blake Avenue, ranges from $145 to $160. Call (303) 928-0878.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kiss Of the Lace
nytimes_articles.abstract: The actress Chita Rivera is not the only one caught in a spider's web. The summer fashion scene appears to be enveloped in a crochet-and-lace cobweb of sleeveless coats, vests, sweaters, pants and skirts. This diaphanous style signals a very strong feminine and romantic impulse emerging from the cookie-cutter dominance of T-shirts, jeans and Armani suits. Today's transparent looks have none of the racy, see-through shock that designers showed in their collections. While crocheted and lace clothes date to the Edwardian era, they are now being mixed with bodysuits, jeans and shorts, giving the concept a fresh vitality.

nytimes_articles.headline: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
nytimes_articles.abstract: WORLD WAR II 199 DAYS The Battle for Stalingrad. By Edwin P. Hoyt. Tor/Tom Doherty, $22.95.

nytimes_articles.headline: In the Region: Connecticut; State Eases the Plight of Small Landlords
nytimes_articles.abstract: IN the final hours of the last day of the legislative session on June 9, Connecticut lawmakers made life marginally easier for the state's mom-and-pop landlords.   They passed a bill that permits direct payment of rent by city welfare agencies to the landlord after one month of nonpayment by the tenant. But measures that would speed the eviction process, and let towns require rent to be paid into the local housing court until the landlord gets a certificate of occupancy, did not reach the floor. Currently, tenants may stop paying rent when no such certificate exists.

nytimes_articles.headline: Susan Arthur, Willard Whitson
nytimes_articles.abstract: Susan Elizabeth Arthur, the director of the Houk Friedman photography gallery, was married yesterday to John Willard Whitson, the senior exhibit developer at the American Museum of Natural History, both in New York. The Rev. Roger W. Smith, an uncle of the bride, performed the Episcopal ceremony in Skillman, N.J., at the home of Lauren Jones and Mark Horneung, friends of the couple.    Mrs. Whitson, 34, graduated from Wellesley College and received a master's degree in art history from the University of Texas. She is a daughter of Mrs. John Glenn Yeager of Houston and the late Dogan H. Arthur. Her stepfather, Mr. Yeager, retired as the manager of commerce for the Exxon Corporation in Houston.

nytimes_articles.headline: RECORD BRIEFS
nytimes_articles.abstract: Bachir Attar: 'The Next Dream' CMP CD 57; CD only.

nytimes_articles.headline: Courtney Bauer, C. B. Burnham
nytimes_articles.abstract: Courtney Anne Bauer, the daughter of Mrs. Henry P. Warren of Delray Beach, Fla., and the late Dale R. Bauer, was married yesterday to Christopher Bancroft Burnham, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander O. Burnham Jr. of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Richard Van Wely performed the ceremony at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.   Mrs. Burnham is the Northeast regional advertising-sales manager for Modern Healthcare magazine in New York. She graduated from the University of Vermont. Her father was an executive vice president of MacMillan Inc., the publishing company, and the chairman of its Standard Rate and Data Service division.

nytimes_articles.headline: Katharine Walker Gregory Brown
nytimes_articles.abstract: Katharine Timmins Walker, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Peter F. R. Walker of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., was married there yesterday to Gregory Curtis Brown, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Curtis E. Brown of Southborough, Mass. The Rev. T. Carleton Lee performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church.   Mrs. Brown, 24, graduated cum laude from Georgetown University. Her father is the chairman of the department of anesthesiology at North Shore University Hospital-Cornell University Medical College in Manhasset, L.I. Her mother, Susan Walker, now retired, was a vice president of the former Browne-Ladd Tours Inc. in Cold Spring Harbor, which ran summer trips for students.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'I've Decided to Keep My Baby'; One Woman's Choice Reflects Issues of the Abortion Debate
nytimes_articles.abstract: Marisol Rodriguez and Robert Laboy grew up together here in the Lakewood projects and fell in love four years ago under Fourth of July fireworks. "The Beginning of Forever," Marisol wrote on the cover of her diary.   Her mother considered premarital sex a sin and made Marisol swear to stay a virgin until her wedding. "But everybody at school kept bugging us," she said, asking them, " 'When are you going to have sex? When are you going to have a kid?' "

nytimes_articles.headline: The 'Timeless Genius' Of 'Gilligan's Island'
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Among the litany of pop culture horrors that William Grimes warns are returning to haunt us ("Revival of the Fittest, May 23), the enduring "Gilligan's Island" is described as "little more than a situation and a handful of little-known actors with a laugh track attached." That critique misses the timeless "genius" of that show. Its characters and comedic structure are shamelessly lifted from commedia dell'arte, the proletariat political street farce of the Italian Renaissance.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Brilliant Salesman
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Many Israelis would agree that Benjamin Netanyahu is a charismatic spokesman and a capable public relations expert. I never heard any Israeli -- including Likud supporters -- describe him as "a formidable intellectual," as he is defined by Conor Cruise O'Brien in his review of Mr. Netanyahu's book "A Place Among the Nations" (May 9).

nytimes_articles.headline: BILLIONS IN LOSSES SEEN IN MORTGAGES INSURED BY H.U.D.
nytimes_articles.abstract: After what its own auditors call years of neglectful management, the Department of Housing and Urban Development expects to lose as much as $11.9 billion as hundreds of apartment building owners default on their Government-insured mortgages.   Most losses, which are expected to occur in the next few years, would be borne by taxpayers through Congressional appropriations. The troubled loans represent more than a quarter of the $43 billion in mortgages insured by the department under programs to encourage the construction of apartment buildings.

nytimes_articles.headline: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia; Market Slow, Towers Close
nytimes_articles.abstract: FACING downtown office vacancy rates nearing 20 percent and rents in Class A space close to those being charged in older buildings, some landlords are choosing to close office towers to wait for better days. At least three have been emptied in recent months and others have been dark for some time.   The 17-story, 258,000-square-foot Avenue of the Arts Building, at Broad and Chestnut Streets, is the largest property emptied. Shortly before its owner, Meritor/PSFS, was seized by Federal regulators last December, tenants were told the building would be shuttered by March. The bank had a branch in the building.

nytimes_articles.headline:
New Jersey Q & A: Jacqueline Rotteveel;
Building a Life in Spite of Mental Illness
nytimes_articles.abstract:
WHEN Jacqueline Rotteveel was 17, she was admitted to a psychiatric hospital and schizophrenia was diagnosed. Her doctors said she faced a bleak future. "The doctors told me that I would never be able to finish school, hold a job or marry," she said, "and that eventually I'd wind up living out the rest of my life in the back ward of a state hospital." 

That grim prophecy was not fulfilled. Instead, Ms. Rotteveel, now 34, said, it ignited a fierce determination that enabled her to build a full, meaningful life despite her illness.

nytimes_articles.headline:
In the Region: Long Island;
'Unco-oping' 8 Town Houses in Lynbrook
nytimes_articles.abstract:
FRUSTRATED by the reluctance of banks to provide would-be buyers with mortgages or to allow owners to refinance their high-interest mortgages, the homeowners in an eight-unit Lynbrook co-op have decided to "unco-op" themselves. Most banks will not make loans in co-ops that have 10 or fewer units.

"We're going to try unco-oping ourselves because otherwise we'll all stay here forever," said Anne Hussey, the president of the board of the 224 Atlantic Avenue Tenants Corporation. The eight units, all two-bedroom semi-attached town houses, occupy a 60-foot by 360-foot strip of land on Atlantic Avenue south of Carter Court.

nytimes_articles.headline: There's Grass in the Dome, and 3 Shots in the Net
nytimes_articles.abstract: Germany and England created an electrifying atmosphere here in today's finale of U.S. Cup '93, but the playing surface in the Silverdome was the day's top star.   The Americans made history in the world of soccer by successfully staging the first game to be played on natural grass in an indoor stadium, creating a sight never seen before in what amounted to a dry run for next summer's World Cup.

nytimes_articles.headline: Johnson Dominates In a 400 Showdown
nytimes_articles.abstract: Quincy Watts, the Olympic champion at 400 meters, was proud to claim third place. Butch Reynolds, the world-record holder and runner-up, had worried so much about this race, he couldn't eat for two days.   But the winner of the final and featured race today in the USA/Mobil championships was Michael Johnson, a 200-meter sprinter who was reluctantly slumming in the 400 because of hamstring problems.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cloud 5 Carries Suns Home To Game 6
nytimes_articles.abstract: By the time the Phoenix Suns' charter was airborne late Friday night, with O'Hare Airport in Chicago in its rear-view mirror, a lively thunderstorm had erupted. Charles Barkley, who had a prime window seat because he sits wherever he darn well pleases, pinned his forehead against the glass, peered down at the lit-up city one last time and said loud enough for the pilot to hear: "Wish I was a carpenter tonight. Because there's a lot of wood to tear down out there."   Lightning certainly struck twice last week. The Suns had previously dropped consecutive games to the Bulls in Phoenix, prompting the Chicago police to board up half of downtown in anticipation of a championship riot. The Suns took note, and their esoteric battle cry became "Save the City!" Coach Paul Westphal even etched the slogan on the Phoenix locker-room chalkboard.

nytimes_articles.headline: On Sunday; The Cost Crisis In Health Care Strikes Home
nytimes_articles.abstract: HOW bad is the health insurance crisis in America?   The Gay Men's Health Crisis -- the nation's oldest anti-AIDS advocacy group, an organization at the forefront in the fight for enlightened health-care policy -- is a target of a union-organizing drive because many of its 260 workers feel their health coverage is inadequate.

nytimes_articles.headline: CRIME
nytimes_articles.abstract: What's an Elizabeth George novel without the usual grotesque characters, twisted psyches and monstrous perversities? A better book, that's what. The author maintains her florid style, but by toning down the Grand Guignol claptrap that made such an unholy racket in her earlier novels, she finds a stronger voice in MISSING JOSEPH (Bantam, $21.95) to tell the mournful story of a village priest who comes to no good trying to reform his unruly flock.   When the gentle Anglican vicar of Winslough dies from eating hemlock root in a meal prepared by a woman who knows her herbs, the gossips have a field day spreading nasty rumors of murder throughout the country parish. The herbalist grows sullen and secretive; the unstable constable who is her lover gets mean and ugly; the woman's 13-year-old daughter acts out sexually; and the local witches fire up their caldrons. By the time the series detectives descend from London on the bleak wintery fields of Lancashire, the scene is well and truly set for a juicy mystery based on the provocative theme of parental love and protectiveness -- and their dangerous outer limits.

nytimes_articles.headline:
BACKTALK;
New Medley: Running, Jumping, Writing and Painting
nytimes_articles.abstract:
Although we often speak of student-athletes competing against each other, rarely if ever do we talk about goalies participating with sculptors and novelists in the same arena. But that will change tomorrow in Newport and Kingston, R.I., when the Institute of International Sport inaugurates a very special event, the World Scholar-Athlete Games. These games will introduce a type of youth-oriented, international competition never seen before, featuring participants exercising intellectual and artistic skills as well as athleticism.

The World Scholar-Athlete Games will assemble 2,000 young men and women, ages 16 to 19, from more than 100 countries and all 50 states to compete in basketball, tennis, soccer, volleyball, sailing, writing, poetry, choir or art. The students will compete on teams that will be chosen at random, not by nationality, creating squads whose only defining characteristic will be a diverse mix of nations and cultures.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bonnie Potash, Michael Tauber
nytimes_articles.abstract: Bonnie Lynn Potash, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvyn Potash of Plainview, L.I., was married last evening to Michael David Tauber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur S. Tauber of New Rochelle, N.Y. Cantor Richard Botton officiated at the Doral Arrowwood in Rye Brook, N.Y.   Mrs. Tauber, 24, is a special education teacher at the Rusk Institute, a rehabilitation center in New York. She graduated from Syracuse University. Her father is the manager of sales and operations at TFI Distributors Inc., a video production company based in New York. Her mother, Rochelle Potash, is the customer service manager at Medi-Source Inc., a medical supply company in Syosset, L.I.

nytimes_articles.headline: Prison and Nonsmokers: Yearning to Breathe Free
nytimes_articles.abstract: William Lynch might have stepped straight from a film noir prison scene of the 1940's. A grizzled, toothless convict who goes by the name Pops and gives his age as "sixtyish," he squints at a visitor through the perpetual haze of bluish smoke that rises from the ever-present Camel cigarette dangling from his lips.   But these days Pops Lynch and his nicotine haze are becoming cellblock anachronisms as corrections officials push for smokeless prisons and the number of smoking prisoners falls.

nytimes_articles.headline: At the Village Well
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: We must reassure future travelers with children that there is an escape from dirty laundry. "Hanging Out With the Wash" is unrealistically depressing. When we spent three days in Florence in 1969 with four children (or was it five?) at the Hotel Roma, just across the street was a laundermat. It was a lifesaver.   For 20 years we have owned a farmhouse in the Perigord. It is true that until about eight years ago there were no laundermats within an hour's drive. Now we have at least one in the very capital of the Perigord Noir (Sarlat) and one in Les Eyzies.

nytimes_articles.headline: IN SHORT: FICTION
nytimes_articles.abstract: TWO SCHOLARS' ROMANCE CHANGING HEAVEN By Jane Urquhart. Godine, $22.95.

nytimes_articles.headline: Conner's New Boat Is Commissioned
nytimes_articles.abstract: With all the fanfare usually associated with his America's Cup campaigns, Dennis Conner today commissioned his new boat for the coming Whitbread Round the World Race.   The dockside ceremony took place here in Newport, the city that was home to the America's Cup before Conner's team lost the coveted trophy to Australia in 1983. But the old angst seemed behind him as Conner prepared to move on into the unfamiliar territory of Whitbread racing.

nytimes_articles.headline: Two in a Row? That's Simple. None in a Row? That's the Mets.
nytimes_articles.abstract: On two-game winning streaks and others:   Putting into perspective the Mets' inability to win two games in a row for more than two months now, consider that other teams have achieved this feat with striking regularity in that period.

nytimes_articles.headline: Questions About Wealthy At Heart of Rent Debate
nytimes_articles.abstract: At the heart of the legislative battle over rent laws is a basic question: Should the wealthy continue to benefit from rent regulation, a system that protects thousands of New Yorkers from drastic rent increases?   The answer is an emphatic "No," say many landlords and their supporters in the Legislature. And to bolster their arguments, they trot out the names of several well-to-do celebrities who they say milk the system by living in rent-stabilized apartments at posh Manhattan addresses.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jennifer Segal, David Madden
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jennifer Ann Segal, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sheldon J. Segal of Hartsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Michael Madden, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jean D. Madden Jr. of Warwick, R.I. Catherine Norris Norton, a justice of the peace in Falmouth, Mass., officiated at the outdoor wedding at Juniper Point, in Woods Hole, Mass.   Mrs. Segal Madden, 27, is an account executive at Moret Advertising Inc., an advertising agency in Tucson, Ariz. She graduated cum laude from Wellesley College and received a master's degree in management from Northwestern University. Her father is a scientist at the Population Council, a nonprofit research organization in New York. He led the team that developed the Norplant birth-control device. He is also the chairman of the Marine Biological Laboratory at Woods Hole. Her mother, Harriet Segal, is a novelist.

nytimes_articles.headline: Aegean Idyll: Was It Really That Good?
nytimes_articles.abstract: LAST summer my friend Lynette and I spent a couple of weeks on the Greek island of Santorini. We had a great trip, of course. We bring it up sometimes, always wistfully: our hotel room was actually a tiny stone house, ancient, built right into the hillside at the town of Oia; our sunny balcony overlooked volcanic islets shimmering in the Aegean; the long sunsets hovered over the islets and seemed to vibrate with color and time.   In the morning, cats prowled or posed on the walls of the hillside houses; one little black kitty adopted us, and came every morning to lick the creamy dregs of our goat-milk yogurt. When the day grew warm, we would walk down a long curving set of steps to the blue blue water, and swim for hours. The crystalline sea seemed to lift us up, hold us in the buoyant moment; we were suspended at the still center of the world.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Teacher, Her Pupils And Lessons Learned
nytimes_articles.abstract: When school began last September, Patricia Cullen was as much a novice as the first-grade students assigned to her class at Public School 116 in Manhattan. It was her first teaching job, their first time in grade school. By the end of that first week, Mrs. Cullen looked pummelled, and the wiggling, giggling children had mastered only one lesson: standing in line.   But as the school year winds to an end, it is clear that much has changed inside Room 205.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Child So Light He Could Fly
nytimes_articles.abstract: There's more than a whiff of menace in MR. SUMMER'S STORY (Knopf, $17), a seemingly sprightly fable of childhood adventure and discovery by the German novelist Patrick Suskind, whose malevolent first novel, "Perfume," was an international best seller. Unlike most coming-of-age stories, this one explores not only the mysteries of duty and desire, injustice, aging and death -- but also Galileo's laws of falling bodies. Set in a pleasant lakeside village "shortly after the war," the tale is narrated by a nameless boy who loves his typically incomprehensible parents, dotes on his elusive sweetheart and despises his hilariously cranky piano teacher. Gravity (and perhaps gravitas) enters the life of this child "so light I could fly" in the form of the mysterious Mr. Summer, an eccentric recluse who spends all his time ferociously striding about the countryside, and whose single utterance is an angry "Why can't you just leave me in peace!" Like a force of nature, Mr. Summer pulls the airy narrator down to earth, providing sobering lessons about childhood foibles and grown-up fears. And if the translation by John E. Woods occasionally provides a few thuds of its own ("They were only dreams, and like all dreams not really emotionally satisfying"), the accompanying drawings by Jean-Jacques Sempe have the ethereal quality of innocence just on the brink of being lost.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Wrong Message For Young People?
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:    Are you encouraging your readers to get stoned? In two major pieces that have appeared in the Sunday Styles section ("Tripping, but Not Falling," May 2, and "Repotted," March 7), it seriously looks like the Times wants its readers to trip on LSD, preferably while smoking a joint and wearing clothing made from hemp.

nytimes_articles.headline: Michelle K. Vitulli, Robert B. Proctor
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. Michelle Karen Vitulli, a veterinarian in Syracuse, was married yesterday in Ithaca, N.Y., to Robert Benjamin Proctor, a doctoral candidate in applied physics at Cornell University. The Rev. Richard Murphy, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Sage Chapel on the Cornell campus.   Dr. Vitulli, 28, graduated from Muhlenberg College. She received a degree in veterinary medicine from Cornell. She is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Vitulli of Floral Park, L.I.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ease Up!
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Sports Editor:   During the 40 years I have lived here, and especially when the salaries of star athletes rose to the stratosphere, it seems there has always been at least one athlete on the receiving end of the contumely of the local press corps: Reggie Jackson, Dave Winfield, Darryl Strawberry, and now Bobby Bonilla ("Lost in a City He Calls Home," The Times, April 25). Strangely enough, they all seem to be black and/or Hispanic. Once one is driven out of town via trade or whatever, once the atmosphere is so poisoned that life becomes intolerable for the athlete, there is a round of self-congratulation by sports reporters about what a tough town New York is.

nytimes_articles.headline: Article 891593 -- No Title
nytimes_articles.abstract: Last winter Walter H. Annenberg telephoned the headmaster of the Peddie School to say he was thinking of making yet another donation to his old alma mater. He tossed out a figure in the $50 million range.   "I almost fell off my chair," recalled Thomas A. DeGray, the headmaster of the Hightstown, N.J., school. "Ask my wife. I got off the phone and let out a scream."

nytimes_articles.headline: IN SHORT: FICTION
nytimes_articles.abstract:
COMING OF AGE IN 70's LONDON
PEERLESS FLATS
By Esther Freud.
Harcourt Brace, $19.95.

nytimes_articles.headline: Beleaguered Parish Welcomes a New Pastor
nytimes_articles.abstract: With a simple, warm embrace, John Cardinal O'Connor installed the Rev. Richard T. Adams as pastor of St. John the Evangelist Church today, amid thunderous applause from parishioners during an afternoon Mass.   The Roman Catholic parish and its 2,000 members have been beleaguered since April, when allegations surfaced that the former pastor, the Rev. Edward A. Pipala, had sexually abused boys at St. John's and at Sacred Heart Church in nearby Monroe, where he formerly served.

nytimes_articles.headline: Remaking Stamford as a Corporate Hub
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IN a down economy, Neil Sherman faces what many would call an Olympian task: promoting Stamford as the place to do business. 

Following the explosive corporate growth that rocked Fairfield County in the 1970's and 80's, and the downturn that followed, Stamford has more than three million square feet of empty office space. And rents are dropping, from $24 a square foot four years ago to $21 a square foot today for prime office space.

nytimes_articles.headline: Will Tomorrow's TV Viewers Sit by the Set, or Ride a Data Highway?
nytimes_articles.abstract: An interactive cable television network in Montreal and the America Online network for personal computers offer a preview of the future.

nytimes_articles.headline: Peace, Love And Chompers
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE roster of superwaifs, vegetarian grunge actors and musicians in Birkenstocks and beads continues to grow like late-summer squash in the garden of some California commune. That's why the New York Shakespeare Festival's black-tie fund-raising event under a tent at Tavern on the Green on Wednesday, which celebrated the 25th anniversary of the tribal love musical "Hair," carried more cultural weight than it would have two years ago.   It was nice, a relief even, that some of the performers singing about the Age of Aquarius, peace, love, harmony and understanding -- they included Kevin Kline, Ben Vereen and Betty Buckley -- were actually old enough to have lived through the hippie era. And if the event was yet another revival in a season of revivalism, at least it was inspired by a breakthrough moment of political and spiritual intention in musical-theater history.

nytimes_articles.headline: In the Region: Long Island; Recent Sales
nytimes_articles.abstract: Albertson  $131,000   54 I.U. Willets Road  2-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, attic, 1-car attached garage; taxes $3,100.
