nytimes_articles.headline: Q and A
nytimes_articles.abstract: Discount Paris Fashions   Q. I will be traveling to Paris next month and wonder if there are any discount shops there offering designer merchandise? -- Vicki A. Schneps, Melville, L.I.

nytimes_articles.headline: Turned-Wood Vessels and Art Objects Show Their Stuff
nytimes_articles.abstract:
"WHAT most people think of as wood turnings are finials on a bedpost or a nutbowl," said Irving Margulis, an owner with his wife, Suzan Margulis, of the three-year-old New Horizons Gallery in Greenwich. "The art of wood is not just carving to make a bowl," he said, "but bringing out its inherent graining and structuring an object of art. Some are segmented turnings where little slivers of wood are cut to specific dimensions and glued together to form a mosaic pattern in wood. That block of wood is then turned on a lathe to form an original vessel." 

"Turned Wood Arts '93," an exhibition on view at the gallery through July 3, was inspired by the American Association of Woodturners' annual symposium being held this year at the State University of New York in Purchase Friday through Sunday. "Several of the association's members, aware that I had a gallery in close proximity to SUNY, suggested I tie in a juried show," Mr. Margulis said. He was also motivated by Congress's designation of 1993 as "The Year of American Craft," and Forbes magazine's Sept. 14, 1992, "75th Anniversary Issue," proclaiming turned-wood vessels as the collectible of the 1990's.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A picture caption on June 6 about a father and son who play tennis on the same college team misidentified the man on the left in the photograph. He was the team's coach, Stan Dlugosz, not the father.

nytimes_articles.headline: Marion Atherton and John Reager
nytimes_articles.abstract: Marion Phelps Atherton, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allan G. Atherton of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to John Reager, the son of Claire Reager and Osborne Reager, both of Claremont, Calif. The Rev. William C. Rhodes performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Cathedral in San Francisco.   Ms. Atherton, who is keeping her name, is an arts administrator with the Philharmonia Baroque Orchestra in San Francisco. She graduated from Yale University and received a master's degree in music education from Columbia University.

nytimes_articles.headline: Time for the Dinner Bell on the Housatonic River
nytimes_articles.abstract: What the green drake is to mayflies, the alder is to caddis, which is to say, this is a big bug, folks. So big, in fact, that you almost expect to see bib-clad trout with forks and knives like underwater patrons at some sort of rib joint. The Housatonic River in northwest Connecticut is now serving one of the biggest and best menus of these tasty morsels for trout -- and the alder fly hatch will be available for anglers to imitate, and with any luck, take trout on for several weeks to come.   Anglers here wait anxiously for the alder because it is the source of some dramatic dry-fly action, which stirs large trout that normally keep low profiles.

nytimes_articles.headline: A la Carte; What's Good for the Island May Even Be Good for Manhattan
nytimes_articles.abstract: POMODORO is turning the tables on the Manhattan restaurants that have opened outposts on the Island. The casual Italian cafe, which first opened in Port Washington and then in Huntington and Great Neck, is commuting in reverse.    Fabio Machado and Piero Casaliocchio, who own the popular Pomodoro threesome, will open a fourth, on Columbus Avenue between 70th and 71st Streets, by July 1. The beachhead in Manhattan will mirror their Island restaurants.

nytimes_articles.headline: If You're Thinking of Living in: Morningside Heights
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IN a public relations move at the turn of the century, Morningside Heights was named "The Acropolis on the Hill." The name has stuck, at least among guidebook writers and the neighborhood's present enthusiasts. 

Then, as now, educational, spiritual and medical institutions dominated the neighborhood, occupying about half the land; one institution -- Columbia University -- owns another quarter.

nytimes_articles.headline: Gregg Solomon and Robin Kramer
nytimes_articles.abstract: Robin Kramer, a daughter of Madeline Kramer of New York and Robert S. Kramer of Dallas, was married last evening to Gregg Solomon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Solomon of New York. Rabbi David Posner officiated at Le Club in New York.   The bride, 30, is the director in New York of Calvin Klein's in-store shops. She graduated from the Fashion Institute of Technology. Her father is the owner of Remark, a manufacturers' consulting company in Dallas.

nytimes_articles.headline: Expensive Hair, Continued
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nearly three weeks after the "Hair Force One" brouhaha that beseiged President Clinton, Barbara Bush also retained the services of a high-priced hairdresser.   On June 8, the former First Lady celebrated her 68th birthday at the Upper East Side home of Robert and Georgette Mosbacher. Before the party, Mrs. Bush had her hair done at the Mosbacher home by a stylist from the Coppola salon on Madison Avenue. While the salon wouldn't comment on what it cost Mrs. Bush, it generally charges $200 for at-home visits.

nytimes_articles.headline: 'Nightline' Wakes Itself Up
nytimes_articles.abstract: It is a little bit more than five hours until air time, and preparations for "Nightline" are running precisely the way Ted Koppel likes them -- just this side of panicked.   Sitting around a long table, Mr. Koppel and his staff still can't decide on the topic for that night's show. The executive producer, Tom Bettag, is pushing Waco, which has been the subject of hearings all day on Capitol Hill. He has lined up three guests in three cities. Mr. Koppel is pressing for Bosnia, which has been the focus of tense behind-the-scenes discussions at the White House, but he has secured no guests. Staff members are dispatched to place calls to Defense Secretary Les Aspin and the United Nations envoy Madeleine Albright. A talkative general is located, but no camera crew.

nytimes_articles.headline: Cynthia Sulzberger and Gary Simpson
nytimes_articles.abstract: Cynthia Fox Sulzberger, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Ochs Sulzberger of New York and Southampton, L.I., was married in New York on Thursday evening to Gary Leonard Simpson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Simpson of Old Westbury, L.I. Dr. Ronald Sobel, senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El in New York, performed the ceremony at the Plaza.   The bride, who will keep her name, graduated from Duke University. She is an intern in the Language and Learning Disability Unit at St. Luke's Hospital in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Flying to Florida
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: I am writing to add my voice to the chorus of outraged and disappointed travelers on Skybus. In February I purchased round-trip tickets (Newark-Fort Lauderdale) for myself and my daughter. As I informed Skybus, the sole purpose of the trip was a brief visit to my elderly father, who was hospitalized in Florida. The tickets were for departure on Feb. 5 and return Feb. 6.   We arrived on time and waited in line for almost two hours. We were then curtly informed that our plane would not depart at 7 P.M., as scheduled, but at 1 A.M. the next day -- meaning that we would arrive in Fort Lauderdale at 5 A.M., the same day we would have to leave.

nytimes_articles.headline: Correction
nytimes_articles.abstract: A report in the Benefits column last Sunday about a jazz concert this Thursday for the Jewish Presence Foundation misstated the location. The event, at 8 P.M., will take place at Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center, not at Carnegie Hall.

nytimes_articles.headline: Streetscapes: 110-118 Riverside Drive; A Mixed Window Dressing
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT'S just the kind of thing that drives preservationists nuts: Over the last 20 years the 1929 apartment house at 110-118 Riverside Drive has gone window-wild.    With no master plan for replacements, tenants in the nonlandmark co-op have installed windows in a wild variety of colors and the place looks like a test lab for a fenestration institute.

nytimes_articles.abstract:
AND THEY CALL IT HELP
The Psychiatric Policing
of America's Children.

nytimes_articles.abstract: GIRL, INTERRUPTED By Susanna Kaysen. 169 pp. New York: Turtle Bay Books/Random House. $17.

nytimes_articles.headline: Pirates Plunder Sinking Ship
nytimes_articles.abstract: The organization and clubhouse are in turmoil. Players are coming and going. The manager, after waging a loud campaign that mixed intimidation with encouragement, appears to be readying himself for open warfare with his players. And there is a personal medical drama involving a player's child that has further torn the clubhouse.   Amid it all, there have been games, and the Mets, who lose almost all of them, had another taken from them tonight. The Pirates, dismantling the ever-fragile pitching of Frank Tanana, left the Mets in pieces again with an 8-3 triumph, their third straight of the series.

nytimes_articles.headline: Topics of The Times; Stop Flogging Franks
nytimes_articles.abstract: "Wait! I'm a Republican!" That's what Gary Franks, the Republican Representative from Connecticut, once yelled as white voters breezed by him on the stump. Mr. Franks was the first black Republican they'd seen.   "Wait! I'm black, too" is what he yells now as the Democrats of the Congressional Black Caucus throw him out of meetings. As the only Republican in the caucus, Mr. Franks is suspected of being an agent of the G.O.P. As such, the Democrats periodically eject him so that they can discuss "strategy" among themselves.

nytimes_articles.headline: Nantz Decides to Stay With CBS
nytimes_articles.abstract: JIM NANTZ, whose contract with CBS expires at the end of June, has decided to remain with the network rather than move to ABC, a spokeswoman for CBS confirmed yesterday. ABC had sought to lure Nantz with the promise he would return to calling college football. He is expected to take over CBS's golf hosting duties when PAT SUMMERALL retires and will continue as the lead announcer for men's college basketball. Terms of the deal were not announced, and Nantz was unavailable for comment. "We're happy to have him stay," said SUSAN KERR, the CBS spokesman.

nytimes_articles.headline: Taking the Measure of Summer Stock
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE defective septic system that caused Gateway's Candlewood Playhouse to shut down in New Fairfield last year has been replaced. And the Ivoryton Playhouse had a new staircase built in accordance with fire regulations. While the removal of fire and health code violations are hardly the stuff of inviting theater news, it's the repairs and the numerous renovations, not the repertory, that tell the story of Connecticut's summer stock. What's left of it.    Ivoryton Playhouse, beginning its 64th season, one ahead of the Westport Country Playhouse, is the winner in the survival game. But statistics simplify. They do not reflect changes.

nytimes_articles.headline: Clinton Issues Call to Arms at Northeastern U.
nytimes_articles.abstract: President Clinton told a cheering audience of Northeastern University graduates today that their futures depended on the ability of leaders in Washington to make tough decisions, and he challenged recalcitrant politicians in Congress to start making some.   Mr. Clinton made no effort to hide the campaign-style nature of his remarks, directing his criticism at opponents in Congress who he said have opposed his plan to reduce the deficit and raise taxes without providing workable alternatives.

nytimes_articles.abstract: MY LIFE AS A FAN By Wilfrid Sheed. 221 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $20.

Pelosi of San Francisco and Washington, was married yesterday to Michael Terence Kenneally, a son of Patricia S. Kenneally of Houston and J. Thomas Kenneally of Kilquade, County Wicklow, Ireland. The Rev. Royden B. Davis performed the ceremony at the Catholic Church of St. Helena, in St. Helena, Calif.   The bride and the bridegroom graduated from Georgetown University. She was until recently a promotions coordinator at Gourmet magazine in New York. Her father is the president of Financial Leasing Services, a venture-capital company in San Francisco. Her mother is a Democrat from California.

nytimes_articles.headline: Carrie Miller, L. A. Goldberg

Goldberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Barry Goldberg of Livingston, N.J. Cantor Bernard Fitch officiated at the Woodcliff Lake (N.J.) Hilton. Wetzel Associates Inc., an exhibit design concern in Boston. She graduated from St. Lawrence University. Her father, now retired, was a senior partner in the Philadelphia law firm of Ballard, Spahr, Andres & Ingersoll.

nytimes_articles.headline: Where to Stop and Smell the Flowers
nytimes_articles.abstract: AT Norfolk, in the foothills of the Berkshire Mountains, Fred and Mary Ann McGourty have tucked Molly the Witch in a raised flower bed near a Korean Stewartia tree. As the owners of Hillside Gardens and Nursery, the couple hope that the rare peony will become another hallmark of their perennial paradise.    On six gently sloping acres, impressionistic displays of flowers set against the backdrop of the couple's 18th-century home to provoke the senses as well as the mind.

nytimes_articles.headline: Women Players Still Shooting For a League of Their Own
nytimes_articles.abstract: Sheryl Swoopes, star of the Texas Tech national collegiate champions, couldn't make it to the game. But Sue Wicks, a former Rutgers all-America who has been playing in Japan for the past few years, could. And there were lots of other names from the recent past who made it.   The Adidas All-Star Classic at the State University of New York here tonight was a gathering of some of America's finest female basketball players, getting together to drum up some interest in another women's professional basketball league.

nytimes_articles.headline: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
nytimes_articles.abstract:
FOR DEAR OLD DAD

Never let it be said that the man of the house is being ignored on Father's Day today. For the musically inclined there is a free concert by the Lou Grassi Jazz Quartet at 2 P.M. at the Bayard Cutting Arboretum in Oakdale (224-5420), and works by Beethoven, Mendelssohn and Stravinsky are on the bill at 2:30 P.M. at Old Westbury Gardens (333-0048), where Naho Nayuke, a 15-year-old violinist, will perform.

nytimes_articles.abstract: An article last Sunday about New York City hotels referred incorrectly to the Latham Hotel. The building's northern half remains a conventional hotel, the Latham, at 4 East 28th Street; the southern half now operates as a youth hostel and budget hotel, the Gershwin, at 7 East 27th Street.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Leader in Cornea-Transplant Surgery
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE beeps of a heart monitor punctuated the smooth rhythms of Nat King Cole singing in the background as Dr. Mitchell Stein prepared to remove Christopher J. Boufford's diseased left cornea late last month. The scene was an operating room in the Northern Westchester Hospital Center here, where the 23-year-old patient lay anesthetized and draped with sanitary cloths, his exposed eye kept open with a speculum.   The cornea-transplant surgery, which could be watched on a closed-circuit television monitor in the operating room, takes place only six times a year at the hospital, and Dr. Stein is the only ophthalmologist who performs the procedure here.

nytimes_articles.headline: Note to Readers
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Op-Ed page welcomes unsolicited manuscripts. Because of the volume of submissions, however, we regret that we cannot acknowledge an article or return it unless it is accompanied by a self-addressed, stamped envelope. If manuscripts are accepted for publication, authors will be notified within two weeks.

nytimes_articles.headline: Auerbach Stable After Quintuple Bypass
nytimes_articles.abstract: RED AUERBACH, the 75-year-old Boston Celtics president, was in stable condition yesterday, a day after six hours of open-heart surgery at Massachusetts General Hospital. Five arteries were bypassed during the operation Friday, a hospital spokesman, MARTIN BANDER, said. Auerbach, the winningest coach in National Basketball Association history, had two blocked arteries cleared in procedures last month. (AP)

The Rev. Canon Michael Du Plessis performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Englewood, N.J.   Mrs. Thigpen, 28, is an associate product manager at the Sterling Winthrop pharmaceuticals company in New York. She graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and received an M.B.A. from Columbia University, where her husband received a law degree. Her father is a food service manager at the Isabella Geriatric Center, a nursing home in New York. Her mother teaches social studies at Dwight Morrow High School in Englewood.

LONG WAY FROM HOME

nytimes_articles.headline: At the Village Well
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: Your recent articles about dealing with laundry while traveling, ("Hanging Out With the Wash," April 25) and studying the Welsh language, ("Gymru and Cymru and All That," May 2) brought back a very happy memory for me.   In 1976, four of us vacationed in northern Wales. The guidebooks had warned us that the Welsh language was practically extinct and that few, if any, tourists ever heard it spoken.    After I melted a pair of knee socks in an unsuccessful attempt to dry them at the electric fire in our hotel, I learned that a neighboring town had a laundermat and decided that, vacation or no, laundry had to be done.

nytimes_articles.headline: Players Polish Their Shooters For U.S. Marbles Tournament
nytimes_articles.abstract: ON the amusement pier here, one recent Saturday, riders shrieked as the Sea Serpent dropped them from dizzying heights, but the two youngsters on the beach nearby paid no attention.    Alyisa Mercaldo, 7, from Villas, and Michael Vasser, 9, from West Cape May, were shooting marbles on a cement block. As New Jersey's entrants in the four-day National Marbles Tournament, which begins here tomorrow, they were learning one of the secrets of marbles champions: concentration.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A review on May 23 about "The Real Anita Hill," by David Brock, misstated Ms. Hill's law school affiliation. She is at the University of Oklahoma, not Oklahoma State University.

nytimes_articles.headline: Geraldine Visco, Paul A. Capello
nytimes_articles.abstract: Geraldine Winifred Visco, a daughter of Carmella Watkins of Santa Barbara, Calif., and Louis Visco of Burlington, Mass., was married yesterday to Paul Anthony Capello, a son of Gilda Tisa of Brooklyn and Luciano Capello of Zurich. The Rev. Bruno J. Visco, a Unitarian Universalist minister and the bride's uncle, performed the ceremony at the White Horse Tavern in Newport, R.I.    Mrs. Visco Capello, 38, writes short stories and is an administrator for the department of industrial engineering and operations research at Columbia University. She graduated from Columbia and received a master's degree in writing there. The bride is a stepdaughter of Rhonda Visco of Burlington and the late John Watkins.

nytimes_articles.headline:
CUTTINGS;
Deciphering Soil's True Nature
nytimes_articles.abstract:
TRYING to understand soil by submitting it to chemical tests is like trying to understand the human body by cutting off a finger, grinding it to a paste and performing the same sort of tests. You may learn a lot about the chemistry of the soil -- as you would learn about the body's chemistry -- but you would learn nothing at all about the intricate linkage of systems, or about how the soil -- or the body -- functions as a whole.

Like the human body, the soil is full of channels and pathways, directing substances into useful combinations. While the body transforms food, soil transforms the four elements: earth, air, fire and water.

nytimes_articles.abstract: Caroline Drew Oehmler, an associate at the law firm of Rome, George & Klein in Boston, and Dr. Sherman Morris Chamberlain, a resident in internal medicine at Deaconess Hospital, also in Boston, were married yesterday. The Rev. Ronald Coyne, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Benjamin Rudavsky officiated at the Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass.

Those involved in weekly "issues" meetings of this group are:

nytimes_articles.headline: Landmarking Enters the Jet Age
nytimes_articles.abstract: Mammon and modernism dominated the agenda of the Landmarks Preservation Commission last Tuesday. It considered giving landmark status to six grand banking rooms in Brooklyn and Manhattan that resemble temples, basilicas and palazzi.   Perhaps more remarkably, it examined the gull-like T.W.A. terminal at Kennedy International Airport, the crystalline former Pepsi-Cola Building on Park Avenue, a glass-fronted town house by Philip Johnson and two interiors at the New School for Social Research: the egg-shaped auditorium and a classroom with murals by Jose Clemente Orozco.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A photograph of Antoine de Saint-Exupery on May 30 omitted a credit. The photographer was John Phillips.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Isle Without the Emerald
nytimes_articles.abstract: ANYONE who associates Ireland with all things green may be startled by the Burren, a limestone plateau covering about 200 square miles of northern County Clare on the Atlantic coast, not far from Shannon Airport. Rather than rich rolling hills, it has a gray, timeless austerity.   This stark landscape of megalithic tombs, caverns and castles, craggy lunarlike rocks and the most unusual flora in the country takes its name from the Gaelic boirinn, meaning stony area. Unlike the topography of the rest of Ireland, there are no bogs and few pastures. The limestone is deeply fissured, and most streams and rivers have gone underground. The only lakes are known as turloughs, hollows that fill up after a heavy rainfall saturates the underground systems and then evaporate after a few dry days. With few prominent landmarks, the Burren's landscape appears to stretch in an endless series of bare, irregularly shaped stones, dry and treeless.

nytimes_articles.headline: SURFACING
nytimes_articles.abstract: HUMILIATION -- Kill-all-the-lawyers redux: Echoes of Shakespeare's maxim are found in "Jurassic Park" (T. rex's first victim is a money-grubbing coward-at-law) and in a Miller Lite commercial in which several briefcase-toting lawyers are chased and roped in a rodeo. CLUBS -- Valet parking in Manhattan: Proof of the trend-fuse on the South Beach-Los Angeles-Manhattan axis. Valet parking has appeared at New York clubs like the Roxy and the Palace. RECREATION -- Windskating: Two of the slickest modes of getting from here to there -- Rollerblading and windsurfing -- are married in this sport, in which bladers carry a kite-like sail roll and blow around.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rudolph's Legacy: Triumphs Over Pain
nytimes_articles.abstract: WILMA RUDOLPH sat in an oversized chair looking very cool, very casual. The roses that had begun to arrive that morning in honor of her 53d birthday next Wednesday accented her natural elegance. It was what Ed Temple, her track coach at Tennessee State, liked to call "that charisima."   "I thought I'd be able to sneak this birthday in," she said smiling. "Everybody knows. It's really fascinating; I still get gifts and letters from people around the world."

nytimes_articles.headline: Another India
nytimes_articles.abstract: A RIVER SUTRA By Gita Mehta. 291 pp. New York: Nan A. Talese/Doubleday. $20.

nytimes_articles.headline: Olympus Plan Likely To Raise Taxes
nytimes_articles.abstract: Supporters of the Olympus-Parr Development project are making the impossible assertion that Huntington taxpayers will receive a decrease in their taxes as a result of the project. Even County Executive Robert J. Gaffney, on a recent radio broadcast made this very claim. Nothing could be further from the truth.   The public-relations team lobbying to sell the project claims that some amount of payment in lieu of taxes would be paid on the 53.7 acres of state land on which the multimillion-dollar corporate headquarters would be built. But first the public should know that Olympus and Parr Development may not be paying anything. The State Urban Development Corporation, after repeated requests under the Freedom of Information Act and a court order, which is being appealed, still won't reveal the content of the property leases involved, thereby making it impossible for homeowners to know what taxes or other payments would actually be required by law. This alone should arouse suspicion as to who will be paying for what when the deal is completed. Public-relations talk doesn't legally commit Olympus-Parr to anything.

nytimes_articles.headline: Price Battles His Way Into Third Place
nytimes_articles.abstract: Nick Price, the compact battler from Zimbabwe now playing out of Orlando, Fla., had a good day at the United States Open when so many others did not. Price shot par, 70, to make for a 54-hole total of 207, third-best in the field, four strokes back of the leader, Lee Janzen, and three behind Payne Stewart.    For Price the key hole was the 13th, where he sank the putt that, he said, "turned the day around for me. I was hitting the ball really well but I couldn't get it in the hole. Then I made about a 25-footer that gave me a birdie and some relief."

nytimes_articles.headline:
Long Island Q&A;: Pierce Gardner;
Why Adults, as Well as Children, Should Receive Immunizations
nytimes_articles.abstract:
DR. PIERCE GARDNER, 57, is a professor of medicine at the State University at Stony Brook. He is also chairman of the American College of Physicians panel on adult immunizations. The panel recently recommended changes for adults vaccinations to the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices of the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. 

Drs. Gardner and William Schaffner of the Vanderbilt University School of Medicine wrote in April in The New England Journal of Medicine that the poor record of immunizing adults stemmed from doubts about the vaccines, uncertainty about specific recommendations, concerns about liability, inadequate reimbursement and poorly developed systems for immunizing adults.
