nytimes_articles.headline: Cauthen Finds a Job
nytimes_articles.abstract: STEVE CAUTHEN has been hired to do promotional work for Turfway Park, the Cincinnati-area track in Florence, Ky. He will share the title of associate vice president with STEVE FORD. Cauthen, 33, grew up in nearby Walton and in 1978, at age 18, rode Affirmed to the Triple Crown. Cauthen raced in England and Europe from 1979 until last year, then returned to his farm at Verona, Ky., unsure of his future, unwilling to return to Europe's reduced earnings opportunities and too heavy to ride in the United States. He has been helping his mother train horses at River Downs in Cincinnati. (AP)

nytimes_articles.headline: The War Against Anita Hill
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   I found Signe Wilkinson's review of David Brock's book "The Real Anita Hill: The Untold Story" (May 23) right on target.

nytimes_articles.headline: At the Village Well
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: Libby Lubin's "Hanging Out With the Wash" recalled a trip of ours to Paris in April 1992, where we met our daughter. After a semester in Wales, she had been spending her spring break vagabonding around Europe -- and had the dirty laundry to prove it.   One morning at breakfast, as we planned a day at the Musee D'Orsay, my husband announced that he had seen a coin laundry and intended to go do the wash. Over our protests ("We did not come to Paris to rinse and fold!"), he set off in the Metro with two suitcases full.

nytimes_articles.headline: Looking for Cheerleaders in Montana
nytimes_articles.abstract: HOW I CAME WEST, AND WHY I STAYED Stories. By Alison Baker. 182 pp. San Francisco: Chronicle Books. Paper, $9.95.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ms. Edmonds, Mr. Messinger
nytimes_articles.abstract: Catherine Edmonds, the owner of Wallis & Edmonds, an event-planning company, was married yesterday to Matthew S. Messinger, a casting director for film, television and theater. Both work in New York. The Rev. Gaylord Shimnoski, an Episcopal priest, and Rabbi Nathaniel Schwartz officiated at the Americas Society in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Correction
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article last Sunday about recordings by Leonard Bernstein described the Leonard Bernstein Center for the Arts in Nashville incorrectly. It is an educational center, not the repository of his archives, which has yet to be established.

nytimes_articles.headline: Using Sorrel, A Lemony Accent
nytimes_articles.abstract: ONE year I planted a couple of sorrel seedlings in a corner of my garden. We had rented the house for the summer and when we returned the following year, I was amazed to see that the entire flower bed had been overrun. The sorrel had gone to seed and stood two feet high with leaves as big as the pages of a book. No matter how hard I tried to cut it back, it seemed to grow up again overnight like Jack's beanstalk. But I love sorrel, and I was delighted to have so much of it.    Sorrel has a sharp, lemony taste that is great with lamb, veal, chicken, fish and eggs. A few raw leaves are delicious in salads, too (you can add other leaves like nasturtium, basil, lemon balm and young lettuces and dress them with nothing but lemon and olive oil).

nytimes_articles.headline: A Couple of Predators
nytimes_articles.abstract:
SAVE ME, JOE LOUIS
By Madison Smartt Bell.
351 pp. New York: 
Harcourt Brace & Company. $23.95.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Dual View of Debussy
nytimes_articles.abstract: The English pianist Paul Crossley has taken a cleansing look at Debussy's "Preludes," to begin his survey of the composer's complete piano music (Sony Classical SK 52583 and 53111; two CD's). Also included here are both books of "Images," "Children's Corner," "Estampes" and "La Plus que Lent."   Mr. Crossley offers considerable pleasure even before he plays a note. He writes as interestingly about Debussy's music as he plays it. And when, in his program notes, he wants to put his finger on one of music's most elusive methodologies, he wisely quotes the composer himself.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Thrill of the Kill
nytimes_articles.abstract: On a sunny afternoon at Republic Airport, two airplanes prepare to taxi to the runway. In the cockpits, two doctors are anxiously waiting to kill each other.    The control tower operator gives the signal for departure, and in one cockpit, Dr. Ron Mann waves into a video camera. "Hi, Mom," he says. "We're going against Peter Welsh today. We're going to wax his fanny."

nytimes_articles.headline: For Rape Victims, a New Fear: AIDS
nytimes_articles.abstract:
FOR weeks after she was raped at knife point by a man with a nylon stocking over his face, all she could think about was getting AIDS.

"I figured he hadn't killed me one way, but he could still kill me another way," said the 32-year-old resident of Union County, who recently recounted her ordeal of four years ago but insisted upon anonymity. "When I went for an AIDS test, it was the second time that I literally wondered if I would live or die."

nytimes_articles.headline: The War Against Anita Hill
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   What I want to know is whether the eventual appearance of a carefully researched, balanced monograph on Anita Hill will be accorded a great big review, like the gullible praise song that David Brock's thimblerig attack on Ms. Hill received. NELL IRVIN PAINTER Princeton, N.J.

nytimes_articles.headline: Don't Let the Pesticide Polluters Fool You; We're All Lab Animals
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Re "Mother Nature's Pesticide Factory" by Michael Fumento (Op-Ed, June 9): Environmentalists are correct in wanting to ban potentially toxic chemicals, and Carol Browner, Environmental Protection Administrator, is equally justified in seeking a revision of the Delaney Clause, though not for the right reasons.   Since 1958 the Delaney Clause has allowed innacurate and misleading data to steer regulation. Until the flawed methodology behind its guidelines is replaced, humans will continue to be industry's real guinea pigs, irrespective of the chemicals tested.

nytimes_articles.headline: Immigration Puzzle
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   For many who live and work productively in this country there is irony in your June 10 front-page report on a Chinese gang leader, suspected of alien smuggling, who twice entered this country illegally, who may have deposited hundreds of other illegals here and now has our immigration system tied up in a protracted request for asylum. I came to this country, legally, as a physician on a student visa in 1964. I was required to report my whereabouts to the Immigration and Naturalization Service each year, and when my time was up, I was emphatically told to leave, which I did. In time I returned, again legally, as a permanent resident.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jennifer J. Brokaw and M. Allen Fry
nytimes_articles.abstract: Dr. Jennifer Jean Brokaw, a daughter of Tom Brokaw, the NBC News anchor, and Meredith Brokaw of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Michael Allen Fry, the son of Allen and Lynne Fry of Claremore, Okla. The Rev. Mitzi Noble, an Episcopal minister, officiated at the Trinity Episcopal Church in Lime Rock, Conn. Lois Gatchell, an Episcopal deacon and a great-aunt of the bride, took part in the ceremony.    Dr. Brokaw and Dr. Fry, both 27, received their medical degrees last week from Dartmouth College. Later this month they are to become residents at the University of New Mexico Hospital in Albuquerque, N.M., she in emergency medicine and he in radiology.

nytimes_articles.headline:
ART;
Haring's Legacies: Confidence And Surety
nytimes_articles.abstract:
EASILY recognizable symbols fill Keith Haring's art, and their repetition helps to convey the image of an artist working with surety and confidence.  The great fame that Haring achieved in the 80's underscores this impression. 

Every project, however, must have an initial formative phase, and part of the value of the Haring exhibition at the Dia Center for the Arts in Bridgehampton is its focus on work that represents the first development of an idea. This provides a show that both sharpens perceptions and feels surprisingly intimate.

nytimes_articles.headline: Topics of The Times; Dads in the Ads
nytimes_articles.abstract: A colleague has been walking around mumbling, not exactly to himself, "Oh yeah, yeah. Sure. Phooey!" He seemed distressed enough to warrant asking what the problem was.

nytimes_articles.headline: NOTES
nytimes_articles.abstract: Steven Spielberg, left, who is raking it in with dinosaurs, now has high hopes for transvestites. The director's production company, Amblin Entertainment, plans to produce a film based on a screenplay titled "To Wong Foo, Thanks for Everything, Julie Newmar."   The screenplay is about three New York drag queens on a road trip that ends when their car breaks down in a small Midwestern town. The script is by Douglas Carter Beane, who wrote the 1991 Off Broadway play "Advice From a Caterpillar."

nytimes_articles.headline: Good Works
nytimes_articles.abstract: Contributing to worthwhile causes, and dining, dancing and mingling around New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Publisher Gives $365 Million To 4 Schools
nytimes_articles.abstract: Walter H. Annenberg, the billionaire who made his fortune from TV Guide magazine, announced yesterday the largest one-time gift to private education in American history, $365 million in cash grants to three universities and one little-known preparatory school in Hightstown, N.J.   Mr. Annenberg, through his family foundation, will award $25 million to Harvard College, $100 million to the Peddie School, his alma mater, and $120 million each to the communications programs at the University of Southern California and the University of Pennsylvania.

nytimes_articles.headline: Deals and Discouts
nytimes_articles.abstract: PARIS PACKAGES Europe Express has Xpress Paris packages from New York, among other cities, with T.W.A. From July 1 to 15, the cost is $959 for air fare; six nights' hotel accommodation at the Pierre Hotel, part of the Quality Inn chain, or the Comfort Inn Montmartre, with tax and service charges; Continental breakfast; airport transfers, a Seine cruise, and other extras. The deadline to buy this package at this price is June 25. The price rises to $1,029 from New York from July 15 through August, then drops to $949 from Sept. 15 to Oct. 31. Airport tax of $33 a person is extra. Prices are based on travel Monday through Thursday. Call (800) 927-3876.   SAN FRANCISCO DISCOUNTS A free booklet for Visa cardholders, co-sponsored by Dollar Rent a Car and the San Francisco Convention and Visitors Bureau, features a variety of discounts and special offers at more than 100 establishments in that city, through Oct. 15. (The booklet must be ordered by Sept. 1.) Among the booklet's offers: $5 off the daily Dollar Value Rate or $20 off the weekly rate for a rental car; a rate of $159 for a deluxe room and breakfast for two at the Ritz-Carlton, including tax and gratuity; buy-one, get-one-free deals on bay cruises; a similar program on either of two Gray Line tours, and discounts on shopping, attractions and restaurants. Discounted purchases must be made with the Visa card. Call (800) 442-2489.   HONG KONG PROGRAMS The Mandarin Oriental Hong Kong and T.B.I. Tours (a division of Japan Travel Bureau International) have a six-night package for $1,345 through August that includes hotel, air fare from the West Coast on United, Continental breakfast daily, round-trip transfers by private car and a half-day tour. Air fare from the East Coast is an additional $230 round trip. Trans-Pacific travel from Friday through Sunday costs $50 more each way, and departure taxes of about $40 are extra. Rates are per person, based on two in a room. Call (800) 223-0266.   BARGE DISCOUNTS Abercrombie and Kent is offering discounts on its barge cruise programs in France. For departures Aug. 11, 18 and 25, the 12-passenger Napoleon cruising the river Rhone between Avignon and Lyons now costs $2,463 in a standard cabin and $2,630 in an upper deck cabin; these rates are a third off regular prices. Fares include meals, drinks and wine and sightseeing. Travelers who book a six-night cruise on the barges Lafayette or L'Abercrombie for July or August and purchase an economy class ticket to Paris on United Airlines from most United States gateways will receive another ticket free. The Lafayette sails the upper Loire and Sancerre regions; the L'Abercrombie cruises the Saone and lower Burgundy. Prices for both start at $2,690 a person sharing a double cabin. Call (800) 323-7308.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Feel of Africa Is Transplanted to Staten Island
nytimes_articles.abstract: When Anthony Idow hankers for a native Nigerian dish or fresh news from his homeland, he simply strolls over to one of the blazing grills dotting his neighborhood, where men and women in flowing tribal gowns, shirts and headdresses gather against a backdrop of leafy streets and cloistered suburban-style homes on Staten Island.   "This is the way we lead our life back home," Mr. Idow, 30, explained as he stood on Targee Street, a commercial strip bustling with West African street vendors and music. "We get together after work for peaceful conversations and drinks. This is just like home to us."

nytimes_articles.headline: Susan L. Golden, Victor Del Rio
nytimes_articles.abstract: Susan L. Golden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Golden Jr. of Teaneck, N.J., was married on Friday to Victor Del Rio, a son of Adeline Del Rio of Brooklyn and the late Jose Del Rio. The Rev. Jack Lord performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in New York.   Mrs. Del Rio, 30, is a reading specialist and the assistant to the head of the lower school at the Allen-Stevenson School in New York. She graduated from Villanova University and received a master's degree in education from Fordham University. Her father is the president of Milberg Factors Inc., a factoring and commercial financing concern in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: Susan Gates and Michael Pottinger Jr.
nytimes_articles.abstract: Susan Roberts Gates, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Moore Gates Jr. of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Michael Howard Pottinger Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pottinger of Louisville, Ky. The Rev. Wallace M. Alston Jr., a Presbyterian minister, officiated in the garden at the Hun School. The Rev. William Allard, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bridegroom, took part in the ceremony.   Mrs. Pottinger, 29, is a counselor at the Tillicum Middle School in Bellevue, Wash. She graduated from St. Lawrence University and received a master's degree in counseling from the University of Vermont. Her father is a principal with Gates, Wilmerding, Carper & Rawlings, an investment counseling firm, in Princeton.

nytimes_articles.headline: Shrimpers Voice Fear On Growth of Factory
nytimes_articles.abstract: Out on San Antonio Bay, as a hazy Texas sun arches overhead, shrimp trawlers with names like the Lady Harvester and the Gulf Tide drag their nets placidly back and forth before puttering back to the fish markets here for a decades-old ritual of local commerce. Tens of thousands of bay shrimp pass along conveyor belts, then are cleaned, weighed, packed in ice and bartered over. (Current price, 65 cents or so a pound.)    But the languorous pace in the fishing villages along this stretch of the Gulf of Mexico belies a profound anger among those whose livelihood has long been tied to the seafood-rich bays and estuaries of the Texas coast.

nytimes_articles.headline:
The View From: Greenwich;
Where a Passion for Books Is Tolerated, in Fact Indulged
nytimes_articles.abstract:
YOU can leave home without it. In fact, you don't even need old-fashioned cash to buy at Just Books, a tiny, overstuffed shop in downtown Greenwich that is everything a chain bookstore is not -- except phenomenally successful. 

"You can take a book home without having paid for it," said Bernie Rath, executive director of the American Booksellers Association, an organization of 8,000 booksellers that is based in Tarrytown, N.Y. He added of Just Books's owner, Warren Cassell, "And he won't ask for your mother's maiden name."

nytimes_articles.headline: A Switch That Fails Equals Inconsistency
nytimes_articles.abstract: THERE are situations in which it is clever to change horses in midstream, leaving a befuddled opponent to stare as you gallop off in a new direction. But if your ploy doesn't work and you get smashed, your fans will lament your inconsistency.    And so it was in the game between the grandmasters Alexei Shirov of Latvia and Oscar Panno of Argentina in Round 3 of the Fourth Miguel Najdorf International Tournament in Buenos Aires in April.

nytimes_articles.headline: At AIDS Epicenter, Seeking Swift, Sure Death
nytimes_articles.abstract: Scores of gay men gathered last week in a church meeting room here, at the epicenter of the AIDS epidemic, to learn which drugs to use for suicide, how to avoid a botched attempt and whether to involve their loved ones and doctors.    The unusual how-to seminar was led by Derek Humphry, the founder of the Hemlock Society and the author of a best-selling suicide manual, who said that teaching people to kill themselves was a "sad commentary on our society" but a logical development in a country that largely outlaws doctor-assisted suicide.

nytimes_articles.headline: Towns Fall in Line On Pinelands Bill
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THREE Suffolk County towns have given final consent tothe creation of a five-member state commission to oversee development in the Long Island pine barrens. The approvals remove a major hurdle for the effort to preserve 50,000 acres of the pinelands.

The agreements from Brookhaven, Southampton and Riverhead, where the remaining 100,000 acres of pine barrens are situated, were crucial to the progress of the legislation nearing a vote in Albany.

nytimes_articles.headline: 2 Birdies At Start Let Janzen Lead by 1
nytimes_articles.abstract: At every stage of his career in golf, Lee Janzen has made sudden, dramatic leaps.   As an amateur who didn't begin playing seriously until he was 15, he became a college all-America. As a young professional who had to wait four years before he made the PGA Tour, he won the first time he was in serious contention.

nytimes_articles.headline: Editors' Notes
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Westchester Q&A column on page 3 in some copies of the Westchester Weekly today interviews Harold E. Vogt, chairman of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield. It quotes him as saying that his company was subjected to erroneous claims of mismanagement and that he and other board members understood what was happening as its financial problems developed.   As the introductory paragraphs report, the interview took place early in June, before the acknowledgment by Mr. Vogt last week that Empire had repeatedly submitted erroneous financial reports to New York State regulators and had used the false data to help secure a major revision of insurance law in its favor.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rebecca Spencer, Charles Rice
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Rev. Rebecca L. Spencer, the senior minister of the Central Congregational Church in Providence, R.I., was married yesterday to Charles B. Rice, a liquidator in Franklin, Mass., for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The Rev. Dr. William Nye, a United Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother in Middlebury, Conn.   The bride graduated from Wellesley College and received a master's degree in divinity from Harvard University. She is a daughter of Henry C. Spencer of Green Valley, Ariz., and Evelyn Burchard Spencer. Her father, now retired, was a vice president of the Kerite Company, a manufacturer of copper wire and cable in Seymour, Conn.

nytimes_articles.headline: Mentor to Some, Cult Leader to Others
nytimes_articles.abstract: TO his followers, he is Rama, a gifted teacher and spiritual leader with special powers who offers a path to enlightenment, happiness and career success. To his detractors, he is everything from a sophisticated con man to a dangerous cult leader.   Controversy has surrounded Dr. Frederick P. Lenz for the last 15 years as he has moved his base of operations to different cities around the country. Trina Walker, a former student, said that Dr. Lenz has more than a hundred students in Westchester County. He offers lectures at several places, including regular monthly lectures, by invitation only, at the Performing Arts Center at the State University of New York at Purchase. The group has been renting space at SUNY for three years but is not affiliated with the college.

nytimes_articles.headline: How the Laws Work In Regulating Rent Market
nytimes_articles.abstract: The rent-regulated housing market in New York City and some suburban counties includes more than a million apartments and is divided into two categories, rent controlled and stabilized.   Rent-controlled apartments are those built before 1947 that have been continuously occupied by the current tenant, or a legal successor, since 1971. The tenants have no leases, but instead have a statutory right to occupy the apartment for as long as they want.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Last Laugh
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Leonore Gershwin, Ira's widow, was a snarling Cerberus when it came to the use of George Gershwin's music. In 1986, the director Paul Bartel and I prepared a 30-minute episode for the "Amazing Stories" fantasy series on television. Titled "Gershwin's Trunk," our story had George, channeled through a medium, coming back to deliver new songs.

nytimes_articles.headline: Japan's Crisis: U.S. to Profit?
nytimes_articles.abstract: For the better part of four decades America has held tight to the view that the unshakable dominance of a single, conservative party in Japan is essential to Washington's most critical alliance in the Pacific -- first as a bulwark against Communism, and second as a platform for one of the world's most remarkable economic success stories.   But as the party grew bloated with power, and the endless payoffs and influence-peddling became an international embarrassment for Japan, American officials increasingly found themselves forced to avert their eyes from the system's rotting core.

nytimes_articles.headline: Get a Life, Valentina
nytimes_articles.abstract: PERSONAL EFFECTS By Francesca Duranti. Translated by Stephen Sartarelli. 152 pp. New York: Random House. $19.  AFTER 10 years of marriage, Valentina Barbieri has been jilted by her husband, a monster of appetite. Riccardo "wants everything": fame, designer clothes, an expensive car, a fancy address, a summer retreat, swanky friends, experimental sex and, above all, money. And he gets it -- gets a radio talk show and a showpiece girlfriend too, an economist, appropriately enough. He does all this by writing smart-alecky and irreverent biographies of the church fathers. These biographies succeed, however, because of Valentina's research and editing, for which she has received no recompense, material or emotional. One day she hears furtive scratchings on the door of her apartment, formerly theirs, and through the peephole discovers her ex-husband removing the brass plaque on which is engraved his name, formerly theirs. "As of that moment," Valentina says, "I ceased to exist."

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: A report in the Travel Advisory column on May 9 about 15-day Scandinavian tours that commemorate the 50th anniversary of the rescue of Danish Jews from the Nazis misstated the cost. A letter from the tour company, dated June 3, pointed out that the price of $2,588 a person is for land arrangements only and does not include air fare.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jerome Kern: The Song Is Mine
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Lawrence O'Toole makes valid points about the lengths to which some popular composers' estates will go to insure that the music is put to "good, tasteful and interesting use." While it's true that some composers of classic American musicals "had a more casual attitude," Jerome Kern, for instance, was known to have fired singers at rehearsals before Broadway openings for changing even one note of his score. Richard Rodgers usually approved of Frank Sinatra's liberties with his songs, but one can imagine what Kern would have thought of the crooner's swinging version of "The Song Is You" in the late 1950's. ALEX JESCHKE Pittsford, N. Y.

nytimes_articles.headline: Melissa Brooks, Robert Zakarian
nytimes_articles.abstract: Melissa Millicent Brooks, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Brooks of Glen Head, L.I., was married to Robert Anthony Zakarian, the son of Elizabeth Zakarian and Jack Zakarian, both of Modesto, Calif. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I.

nytimes_articles.headline: Kathleen King and Christopher Moran
nytimes_articles.abstract: Kathleen P. King, the daughter of Thomas F. and Kathleen M. King of Rockville Centre, L.I., was married there on Friday to Christopher G. Moran, a son of William A. and Dr. Theresa K. Moran of West Hempstead, L.I., and Chicago. Msgr. Robert Mulligan performed the ceremony at St. Agnes Cathedral.   Mrs. Moran, 26, graduated from the University of Virginia. She and her husband are associates at Goldman, Sachs & Company in New York, she in the investment banking division and he in the municipal bond department. The bride's father is a trader in the equities division at Goldman, Sachs in New York. Her mother is a real-estate broker in Rockville Centre.

nytimes_articles.headline: Car Thefts Increase Sharply at Train Stations
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THOMAS J. MORAN of Deer Park had a factory-installed antitheft device when he bought his 1990 Honda CRX, knowing that the car would be vulnerable to thieves in the lot at the Deer Park train station.

It was stolen, anyway, one of 445 cars swiped last year from train stations in Suffolk, a 23 percent increase over 1991.

nytimes_articles.headline:
ART;
First Show of Siblings Who Were Indeed Rivals
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IF the people of Connecticut can't go to the mountain -- Mount Rushmore, that is -- the mountain will come to them. At least it will be an association in "The Borglums of Fairfield County," a retrospective of the sculpture of Gutzon and Solon Borglum in the Rich Forum of the Stamford Center for the Arts.

The Borglum brothers were competitors. They had individual styles and focused on different subjects besides spending their lives engaged in a bitter feud, and this show is the first time that their work has been exhibited together. The show is surprisingly moving, and passersby can't help but be affected by it. Gutzon Borglum's "Seated Lincoln," a larger-than-life-size figure is sited on the sidewalk outside the Forum at the corner of Atlantic Street and Tresser Boulevard. This Lincoln seems especially spindly, even gawky, pensive yet approachable. A similar sculpture in Newark, N.J. is nicknamed the "Children's Lincoln."

nytimes_articles.headline: Surge in Free Lunches At Schools a Sign of Tough Times
nytimes_articles.abstract: IN what state and local education officials say is a good measure of a bad economy, the number of children receiving free lunches at schools on Long Island is rising. Even so, the officials said, many children who qualify for the lunches do not receive them because their parents are afraid or embarrassed to apply.   As more family incomes begin to feel the effects of long-term unemployment, the surge of applications for free or reduced-price lunches, which began to hit districts last year, has continued in the school year that ends this month. According to the State Education Department, the number of specially priced lunches served on the Island has also grown again.  21% Increase in Two Years    Of the nearly 14 million lunches served in Long Island schools through February of this school year, 34 percent were free or reduced in price, up from 32 percent last year and 28 percent in the 1990-91 school year. That is, proportionally, a 21 percent increase over the two years.

nytimes_articles.headline: How a Writer Became Guardian of a Dune
nytimes_articles.abstract:
I MET Ed Kleban on Memorial Day weekend 1978. I was a writer for "Captain Kangaroo" and had rented a house in East Hampton for the first time. Ed was the lyricist of "A Chorus Line." Although he had "shared" in the Hamptons as a struggling writer, now that his smash hit was in its third year on Broadway, he finally felt that he could afford his own summer rental. With a pool. He moved his Steinway out from Manhattan into a rambling house on Spring Close owned by his friends the Broadway writer Peter Stone, and his wife, Mary.

Ed was barbecuing in the backyard when we met. I can still picture hiswaving the spatula like a conductor rehearsing an orchestra of hamburgers. I was impressed to meet him. A fellow kid from the boroughs -- him the Bronx, me Queens -- who had written the groundbreaking musical of the decade. In his baggy shorts, on the spacious lawn he looked like a city urchin on a self-endowed scholarship to a high-tone Fresh Air Fund. But Ed quickly became an entrenched Hamptonite -- composing at the piano, tennis, Latham House crewnecks slung just the right way over the shoulders. When a summer storm flooded the room that housed the Steinway, his upset was salved by the sight of his Pulitzer-Tony-Edgar winning landlord's cleaning his gutters.
Revue at Cabaret 

 Ed first came to East Hampton in 1972 when he wrote songs and played the piano for "The Revue at Moon," a cabaret on Montauk Highway, on the site most recently occupied by the Little Rock Rodeo. The show included sketches co-written by Avery Corman and Dan Greenburg, by Jules Feiffer and by Murray Schisgal. A local review called Ed's songs "hilarious . . . all sung in grand Broadway style, dealing with a variety of breakfast foods ("French Toast, French Toast, je t'aime')." The revue also featured Ed's song "Better," which Barbra Streisand later recorded but didn't release and which Phyliss Newman introduced on "The Tonight Show" with Johnny Carson.

nytimes_articles.headline: Suzanne Hopkins, Jonathan Chase
nytimes_articles.abstract: Suzanne Middleton Hopkins, a daughter of Barbara Hopkins of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Chester Hopkins of New York, was married yesterday evening to Dr. Jonathan Seth Chase, a son of Gertrude Chase of Pearl River, N.Y., and the late Howard Chase. Rabbi Steven Pearce performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Hirsch, friends of the bride's parents, in Hastings-on-Hudson.

nytimes_articles.headline:
Connecticut Q. & A.: Helene Pepe;
Immigrants, Home Care and the Law
nytimes_articles.abstract:
JUST as Anita Hill's testimony in the Clarence Thomas confirmation hearings focused attention on sexual harassment, Zoe Baird's child-care dilemma and the solution she settled for has sparked discussion of how few alternatives working parents have. Many families have had the experience of finding a warm, well-qualified child-care provider who lacks one important credential: the right to work legally in the United States. 

An immigration lawyer in Stamford, Helene Pepe, who represented Victor Cordero, Ms. Baird's chauffeur who returned to Peru when his illegal alien status was revealed, is working with a group from the American Immigration Lawyers Association to draft changes to existing law that would create a temporary visa for home-care workers. It's an easy and cost-effective solution that would solve plenty of problems, in Ms. Pepe's view: Families would have access to a qualified, willing and affordable labor pool to fill critical jobs in child care and elder care and it would grant a temporary legal status for the many illegal aliens already working in such jobs.

nytimes_articles.headline: Short of Money, U.N. Refugee Official Asks for Aid
nytimes_articles.abstract: Faced with a serious shortage of money, the United Nations official charged with caring for the world's 18.9 million refugees plans to summon representatives of the richest countries to a meeting here in July to ask them squarely whether they are willing to continue paying the bill.   "With this funding we can't continue," Sadako Ogata, the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, said in an interview at her headquarters here this week. "For most operations I've only got money for another month or two."

nytimes_articles.headline: An Outlet Masquerading as a Gallery
nytimes_articles.abstract: IN Little Italy, Julie Dermansky's storefront gallery provides a refreshing art-world experience. Ms. Dermansky, 27, dispenses her own paintings, sculpture, furniture, jewelry, ceramics, collages and art books out of a cluttered shop called J. S. D. Studio, where the floor is thick with paint spatters, an old sign that reads "Segunda Iglesia Pentecostal" still hangs above the door, and prices are as low as $15.   "I opened the store in the spirit of the pop artist Claes Oldenburg, who used to sell his work out of a storefront in the East Village," Ms. Dermansky said. "When I moved to New York two and a half years ago, it seemed really difficult to get representation, so I thought, why not open a store?"

nytimes_articles.headline: New Hydrofoil In Vietnam
nytimes_articles.abstract: Until recently, traveling from Ho Chi Minh City to the beach at Vung Tau 60 miles away required a land trip that took anywhere from two to four hours because of the condition of the roads (basic, at best) and the traffic (a melange of trucks, bicycles, cyclos, motorcycles and oxen carts). Now, a Russian-built hydrofoil leaves every morning at 8 A.M. from the docks on the Saigon River near the Saigon Floating Hotel (Me Linh Square) and arrives 90 minutes later at the resort the French called Cap St.-Jacques. The 112-foot craft is crewed by Russians and has a snack bar.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Long Shot for Casinos: Sports Betting on Ballot
nytimes_articles.abstract: In a campaign akin to a political race, the Casino Association of New Jersey is conducting a last-ditch effort to get a sports betting referendum on the ballot in November.   The association, which represents the 12 Atlantic City casinos, is in the final week of a two-week, $500,000 campaign that has included newspaper, television and radio advertisements, mailings to state legislators and the recruitment of gamblers off gaming floors.

nytimes_articles.headline: Legislators Seek to Curb Fund-Raisers
nytimes_articles.abstract: IN an effort to crack down on scams that bilk New Jersey residents out of millions of dollars a year, two State Assemblymen have introduced a bill that would completely revamp the law regulating fund raising in the state.   The bill, which was recently released from committee and awaits a vote in the full Assembly, significantly expands the state's ability to monitor fund-raising activities by requiring registration of all fund-raising organizations except for religious and educational groups. The proposal would also give officials the power to audit the records of fund-raising organizations and to fine those that violate the law.

nytimes_articles.headline: Phoenix No Vacation For the Visiting Bulls
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Chicago Bulls expected to be on vacation today. Instead, they were in Phoenix preparing for another challenge.   Thanks to the Suns' 108-98 victory Friday night in Game 5 of the National Basketball Association finals, the series returned to the Valley of the Sun. And the Bulls were feeling the heat.

nytimes_articles.headline: Shirien Taylor and Ron Wasserman
nytimes_articles.abstract: Shirien Taylor, the principal second violinist with the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra in New York, was married on Monday to Ron Wasserman, the principal bassist with the New York City Ballet Orchestra. Paul Phinney, a town justice in Orangetown, N.Y., performed the ceremony in his chambers in Orangeburg, N.Y.   Ms. Taylor is keeping her name. She is a daughter of Sharlyn Matthews of Green Valley, Ariz., and the late Edward Taylor. Her mother, who is retired, taught music in the Albuquerque, N.M., school system. The bride is a stepdaughter of Ellery Matthews. Her previous marriage ended in divorce.

nytimes_articles.headline: Infiniti's G20: Luxury at the Entry Level
nytimes_articles.abstract: IT must be tough to be an automotive-product planner.   Sure, you have an easy day when the boss comes by and tells you to whip up a fantastic sports car. Or a utility vehicle. Or even a new station wagon. But what do you do if you work for a luxury line and you have to invent an "entry-level" car?

nytimes_articles.headline: A Very Personal AIDS Project
nytimes_articles.abstract: Protection Productions, a group of young New Yorkers who are producing an educational film about AIDS, has some big-name backers: Saul Steinberg, Robert Woolley, Bill Blass and Mark Hampton all showed up at Amanda Burden's apartment on June 8 for a fund-raiser for the project.   The filmmakers include, below, from left to right, Michael Swanhaus, Beatriz de la Sierra, Belle Burden (Ms. Burden's daughter), Rafael de la Sierra and Nancy Hirsch.

nytimes_articles.headline:
ART;
Box Format: Container and Receptacle
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE juried exhibition now at the Islip Art Museum features 77 pieces using the box as the basic format or motif.  The show, "Exploring the Corners: Box Works," was selected by Nancy Driscoll, director of the gallery in Sea Cliff bearing her name. Judging by her choices, artists responded imaginatively to the call for entries, interpreting the theme with considerable latitude.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Dinosaur Era, Frozen in Amber
nytimes_articles.abstract: AS thousands of moviegoers in 39 theaters across the state stood on long lines last weekend to see Steven Spielberg's dinosaur epic, "Jurassic Park," researchers from the American Museum of Natural History in New York were unearthing ancient material in New Jersey that, at some point in the distant future, could make the movie's scientific premise a reality.   The film, based on Michael Crichton's best-selling 1990 novel, centers on a theme park built on a remote island off Costa Rica where dinosaurs roam in jungle habitats bound by electrified fences. The dinosaurs are clones, created from DNA extracted from parasitic insects that had ingested dinosaur blood and then been imbedded in tree resin. When the resin hardened into amber, the film suggests, the insects -- and the dinosaur blood -- were preserved.

nytimes_articles.headline: Virginia Galda, Andrew Woelflein
nytimes_articles.abstract: Virginia Aletha Galda, a daughter of Odessa P. Galda of Tryon, N.C., and the late Frank D. Galda, was married yesterday to Andrew Buckley Woelflein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kevin G. Woelflein of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Christina Condit performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in Saluda, N.C.   Mrs. Woelflein is a project manager in global operations for the American Express Bank in New York. She graduated cum laude from Duke University. Her father was the manager of a J. C. Penney store in Grosse Pointe, Mich.

nytimes_articles.headline: Co-op Loans
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   Your article on June 6 entitled "A Mortgage Hurdle Blocks Some Co-op Sales" discusses the reluctance of banks to make co-op apartment loans when a significant proportion -- typically more than 50 percent -- of the apartments in the building are still owned by the sponsor.

nytimes_articles.headline: Public & Private; Daughter Of the Groom
nytimes_articles.abstract: My father was married for the third time last month. This makes him sound a good deal more Liz Taylorish than is accurate or fair. He is, happily, a good man who loves women and who, sadly, has had two wives die of cancer. Our eldest child wanted to tell the bride, a warm and intelligent woman we liked instantly, that there was a curse on Grandpop.   But there was a blessing on him, really, and that was that he has been able to learn from death and grief the most useful lesson they can teach, the value of life and happiness. He has taught me that, too, as he has so many other things.

nytimes_articles.headline: In Summer, Film Needs Special Care
nytimes_articles.abstract: FILM should be treated as if it were a delicate food. Like milk, ice cream and mayonnaise, it requires special attention, especially in the summer.   If temperature, time, humidity, X-rays or any number of other silent monsters attack film, it is usually not obvious to the photographer. Spoiled film does not announce itself until it's too late.

nytimes_articles.headline: How Big Were Garbo's Feet?
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   I look forward to reading "First Nights," by Susan Fromberg Schaeffer, reviewed in the May 30 Book Review by Robert Plunket. The reviewer declares Ms. Schaeffer's heroine, Anna Asta, to be "inspired by" -- or, actually, "totally based on, down to the smallest detail" -- Greta Garbo. After referring to various similarities between the character and Garbo, Mr. Plunket mentions that Anna "is sensitive about the size of her feet."

nytimes_articles.headline: Even a Lifer Has Rights
nytimes_articles.abstract: William McKinney, a murderer serving a life sentence in a Nevada prison, has forfeited most of his rights. But he now has one right not automatically granted to people outside the walls. Henceforth, his jailers may no longer indifferently subject him to the secondary smoke of a cellmate who puffs five packs of cigarettes a day.    So says the United States Supreme Court, 7 to 2, with only Justices Clarence Thomas and Antonin Scalia dissenting. Those Justices, who happen to smoke, are normally the least inclined to find that conditions of confinement may be so bad that they constitute cruel and unusual punishment in violation of the Eighth Amendment.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Golf Complex for Downtown Chicago
nytimes_articles.abstract:
A GOLF complex that includes a nine-hole course is coming to Illinois Center, 83 acres of offices, apartments and hotels that is perhaps the nation's largest downtown land-development project since World War II.

The huge development, bounded by South Michigan Avenue, East Randolph Street and East Wacker and North Lake Shore Drives, has been under development for 24 years, but 52 acres have yet to be built upon.

nytimes_articles.headline: Fishers Island Fears Connecticut Sludge
nytimes_articles.abstract:
LIKE particles of matter suspended in water, a couple of plans to dredge the Thames River are floating about and not one makes the 300 year-round residents of Fishers Island feel secure. 

Major decisions that are pending about national defense and the Connecticut economy have cast a shadow on the 3,000-acre island, which lies seven miles from New London and 30 miles from Southold, N.Y., under whose aegis it falls. Residents, fishermen and environmentalists fear that disposal of the dredge spoil in a dumpsite one and one-half miles northwest of Fishers Island will leave both the island and eastern Long Island Sound awash in waste.

nytimes_articles.headline: A 4th Body Is Discovered in the Waters Off Queens
nytimes_articles.abstract: A body of an Asian man was pulled from the sea off Queens yesterday by the United States Coast Guard, the police said.   The Immigration and Naturalization Service said the body might be that of a passenger on the Golden Venture, one of 20 people believed to be missing from the immigrant-smuggling ship that ran aground off Rockaway Beach on June 6 with about 320 passengers.

nytimes_articles.headline: If You're Thinking of Living in: Morningside Heights
nytimes_articles.abstract:
IN a public relations move at the turn of the century, Morningside Heights was named "The Acropolis on the Hill." The name has stuck, at least among guidebook writers and the neighborhood's present enthusiasts.

 Then, as now, educational, spiritual and medical institutions dominated the neighborhood, occupying about half the land; one institution -- Columbia University -- owns another quarter.

nytimes_articles.headline: Flights Of Artistic Fancy
nytimes_articles.abstract: A TWIST of the imagination can transform practical crafts into art forms. At the Sheila Nussbaum Gallery in Millburn, Marylou Higgins's vessels, candle holders, teapots, necklaces and tables have one thing in common: their surfaces are covered with realistic portraits of imaginary people. In Fair Lawn, the Kornbluth Gallery's display of garden accessories includes a ceramic wart hog by Hilda Hortens and Elyse Saperstein's grimacing lizard; both are functional planters.    Ms. Higgins has portrayed literally hundreds of faces and small sculptured figures on her 74 pieces. Some are drawn with a special pencil on bisque-fired clay, others are painted in soft glaze tones and framed in lustrous borders of gold and silver.

nytimes_articles.headline: Susanna Cassell, R. S. Kopchains Jr.
nytimes_articles.abstract: Susanna Dawn Cassell, the daughter of Dr. Samuel and Carol Cassell of Wyckoff, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Stuart Kopchains Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kopchains of Hamburg, N.J. Rabbi Alfred Landsberg and the Rev. Chester Carina, a Roman Catholic priest, jointly officiated at the Indian Trail Club in Franklin Lakes, N.J.   Mrs. Kopchains is a graphic designer and computer graphics specialist at Lewis & Gace, an advertising agency in Fort Lee, N.J. She graduated from the University of Vermont and received a master's degree in graphic design from Rochester Institute of Technology.

nytimes_articles.headline: Corrections
nytimes_articles.abstract: An article on May 30 about Paris misstated the purpose of the Deportation Memorial on the Ile de la Cite. It is dedicated to the 200,000 French men and women -- not only Jews -- who were deported to German concentration camps in World War II. Nearby, on the Right Bank of the Seine, at 17 Rue Geoffroy-l'Asnier, is a memorial to the Unknown Jewish Martyr, dedicated to victims of the Nazis.

nytimes_articles.headline: Both Sides Say Trenton's Ban on Assault Rifles Has Little Effect on Crime
nytimes_articles.abstract: Although New Jersey's pioneering ban on military-style assault rifles was sold to the state as a crime-fighting measure, its impact on violence in the state, two years after it took effect, has been negligible, both sides agree, and debate over its impact is colored more by opinion than by fact.   Of the tens of thousands, and possibly hundreds of thousands, of assault weapons that state officials had said were in the hands of the public, only about 2,000 have been accounted for since their possession was outlawed, on May 30, 1991. The stores that sold the guns do not miss the business, their owners say, and so far, no one has been sent to jail purely for possession of one of the weapons.

nytimes_articles.headline: For Some Collectors, Graphics Is the Name of the Game
nytimes_articles.abstract: It's not how the game was played or even who won that keeps board-game collectors haunting auctions, art galleries, flea markets and garage sales for a Monopoly or a Parcheesi set in mint condition.    "The pictorial part is what you remember," said Ivan Karp, owner of the O. K. Harris gallery in SoHo, where the exhibition "Vintage Board Games" remains through July 16. "The format is the emblem that stays with you."

nytimes_articles.headline: Stacey J. Byer and Craig L. Farlie
nytimes_articles.abstract: Stacey Jane Byer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Norman E. Byer of Columbia, Md., was married yesterday to Craig Leitzow Farlie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William N. Farlie Jr. of Upper Montclair, N.J. The Rev. Charles Beirne, a Roman Catholic priest, and Cantor Judi Porecki jointly officiated at Oxon Hill (Md.) Manor.    The bride and the bridegroom, both 26, graduated from Princeton University. Mrs. Farlie is an admissions officer there. Her father is an associate director of microelectronics for Martin Marietta Laboratories, an aerospace research and development center in Baltimore. Her mother, Eleanor D. Byer, was until recently an accountant for the United Way in Baltimore.

nytimes_articles.headline: The Last Catch On the Hudson
nytimes_articles.abstract: James Carey and his fishing partner, Calman Greenburg, motored out to the middle of Haverstraw Bay, where the Hudson River is four miles wide, to check their nets one last time.   It was the final day of the first season limiting the catch of Atlantic sturgeon, a fish that grows to eight feet and can live for 60 years. And the fishermen said the new restrictions would finally mark the end of commercial fishing on the Hudson.

nytimes_articles.headline: Adventure Trips For the Disabled
nytimes_articles.abstract: The Smithsonian Institution, in partnership with a 15-year-old organization, Wilderness Inquiry, is offering a new program of tours for travelers with and without disabilities. Both groups are charged the same fee.    The program, called Accessible Adventures, has four camping trips this summer, all concentrating on natural history. Trained naturalists will accompany the tours. From July 13 to 19, for example, travelers will explore the one-million-acre Boundary Waters Canoe Area in Minnesota.  The $795 price does not include air fare to Duluth, Minn., and is based on double occupancy in hotels for the first and last nights. Special canoes are equipped to accommodate wheelchairs. Other adventures planned include canoeing along the Missouri River in Montana; kayaking through the Apostle Islands in Lake Superior, and canoeing on Yellowstone Lake in Yellowstone National Park.  Each trip includes about eight people; prices range from $795 to $1,395, excluding air fare.

nytimes_articles.headline: Violations Cited in Fireman's Death
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE State Department of Labor has cited the city of White Plains for violations in a Feb. 24 apartment house blaze that took the life of one firefighter and resulted in serious burns to three others.   The state's notice of violation and order to comply said that the firefighter, Warren Ogburn, 39, entered a South Lexington Avenue apartment building here during firefighting operations, became trapped and was unable to summon assistance using his portable radio. The firefighter succumbed when his air supply became exhausted, according to the ruling, which cited the city's lack of written procedures covering both communications during a fire and the use of respirators.

nytimes_articles.headline: Boys of Summer Find They're Never Too Old
nytimes_articles.abstract: DIVING to his left, the shortstop, Hank Els, makes a scintillating stop of a hard-hit ground ball. Then, with his glove, he flips the ball backhanded to the second baseman, Dennis Leach, for a force-out on a base runner coming from first. The play would draw cheers at a game in the major leagues.   On the very next play, the third baseman, Mark Beers, lunges to his left and spears a line drive for another out. Again, a major-league play.

nytimes_articles.headline: Tomorrow's TV: The Viewer's View/A special report.; Will They Sit by the Set, or Ride a Data Highway?
nytimes_articles.abstract: Is the world ready for the empowered couch potato?    Television viewers keep hearing that they're about to merge into a global computerized information network, one grand Communicopia. It will supposedly enable them to watch 500 channels, browse in electronic shopping malls and libraries, send a fax to Mount Everest and maybe even learn to use the phrase "digital interactive multimedia" in a sentence.

nytimes_articles.headline: South Africa Leader's Unlikely Target: Black Votes
nytimes_articles.abstract: With an African pageant of ostrich-plumed dancers and thundering tribal drums, President F. W. de Klerk today began his improbable campaign for the votes of South African blacks.   Mr. de Klerk, who was introduced as a "strong chief" and the man "who liberated South Africa," told the overwhelmingly black crowd at a livestock show ground in this northern farm town that the event symbolized his party's rebirth from the white oligarchy that invented apartheid to a rainbow coalition of peace-loving, prosperity-seeking moderates.

nytimes_articles.headline:
MUSIC;
Orchestra Plans a Fond Farewell for Hugh Wolff
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE New Jersey Symphony Orchestra is calling its 70th anniversary event next Sunday a "Spectacular Beethoven Celebration of Hugh Wolff." It seems a fitting tribute to the man who has helped the symphony through some difficult times.

In an unprecedented move, several major artists who have worked closely with Mr. Wolff, both in New Jersey and elsewhere, have volunteered to perform as soloists with the orchestra next week. The all-Beethoven farewell to Mr. Wolff -- after his seven years as music director and one year as principal guest conductor -- will be held in Symphony Hall at 3 o'clock.

nytimes_articles.headline: For the Protection Of Village Residents
nytimes_articles.abstract: It would be inefficient to operate a hospital with a staff composed only of doctors. This is why there are nurses, practical nurses, nurses' aides and orderlies to meet the varying needs of the patients.   Law enforcement is similar. It is inefficient to have only police academy graduates -- police officers -- meet the various needs for the security and safety of the residents of different communities. This is why there are peace officers, code-enforcement officers and security guards to provide the various degrees of protection needed.

nytimes_articles.headline: He's a One-Man Team
nytimes_articles.abstract: When JEROME (J.J.) ALEXANDER moved from the Bronx to the tiny Adirondack community of Westport, N.Y., his new high school didn't have a track team. So he gave them one. "I wanted to run, I set my mind on it," said Alexander, 17, was born in Trinidad and Tobago, moved to the United States at 3 and grew up in the Bronx, surrounded by drugs and violence. Summers at a camp in the area helped Alexander fall in love with Wesport and he arranged to spend the school year there with friends. A sprinter at DeWitt Clinton, he wanted to run for his small school (20 students in his junior class) and received permission to do so as a one-man team. He competed at dual meets in the 400 meters and triple jump. "I have no teammates to warm up with," he told The Plattsburgh Press-Republican. "It's hard, but I've gotten used to it." (AP)

(Source: HSH Associates)

nytimes_articles.headline: Turns of Fashion's Wheel
nytimes_articles.abstract: THE store is so crowded that customers fight to hand over their money. The atrium is a seething, swirling mass of humanity clutching shopping totes. Women with glossy hair and sleek suits rub padded shoulders at the beauty counter. Outside on the sidewalk, yuppie couples juggle attache cases and ice cream.   A shopping mall in America? A rerun of a 1980's movie? An ad man's fantasy? No. Just an ordinary shopping day in Shanghai.

nytimes_articles.headline: Rosemary Ryan, Jack D. DeGrado
nytimes_articles.abstract: Drs. Rosemary Ryan and Jack D. DeGrado, dentists in New York, were married there yesterday. The Rev. William Leydon performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Monica's Church.   The bride, 28, is a general-practice dental resident at Lenox Hill Hospital. She graduated from Marymount Manhattan College, and she and her husband received their dental degrees from Columbia University.

nytimes_articles.headline:
In the Region: New Jersey;
Grants to Conservationists Bearing Fruit
nytimes_articles.abstract:
THE movement by conservation groups to keep parts of New Jersey forever wild has been gaining strength, thanks to the help of state grants.

Late in 1991, the New Jersey Green Acres Program, within the state's Department of Environmental Protection and Energy, awarded $10 million in matching grants to organizations for 27 specific projects that are now bearing fruit. The grants enabled nonprofit organizations to buy land or easements on a total of 4,300 acres for conservation or recreation.

nytimes_articles.headline: Ending Up in Downsville
nytimes_articles.abstract: INNOCENT DARKNESS By Edward R. F. Sheehan. 339 pp. New York:  Viking. $22.

nytimes_articles.headline: M. F. Stewart, James Lawless 4th
nytimes_articles.abstract: Marguerite Frances Stewart, a legal assistant at Debevoise & Plimpton, and James Lawless 4th, an associate at Battle Fowler, both New York law firms, were married yesterday. The Rev. James A. Trimble performed the ceremony in the Christ Chapel at the Episcopal Academy in Merion, Pa.

nytimes_articles.headline: At the Village Well
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor: I can share some of the feelings about the Welsh language Pamela Petro described in "Gymru and Cymru and All That." I travel often in Wales, and perhaps, someday, I will have the courage to attempt a conversation in Welsh (although courage should not be necessary, since the Welsh are truly kind and helpful).   Potential Welsh learners should know that substantial rewards accrue long before attainment of conversational fluency. Welsh is so unpredictable that anyone who enjoys languages will become addicted from the first lesson. As reading facility develops, the learner will enjoy one of Europe's great literatures. Most poetry is difficult but the sagas are simple, direct, concise and powerful narrative. "Branwen Ferch Lyr" is a Greek tragedy in prose, 18 pages of elegantly parsimonious narrative (but material for a thousand-page novel) which begin with a pageant of majestic international harmony but soon explode in sadistically murderous violence that pits family against family, stirs up genocidal paranoia, and leaves Branwen to die of grief because "two such marvelous islands" (as Britain and Ireland) have been despoiled on her account.

nytimes_articles.headline: Hot Hotels
nytimes_articles.abstract: WHAT puts the hot in a hot hotel? What is it about the Royalton in Manhattan, to take one established example of the genre, that has made it the sexiest place to stay? Is it Philippe Starck's luxuriously outre big round bathtubs and sleek slate fireplaces? Or is it just that Ian Schrager, the hotel's owner, is something of a celebrity himself?   Yes, and yes again.   There's a peculiar alchemy between location, design and personality that creates a High Desirability Quotient. This month there are two new entries in the field: the $360 million Four Seasons in Manhattan and the somewhat more modestly produced Bridgehampton Motel on Long Island.

nytimes_articles.headline: Madeline Cuomo, Brian O'Donoghue
nytimes_articles.abstract: EVEN as high school sweethearts, Madeline Cuomo and Brian O'Donoghue were more interested in public service than in partying. They met at the St. Francis Preparatory School in Bayside, Queens, and spent many Saturday nights working together in places that were not exactly popular teen-age hangouts, like a nursing home and a shelter for homeless youths.   Ms. Cuomo, a daughter of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and his wife, Matilda, is now 28 and a lawyer specializing in matrimonial law as an associate at the firm of Shea & Gould in Manhattan. Mr. O'Donoghue, 30, just finished his first year of law school at Fordham University and worked until recently as a fire fighter in Manhattan and as a lifeguard at Jones Beach on Long Island.

nytimes_articles.headline: Bookshelf
nytimes_articles.abstract: Additional titles of interest:   THE PERILOUS PIT. By Orel Odinov Protopopescu. Illustrated by Jacqueline Chwast. Green Tiger/Simon & Schuster. $14. (Ages 3 to 8) Katie throws a peach pit over her shoulder as she sits under a tree. The pit sets off a chain of improbable events leading back to a girl sitting under a tree. Witty, stylized illustrations.

nytimes_articles.headline: A Value-Added Tax, No Matter the Adjustments, Can't Be Fair
nytimes_articles.abstract: To the Editor:   The very curious article "Answer: A Value-Added Tax" by Lester C. Thurow (Op-Ed, June 8) is an example of how one might travel from New York to New Jersey by way of California. To begin with, value-added taxes are added incrementally at each stage of production, and they are not, as the author suggests, the difference between component cost and sales price.    However, no matter how the tax is calculated, it would increase the cost of every manufactured item without exception and raise the cost of living substantially. The author, recognizing this, suggests $4,000 exemptions for each individual, rebates for exports and charges for imports. More drawbacks and exemptions would undoubtedly be added case by case as need arises. The struggle for a good fit would never end.

nytimes_articles.headline: SUNY Chief Retires Proudly
nytimes_articles.abstract: A PINK ballet slipper sits on a bookshelf in Dr. Sheldon N. Grebstein's office on the campus of the State University of New York here. The slipper, signed by members of the dance division faculty, was presented to Dr. Grebstein in honor of his retirement next month after 12 years as the president of SUNY Purchase.    The juxtaposition of the pointed shoe and books on American literature, Dr. Grebstein's academic specialty, is emblematic of the institution that he has guided through declining state support and rising enrollment since 1981. He leaves, he said, regretting that he could not create the "marvelous synergy" he envisioned between the School for the Arts and the College of Letters and Science, two of the campus's main divisions. (The third is the division of continuing education.) That dream was thwarted, he said, by the continual budget cuts that have plagued SUNY Purchase during most of his tenure.

nytimes_articles.headline: Shawn Holmes, Charles Steers 3d
nytimes_articles.abstract: Shawn Holmes, a daughter of Diane D. Holmes and John B. Holmes, both of Purchase, N.Y., was married on Friday to Charles Robert Coster Steers 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Steers Jr. of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Patrick O'Neil, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye.   Mrs. Steers, 31, is a sales representative for Absorba Ltd., a maker of childrens' clothing in New York. She graduated from Rollins College. Her father retired as the president of Izod Ltd., the apparel manufacturer in New York.

nytimes_articles.headline: TRANSACTIONS
nytimes_articles.abstract: Baseball American League  KANSAS CITY ROYALS -- Signed Gary Gaetti, third baseman. Recalled Bill Sampen, pitcher, from Omaha of the American Association. Optioned Craig Wilson, infielder, to Omaha. Designated Harvey Pulliam, outfielder, for assignment. SAN JOSE SHARKS -- Traded Peter Ahola, defenseman, to the Tampa Bay Lightning for Dave Capuano, center. nytimes_articles.headline: Trina Pew, Matthew Gandal
nytimes_articles.abstract: Catherine Douglas Pew, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George L. Pew Jr. of Villanova, Pa., was married there yesterday to Matthew David Gandal, a son of Gabriele Gandal of Chevy Chase, Md., and Alvin Gandal of Washington. The Rev. Carol Ann Taylor, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.   The bride and the bridegroom both graduated from Trinity College, Hartford.   Mrs. Gandal, who is known as Trina, is a teacher at St. Patrick's Episcopal Day School in Washington. Her father is a vice chairman of the Philadelphia Maritime Museum. Her mother, Sally Pew, is a director of Planned Parenthood of Southeastern Pennsylvania.

nytimes_articles.headline: Q and A
nytimes_articles.abstract: Overcharge Dispute Question: I live in a rent-stabilized brownstone and have a rent dispute with the landlord. I filed an overcharge claim with the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal and an expedite order to process the claim has been issued. The department, however, has told me the process will take 60 to 90 days and my landlord has told me he is going to sell the building. He also asked me to show the apartment.

nytimes_articles.headline: Jennifer Rothkopf, Marc A. Ness
nytimes_articles.abstract: Jennifer Rothkopf, a daughter of Barbara and Arthur Rothkopf of Washington, was married yesterday to Marc Aimont Ness, a son of Jeannine Ness and Dr. Gayl Ness of Ann Arbor, Mich. Cantor Siegfried Rowe performed the ceremony in Annapolis, Md., at the weekend home of the bride's parents.    Ms. Rothkopf, 30, is keeping her name. She graduated from Oberlin College and is now a second-year medical student at Case Western Reserve University. Her father, a former Deputy Secretary of Transportation in the Bush Administration, is to become the acting president of Lafayette College in Easton, Pa., next month. Her mother is the administrator at Woodley House, a psychiatric and social-services agency in Washington.

nytimes_articles.headline: New Hockey Museum in Toronto
nytimes_articles.abstract: Civic boosters in Toronto like to say it is a world-class city of many dimensions, including sports. The diverse, modern metropolis on the shore of Lake Ontario boasts of the Blue Jays, who won baseball's World Series last fall and play in a stadium with a retractable dome, quite a tourist attraction in itself. And there is serious discussion about the National Basketball Association expanding north of the border and putting a team in the city.   Still, Toronto's sports soul belongs to hockey, and it is hockey, particularly Canadian hockey, that is honored in a new museum, the Hockey Hall of Fame, which opened last week.

nytimes_articles.headline: Devils Sign Two Young Defensemen
nytimes_articles.abstract: The New Jersey Devils announced Friday the signing of two 19-year-old defensemen, third-round draft choice CALE HULSE and seventh-round selection GEORDIE KINNEAR. Hulse, a 6-foot-3-inch, 210-pounder played last season for Portland in the Western Hockey League. He had 10 goals and 26 assists in 72 games and amassed 284 penalty minutes. Kinnear, 6-1 and 200, played 58 games last season for Peterborough in the Ontario Hockey League, scoring six goals and 22 assists. He had 161 penalty minutes.

nytimes_articles.headline: Move to Curb Incentives To Businesses
nytimes_articles.abstract: Concerned that some cities and counties in New York have gone too far in their efforts to attract new jobs and to keep companies that are being wooed by other states, the State Legislature is seriously considering measures that would curtail some of the incentives that could be offered.   The proposals are intended to increase accountability and to limit some of the incentives, like sales-tax waivers, that local industrial development agencies have offered to companies, usually to keep them from leaving town. While such incentives have been used liberally by New York City to keep companies like Prudential Securities and the Morgan Stanley Group from moving to New Jersey or elsewhere, the legislators say their bills are aimed at abuses that have been reported around the state.
